Neat aroma.  Tart pine, peaches, smoky, and a sweet/ripe mash backing it up.

Thats a lot of big flavors for a dipa.  Definite smoky/peaty flavors with tart, piny hops and bitter grapefruit.  Sweet and juicy with that bitter grapefruit overload.  Nice dry, puckering, bitter finish.
After having this I realize I hate double IPAs.  I liked it better than the hopslam I tried last week, but not by much.  Bitter hoppy-ness once again.  Ugh.

Clear golden beer with a decent white head. Overwhelming hoppy aroma: pine, grapefruit/citrus, flowers, soap and some alcohol. Quite sweet, but the  hops are dominating all the way. Starts dry, but in the end it leaves me with a sticky mouthfeel. (Need some water with this). I dont know what to think about this one; its impressing in some way, but unbalanced and one-dimensional.

Bottle @ home. Yellow-orange appearance with a medium sized white head. Piney, resiny, earthy hoppy nose. Sticky, resiny, piney hoppy, grapefruity flavor with a sticky mouth feel. Bitter, huge grapefruity hoppy finish. Excellent IIPA.
A perfect balance of citrus, pine and floral fruit.  Smooth, dry without bitterness, truly the best of its style.

A: clear golden orange, with a 1-finger white head

S: Sticky pine aroma, with some citrus and mango.

T: Right from the fridge its malty and grassy, and a bit one-note. As it warms, more pine comes out and a pleasant, mild sweetness.

M: medium body, medium linger. Some bitterness in the back of the mouth and throat, but not much. Low-medium carbonation

O: A nicely balanced DIPA that drinks very nicely. Doesnt knock your socks off with any particularly intense or exotic flavors, but is something I would definitely drink regularly if I could.

Bottle (09 notes, Indianapolis).  Pours a very hazy darker marigold orange, with a decent white head.  Lots of mango in the aroma too me, but does register a good deal of grapefruit and some solid sweetness.  Much maltier than I expected, and sadly I dont think I got the freshest possible sample...no date on the bottle. Lots of sweeter fruit hoppiness (ie mango), but some citrus comes in, with some hefty maltiness that keeps a sweeter finish.  Nice brew, and need to get is as fresh as possible...then will re-rate.

UPDATED: DEC 17, 2013 On tap at Three Floyds.  Pours a nice orange colour.  Heavy hoppy, citrusy, floral aroma, and an amazing fruity flavour with sweet malt and a bitter finish.  Thick body.  Incredible amazing stuff.

Bomber-Pours an orange-golden, almost clear pour with an off-white to beige head. It sure has a hop-dominated aroma, fruity, tropical fruits and citrus, and pine, with a heavy maltyness in the background. Nice flavor too, fruity, piney, malty, quite sweet and an amazing Hop bite. Fruity, piney, bitter finish as well. Full body. Loved this IIPA, beautiful mix of hops and malt.

Shared bottle with sherm1016....as noted elsewhere - can smell the nose before it gets to glass...yummm!  Lots of citris / smooth hops....this is a huge contrast to so many IPAs that taste hotter than they are....this one tastes very mild booze wise...but is really hot...sip  it slow.

"ITS NOT NORMAL"

Poured from a bottle into a Stone IPA tulip glass. Jesus I can smell it already and it is several feet from my face. Beer is orangish / yellow carbonation moderate, hazy (like most DIPA) and forms a thin head of small to medium bubbles. Lacing is high.

Smells like a lot of malt, strong citrus hop aroma. This has an aggressive aroma. Really sweet smelling, no alcohol in the aroma though.

Full bodied, hops are not the first thing that I taste. There is a nice sweetness and great hop flavors in the midpalate, the back end is not as bitter as I thought. Second taste, bitterness is growing but still not as strong as I expected / wanted. I wish there was a date on the bottle but alas, I cannot find one. Overall a decent and drinable DIPA.

Serving type: bottle

On tap at 3Floyds Brewpub.  Appearance is slightly hazy, light orange color with medium head.  Aroma is heavy on the citrus especially mango and peach.  Taste is citrus up front with the mango really standing out.  Underneath the citrus theres a very good malt flavor.  Then theres the hops.  Floral and citrus hop flavors are really powerful in this beer leaving behind a strong bitterness on the palate.  Although the hops are heavy, the bitterness is not overwhelming being balanced by the malts.  Truly an amazing beer.

I drank this from a bottle into a chalice. It pours a clear orangy gold with a very carbonated white head and very good lacing. It smells wonderful, hints of citrus, hops and a surprising peach comes through. After the great start, the taste wasnt exactly what I was expecting. It was very fruity so I was expecting to taste a little of that, instead I really just tasted alcohol and hops.

From the bottle this is average, on tap its great and worth having.

This is a dangerous beer, with the alcohol playing only a subtile peppery role. very nice golden color, with a modest head and some lacing direct from the Brewery.  Wonderful full mouth sweet aromatic hops.
One of my favorite beers. Very hoppy with citrus. Wonderful smell wonderful taste. =)

I DO NOT Like IPAs as a general rule.  This is THE BEST IPA EVER, and one of the five best in my very limited history.  Well worth the cost of ordering via UPS.  This could be a gift for my beering buddies, but I doubt it will make it to delivery.  THANK YOU

22 oz. Thanks to tasting with Doug and Eric. Poured golden, dense head. Huge hop nose with a touch of grass and citrus. Great malt taste, finished with a firm bitterness. Noticeable hops throughout. This was not bad.

UPDATED: JAN 12, 2014 Poured from a nicely decorated 22 ounce bomber. Has a 2 finger thick dense off white head that quickly recedes and leaves behind a nice lacing. Color is of dark copper/orange.

Smell is intense, when I first popped the cap off this one it was a tropical fruit surprise. In the glass it is very hoppy and sweet smelling. Has a decidedly citrus hop scent, not too spicy. There is a hint of pine needles. Hop mania through and through.

Mmmm a refreshing hop bomb. The hops attack your palate furiously and do not relent. Citrus hops come in a barrage, then a slight bit of sweet biscuity malt hits, finishing with joyful hop bitterness. Yep, the malt is there, in the middle, but this is a hop lovers dream. Mouthfeel is smooth and perfectly carbonated.

There is no problem in finishing this 22 ouncer, could have gone for a 750 of this or heck even a liter, the alcohol is definitely noticeable and a bit warming but doesnt really show it self too much too be off-putting enough for one not to easily down one of these quickly.

An excellent DIPA.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 08-17-2009 22:34:13

Have had it since and have never been as impressed, keep in mind draft only, i dont get bottles ue to not knowing the age.

Aroma just as bottle says pineapple mango citrus fruit and hoppiness like a tropical smooothie. Pour a slightly hazy golden orange great lacing thin white head. Very cool taste of tropical citrusy hops, big mango and pineapple, some grapefruit and peach, resiny hops, with a terrific but not too sweet malt back bone. MF medium body great mild to medium prickly carb. ABV extremely well hidden. Overall a bench mark IIPA in a league with the top elitists of this category. Outstanding.

An incredible Imperial IPA. Can it get more balanced than this. I have had Plinty the Younger and hopslam. Hopslam has nothing on this. Pliny is still incredible but this is everything youd want in a IIPA. The palate and mouthfeel is so awesome. The finish is crisp and dry with a spicy ending. The hops are out of this world but balanced beyond i could imagine.This makes me what to go back and rerate every IIPA and IPA ive rated. The isnt that soapy thing going on. The malt backbone, as FFF puts it, is the key this beer being so amazing (i believe.) A life changing brew!!!!

This is one of my favorite beers. I love the double IPA style, this is a perfect example. Looks good in the glass. The smell foreshadows the taste with big hop presents and alot of citrus tones. Somehow every drink gets better than the last. "chronic beer" A+.

UPDATED: FEB 10, 2015 Won second place in a blind taste test with fellow local experts. Lost to hop stoopid. Starts as a perfectly balanced almost amber ale then the hops come in a reveal a delicious bitterness. Amazing beer.

Rerate: 9-12-11. Fresh bottle straight from brewery. Grapefruit, apples and weed on the nose. Slightly hop foward, rich, complex. This is a  perfect dipa.

Large format bottle in snifter.  Nice blonde color, clear.  Strong citrus, honey, straw malt aroma.  White lacing.  Medium carbonation. Taste like a Halls lemon cough drop  (honey-lemon flavors with a hot alcohol burn).  Nice medium body.  Slick.  Slight lingering hop bitterness.  Citrus and alcohol overpower the malt.  Tastes out of balance.  Disappointing coming from Three Floyds.

This takes the cake!  thanks Dave.  The best I have ever had.  Berry Grapefruit nose,  This the most perfectly balanced imp ipa ever!  It is sooo smooth, goes down so easy.  Creamy, hides the alcohol.  I hardly left any room in my ratings for anything too get any better.  Finishes smooth and clean.

Bottle from CrackedKettle. Poured with a honey yellow color, and an off-white, lacing head. Aroma of honey, spices like cinnamon, white grapes, apple, grapefruit, pine, somewhat tarty. Medium dense with high carbonation, and bitter aftertaste. Very well done, outstanding beer.

Bomber from Cracked Kettle, Amsterdam, courtesy of Balazs, thanks!
Poured hazy orange-amber with a thick creamy off white head, leaves lots of lacing. Floral and citrus hops mainly in the nose with caramel maltines, honey and vanilla. Complex body with a huge citrus and hop explosion. A wide selection of fruits: grapefruit, lemon-lime, orange peel and some figs too. Malts add a balancing bit of sweetness with tastes of caramel, some freaky cocoa, honey and vanilla.

Sure, I downed this fella after quite a number of other brews in the same night, but I was blown away. It was my first of the elite DIPAs (Pliny, Hopslam, etc.) so I didnt have a lot to compare it to directly. Loved it.

Got this one in a trade with Joeybeerbelly, thanks for the opportunity to try this.

Pours a really clear deep golden/orange with a fluffy white head that really hangs around then laces all the way down. Aroma is hops. Spicy, Piney, Citrus and grapefruit hop goodness. There is a little caramel malt hidden deep underneath as well. The taste is really nice, it isnt as hoppy as the smell would suggest. I taste some caramel from the malt then the grapefruit kind of sneaks in on you. Leaves a citrus twang on the tongue. Well done Imp Ipa, very balanced, very drinkable.

UPDATED: MAR 8, 2011 The Imperial I.P.A should be its nickname. If you want a memorable Double I.P.A that will paint your eyes with a clementine appearance and a  euphoric jubilation that ends in a smile. Wrap your lips around the tip then sip and let the drip of gold covered  caramel pour down your greedy gullet cause you will be whispering "Nobody can have the precious except Smegel" as you near the last few drops of this complex yet effortless brew that demands your full attention.

Orange gold pour medium head strong carbonation with floral richness a delight to the nose citrus hop malt character comes to caramel notes of peach pine flavour resinous fizzy an ibu medium to medium high peel of citrus no doubt grapefruit peach apricot caramel maslt well defined mango sweet pine hop finish a top imp ipa aroma superb tastes are strong on the palate leaving a wonderful true aftertaste of fruit fizz lasting bitter

22 oz bomber poured into a pint glass.

4.5 A: Hazy medium orange color. Two fingers of thick creamy white head. Good retention, leaves lots of lacing.

4.0 S: Floral and citrus hops mainly. Orange stands out. Some caramel maltiness too. Not a whole hell of a lot of aroma though.

4.5 T: Very complex set of citrus and hop sensations. A variety of fruits: grapefruit, orange, perhaps a bit of lemon too. Not overly bitter, hops are showcased instead in the flavor. Malts add a balancing bit of sweetness, but honestly who gives a crap about malts in a hopbomb.

4.5 M: Medium body. Not heavy at all, but still doubly creamy and very smooth.

5.0 D: Very good obviously. No flaws, but not perfection either.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 03-14-2009 21:59:58

(22oz bottle courtesy of Alpar!).  Pours copper with 1 finger off-white head.  Active carbonation and nice lacing.  I can smell the citrus with the glass next to me.  Also, aroma of mango and other tropical fruits.  Taste is sweet with bitterness on the end.  The sweetness and bitterness are so perfectly balanced. Creamy mouthfeel with a bitter finish. For 100IBU, this beer is so smooth.  Great beer!

Thank you so much to my Secret Santa fear025.  I could drink copious amounts of this beer.  The perfect example of a Imperial IPA.  Pours a gorgeous clear amber golden with a small white cap.  Aroma is extreme floral and citrus, also subtle earthy pine hop.  Taste fills your mouth with a dry floral and intense grapefruit citrus.  Pine hop in the aftertaste but its so smooth and so complex its just awesome.  Me want more!

22oz bottle from hrking 
Appearance: Clear amber with a nice big white head that doesnt go away and a medium amount of sticky lacing left in the glass 
Aroma: Grapefruit, tropical fruits and floral 
Taste: Grapefruit, floral with a bitter pine resin and dry finish 
Very nice IIPA, well balanced. 1,000th rating!

From notes 03/2010. 

Autumnal: orange, amber, and yellow as I drink down the pint. A light tan one-finger head leaves wide rings of lace. 

Heavily resinous in the nose. Some lemon and mango as well, with a thinly caramel backbone. 
Overwhelmingly piney and floral on the tongue. Like chewing on a bundle of pine needles, while taking short breaks to savor in some tropical fruit. Hop-forward, but the bitterness on the tongue is manageable. Some malty sweetness comes through, but only after the tongue acclimates. 

Very little alcohol on this one, but youll feel it. On tap, its creamy and sticky. Not your average (double) IPA. Medium-low carbonation. This one will sneak up on you.

From notes:

Pours a dark ruby/golden orange color with burnt orange hues when held to a light source and a two finger frothy, pillowy white foam head. Excellent retention, only slowly fading into a lasting cap that lingers throughout the entire glass and coats the pint with large chunks of soapy lacing.

Dank, resinous hop aroma with lots of earthy pine and citrus fruit notes. Hints if grapefruit, pineapple and lemon peel as well as pine needle and sunlte malt presence that takes away from the hops slightly.

Chewy full body with lots of uber fresh dank, oily hop flavor. Plenty of sweet citrus fruit notes as well as earthy bitter pine flavorthat the aroma suggested. Hints of grapefruit, pineapple, mango and lemon peel. The malt backbone is present and provides nice balance but isnt as prominent as the aroma suggests. There is a sligt lactic/creamy quality mid-palate that makes this beer extremely quaffable. The perfect balance of bitter, floral, sweet and slight malt. The ABV is excellently masked and there is a bitter dry finish. One of the best IPAs Ive ever had.

A: poured into a snifter. Color is a cloudy amber that is more orange than red. nice slightly off white head that has a low retention rate and leads to faint lacing.

S: strong rich oaky aroma that reminds me of an oak aged stout. Strong hops aroma that is mostly citrus and pine, with pine being the lead. some small amounts of vanilla, coconut and some cherries.

T: amazing flavor! nice toasted and caramel malts supply a great backdrop for this beer. Wonderful citrus flavors from the hops, more of a sweet orange flavor. Some mild pine flavors. no strong alcohol flavors either.

M: amazingly smooth for almost 10%. medium to full bodied. low to medium carbonation.

D: this beer is phenomenal. smooth, delicious, and it lacks the high alcohol taste. granted its not a session beer at 9.5%, but I could drink this all day long. unbelievable.

Bouteille de 22 oz. Merci beaucoup Dany! Arômes invitants de fruits tropicaux et dagrumes. Légère présence dalcool. Robe pêche et légèrement trouble, peu de mousse et effervescence assez faible. En bouche, la bière présente des houblons très juteux et fruités (fruits tropicaux et agrumes). Le malt, juste assez rond et sucré, présente des notes de biscuit. Finale très longue présentant une belle amertume de houblon fruité et une chaleur réchauffante dalcool. Très bon et équilibré !

22 oz bottle courtesy of thomcatr3t .  Pours a hazy golden amber with a small white head with good retention and strong lacing.  Aroma is strong with citrus and grapefruit hops and caramel malt.  Initial taste is sweet citrus with some light pine.  Finish is bitter with caramel malt and some breadyness.  Medium body.  Light carbonation.  Good beer, but a little on the sweet side.

Pours a hazy pale orange with a big frothy off-white head. Aroma has strong notes of mango and citric hops on a very malty body. The taste is amazingly complex - sweet mango-peach rapidly turning intensely bitter. The finish is lingering bitterness. The taste of the beer makes the mouth water making the beer less dry than I would like but I suppose that this is a testament to the beers flavor. Excellent.

Really nice pale yellow-orange pour.  Slight haze with a thin white head.  Lots of hops on the nose.  Piny and citrus with notes of grapefruit.  Light sweetness.  Moderate sweetness on the tongue with piny grapefruit hops.  Very clean.  Just a bit too sweet for my taste.

Bomber. Poured golden orange, nice frothy white head that sticks around forever. Nose is mango, orange, pine, slight toffee presence. More mango and orange on the tongue, along with sugared grapefruit, fresh pine needles, and a big caramel malt backbone. Insanely good, well worth the hype.

Pours a cloudy orange with a nice white head. Aroma of sweet citrus ( orange, lemon, grapefruit and hint of pineapple). Some hints of apples and pears also. Semi-sweet taste follows the nose with a nice mouthfeel and carbonation. Nice slow hops bitter to finish. Alcohol is hidden well. Wow what a great beer.

My first sampling from 3Fs. I was not disappointed. Very well-balanced IPA. The aroma and taste initially is that of fruit cocktail juice (peach, pineapple, w/ HOPS); then you get a bitter resiny middleground. Nice alcohol on the finish. Dont know if I should have paid all the shipping charges (to TX), but I will try more of the 3Fs. Very happy with this. Any other recommendations would be appreciated from this brewer.

Orangish hazy amber, foamy off white head. Aroma of sweet caramel malt, some hops-citrus. Flavor is a well balanced combination of malt and hops-just enough sweetness and body to carry the hopload. Great balance of hop bitterness and flavor, everything is just right. Excellent!!! I LOVE THIS BEER!!! One of the elite IIPAs in the U.S.A.

A-pours a clear dark golden orange with a creamy white head leaving a decent lace on the glass.

S-light notes of caramel and doughy malts up front but very faint as the hops dominate.  Tons of citrus fruits, plenty of grapefruit, notes of mango and tangerine.  Hop explosion and still has notes of malt body.

T-the taste is just as good, this has the malt presence with notes of resignous piney hops, the citrus takes over and doesnt let go.  pineapple, tangerines, mango.  This is good stuff!

M-medium body, very creamy on the palate, syrupy feel to it, the body isnt as huge as the sticky feel would imply.  rather juicy with strong carbonation and a crisp semi dry finish and a light to moderate bitterness.

D-hop explosion with hints of balance but no where near detracting from the juicy citrus flavors.  the bitterness is there and lingers slightly but it is lighter and not over powering at all.  great stuff, I do enjoy a dreadnaught!

Bomber.  More than an inch of head.  Aroma is very citrusy and wonderful.  Flavor is more citrus with noticeable mango and peach flavors.  Truly an outstanding IPA, and I really wish FFF distributed in PA so I could drink this regularly.

Pours a clear copper color with a thick white head.  The aroma is wonderfully full of pine and citrus grapefruits coupled with a touch of earth.  Very tart and bitter on the palate.  Full of citrus fruits and pine, earth, and hops.  Very good beer.

Thanks to my lovely fiancee for picking me up a bottle from the newest batch.

A: Dark orange that is transparent, although with some haze. Good white head that leaves behind excellent lacing.

S: Lots of sweet citrus and pine hops. A myriad of citrus fruits defines the aroma of this one.

T: Again, lots of hops that pack in the bitterness and sweetness. A pretty good malt base backing everything up.

M: Fairly light carbonation with a light-to-medium body.

D: Quite drinkable. Not as much to handle as something like HopSlam, but not quite as tasty either. All around, definitely one of the top five DIPAs that Ive had.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 04-29-2009

Bottle pours crystal clear golden with minimal white head. Aroma is intense tropical hops with notes of peach and citrus. Flavor is similar to aroma, but with a pronounced malt backbone and just enough sweetness to balance this big brew.

I poured a 22 oz bottle into 2 snifters (sharing, caring, etc.). Each lay shimmering, opaque, and orange, with plenty of floaties and a one-inch head that quickly dissipated into substantial lacing. In short, this looked just like an ipa should. It also smelled fantastic, with an abundance of juicy hops. This suggested citrus bitterness in the flavor, but the malt profile more than met the hoppy challenge, shining through with notes of buttered biscuits and pale honey. This drank like a dream, smooth and elegant in the mouth. In short, this was certainly worth the hype and the trouble taken to acquire it (since this brewery, sadly, does not sell in GA).

Aroma: citrus, grapefruit; Appearance: hazy, yellow-gold; Taste: very green hops, very citrus, especially grapefruit, a little sweet; Palate: potent bitter but enjoyable aftertaste, very fresh for an Imperial IPA, not as sweet and heavy as other Imperials Ive had, which is actually a good thing, Overall: this is a good middle road between a DIPA and an Imperial IPA

aroma- caramel, flowers, dry hop, light peach, orange, mango, bread.  pours hazy orange gold.  taste is bread, caramel, earthy hop, light fruitiness, nectarine, mango aftertaste.  palate is refreshing, carbonated, medium body.
Very good Imperial Pale Ale.  Purchased in bomber in Chicago and tried at home in Michigan.  I wish we could get this here.  One of the best IIPAs.

Bottle via trade with 12many, big thanks Patrick. Clear gold pour, rather thin white head, lots of lacing. Aroma is very citrusy/fruity - pineapples and grapefruit absolutely beautiful nose. Taste is very bitter but is well "balanced" by the malty flavors too. Palate is one of this beers strongest points - Smooth and silky at first - it lets the fruity flavors develop before ending in a well carbonated, dry, hop kick in the mouth finish. I dont like IIPAs very much, but this is a work of art.
Bottle - Bursting Citrus nose.  Extremely balanced sweet finish, delicious IPA, a must try.
UPDATED: MAY 30, 2011 65cl, American brew, thx to Wimenels!, complex bitter brew, yet very balanced, hazy, good head, very good brew, yet very expensive!

Split a 22oz bomber with a friend (sent to me from "Fanbrew" in Indiana)Appearance: Pure orange. Mostly clear with a slight hop haze. Little, yellow, frothy head. Great lacing, though. Not very bubbly (surprisingly).Aroma: more like tropical fruit juice than beer. The bottle is right on - mango, peach and citrus notes with some flowery, perfume-like scent. Very enticing.Taste: Just like the nose its tropical fruit and citrus with a bold, bitter finish. Hops pack a punch here making for a wicked robust palate. Bitterness takes some getting used to, though.Mouthfeel: For such a strong beer its a little thinner that Id expect. Thankfully it doesnt tear up my tongue while its in my mouth (the hops do that afterwards, though).Drinkability: Starts off quite juice-like and refreshing, but becomes drier and bitterer with each sip. Thankfully the 9.5% ABV is well used as there is no heat or warmth to the beer and it goes down smooth. Still, this beer might be a little too bitter for its own good.Overall: Reminds me of Bells Hopslam sans honey. I really love the juicy taste but the bitterness is hard to handle on its own. Theres no way Id be able to drink a bottle of this by myself without some super spicy wings. So close to a perfect beer!

Oh man, this is my favorite IIPA.  I count myself lucky to live in the Chicago area.  I only wish theyd sell it in 6 packs instead of only bombers, Id buy it much more regularly.  $11-12 per bomber is a bit steep, but a nice treat every once in a while.  Great hops aroma, hops taste and a wonderful mouthfeel.  One of the best beers Ive ever had.

Bottle split with Pat and Vinny, courtesy of Pat. Pours a hazy amber body with nice white lacing that lasts throughout. Aroma is sharp citrus and fresh pine hop. Mouthfeel is great with amazing notes of fresh citrus and pine hop.

Bottle. 25.4 oz. Split with James and Vin. Pours a dark, murky orange amber with a thick, lacy, frothy white head. Aroma of oranges, grapefruit, vanilla, haze, calm honey and amber, mango, and caramel. Fuller bodied with a citrusy, sticky, chewy palate. Finishes with a slow, wet, hoppy kick. Very mild booze. Excellent double IPA, but the Arctic Panzer Wolf takes the win for tonights tasting.
Big bottle split with Dave and his cousin Ben.  Super bitter aroma with citrus.  Taste isnt AS aggressive as the nose and really is a great double IPA.  Delicious.

I could not avoid my huge expectations based on the overall ratings for this beer.  The peach and citrus aroma, and crisp citrus hop taste were fantastic, but I was left with a bitter dryness, where I would like to have had a stronger malt sweetness.  Overall a good beer, but I think there are a few other IPAs which do it better.

A friend brought me this bottle back from his most recent trip to Chicago. When it was bottled, I dont know, but it was opened 10/13, about two months after I got it. Kept refrigerated and away from any kind of light since.

Aroma: the description of mango and peach in the nose is dead on, definitely with that piney, Centennial hop smell.  Somewhat weird, but I got a touch ripe berry hints as well.  There is a firm, but manageable nutty/carmel aroma too.

appearance: deep copper, hop haze, and a thin, but beautifully lacey, white head.

taste:  no roughness in the hop flavor, like a thin velvet hotel blanket of hops getting pulled over your palate.  The carbonation and very danky blend of hops slowly fizzle out with the carbonation with a rich malty comforter.  Reminiscent of many DIPAs, but with a fruitier hop blend.  Im assuming some clean bittering hops, and some big mid boil additions of centennials, otherwise im not getting much late addition hop flavors, but i know that can age out quickly. 

palate:  big, bold, nice hop nose, big hop flavor, but a lingering palate of toffee caramel.  The hop flavor does still stick with you but the malt domninates.  Big body, but not like a barleywine.  good carbonation too.

Bottle. Pours a deep orange amber color with a flufy white, slightly tan head that collars around the glass as it settles. Nice lace forms as the head goes down. A very malty, sweet smelling citrus hop flavor eminates from the nose. Very nice smelling. Tropical fruit type aroma. Nice medium mouthfeel. The taste is sweet upfront with a nice fruity, hoppy flavors that lingers for a while. Very slight alcohol bite at the end. Very easy drinking for being a 9.5%. Really well balanced beer. Totally deserves to be rated as high as it is.

From a bottle, thanks to Jay (fear025). Pours a rich, clear dark orange color, with a decent amount of head. Aroma is floral hops and citrus, very fresh. Flavor is fresh hops and some citrus. Palate is medium and slightly oily. Overall amazing imperial IPA.

22oz bottle in a snifter.  Pours a rich orangeish golden color with a thick, lingering off-white head.   Aroma strong of hops, citrusy and floral and caramel malt and alcohol.  This beers flavor is exactly what I described in the aroma, but its so much more complex when you drink it.  Thick texture.  Its by far my favorite beer that is labelled "IPA."

clear orange pour with a nice whitehead.  Good lacing on the glass. Aroma is citrus, pine, mandarin orange, juicy hops throughout.  Flavor is citrusy, bitter, some sweet caramel notes.  Really big beer with some massive flavor notes, but decidedly clean and pleasant.  Really tasty.

Bottle from Whole Paycheck in Milwaukee.  Its been a while since Ive had Dreadnaught, so I picked up a bottle to give it anothe go.  This really is as good as it gets.  A beautiful orange-yellow color, a clean white head, and nice lacing.  The flavor is an perfect balance of malt and all the great pine and citrus hop flavors.  Not sure when I will get another bottle, but I know it will be great.

22 oz bottle. Hazy orange, small off white head. Big hops aroma, sweet floral and citrusy. Up front hop flavor is very complex yet subtle, nicely balanced by sweet caramel malt.. Bitter hop finish. Amazing how big the hops flavor is without being overwhelming. Really, really nice!
World Class IPA, between the flavor and the punch you will be delighted with this brew.

UPDATED: MAY 24, 2011 75cl bottle from a friend.
Excellent IPA. Very tasty beer. Yummy bitter taste.  Grapefruit aroma

Pours a copper color with a small white head. Aroma is all hops, kinda sweet and of citrus & peachy hops.  Not overpowering at all. Citrus and some floral/pine hops hit at the start with a smooth malt backbone. Very well balanced. Gets better and better with every drink (maybe the 9.5% alc. content helps with that). Awesome beer.
Beautiful hop aroma of grapefruit and mango. Wonderful sweet malt meets bitter finishing hops. Super citrusy with a longlasting bitter.

(bottle - 22 oz) Copper color with a creamy tan head. Big hoppy and citrusy aroma. Not too hoppy or bitter but perfectly balanced. Awesome citrus and floral flavor at the beginning and a smooth and sweet middle. The hops are there underneath but theyre not overly dry or biting. Very smooth and well blended. Highly enjoyable.

Ar: Piney hops, citrusy/tropical fruit hops.  Extremely powerful aroma, completely mouthwatering.
Ap: Pours a light copper-orange with a 1" head that pillows over the top of the glass.  Nice lace.
T: Peach and apricot are the first two notes that come to my palate.  They are followed by a lovely caramel malt backbone that balances the hops nicely.  Piney hops with a huge dose of hop bitterness on the finish with a very minimal alcohol burn.
P: Medium-thick, creamy body with surprisingly soft carbonation.

Another phenomenal offering from FFF.
Had this on draft at Osheas.Peachy, mango, citrus goodness. Goes down way too smooth for almost 10%. Has nice white lacing and gets better as you drink it.

Tasted on draft at Local Option.  Pours clear, bright orange with a fluffy white head that leaves heavy lace.  The nose is intensely bitter hops with the great blend of caramel malt and just a hint of yeastiness.  The flavor is somewhat sweet with the hops overcoming quickly and a nice bread maltiness.  The body is full with lively carbonation and a long bitter finish.

Burnt orange and sports little to no head. Nose is sweet and fruity blended with some strong grapefruit, lemon, peach and apricot tones. Taste is extremely strong hop flavor and evident malts creating a richness that I just cant get enough of. Feels slick and puts a nice bitter buzz on the palate. Easy drinking. Wonderful. Had this many times and will have it again tomorrow.

UPDATED: APR 1, 2011 Location: 22 oz bottle from Binnys Beverage Depot (Naperville), 4/1/11


Overall Impression: 
Sammy brought me another one, and you know what, at only a 4.2 I seem to have underrated this one!  It is really good.  Im bumping the score up...  I could drink this stuff all day.

Location: 22 oz bottle from Binnys Beverage Depot (Naperville), 9/10/10


Aroma: The nose has some nice hoppy flavors to it made up of grapefruit, pine, and mango 

Appearance: A mostly clear golden-orange color with a small white head that leaves a bit of lace

Flavor: The taste is rather hoppy with a citrusy sweetness, pine, and a nice bitter finish

Palate: It has a nice mouthfeel, fairly smooth, soft carbonation, and a fairly long duration 

Overall Impression: 
Thanks goes out to Sammy for bringing this one to NJ for me.  This is really quite good.  I think it loves up to the hype.  A very solid brew.  I can see why it is considered to be a top quality DIPA.   (9/4/8/4/17)

Bomber in trade with Fear025. Quite hard to come by in these parts.  Rosy flowery hops prevail and turn my week old skunky basement (really, it let loose in the basement on the cat)  Into a hop yard of lusciousness. Ahhhhh.  Some spotty lacing in some type of wacky Morse code glyph sense.  A medium deep amber with a bit of translucence.  Hop nose sweetens as beer warms in .5L column glass.   Sweet malts and copious amounts of flower hops roll about my mouth.  A finish that is noticed only after it has occurred.  My mind lingers on the labels statement of "it aint normal"  I concur.  Well worth the second box.   Thanks Jay!

22 oz bottle, Where do you begin. Straight from the pour I was taken back by the lighter hazy copper color. The head was tight with an off white color and plenty carbonation and ample lace to accompany my memories sip by sip. On nose there are aromatic notes of ripe citrus, followed by a grassy hop, the slightest touch of bread, and a sneak peak into the alcohol. On mouth this is a warming balanced DIPA with notes of orange peel, apricot, and a zing of hop flavors. The finish lingers and lingers and when I wake up tomorrow it still may be there.

On tap at Sugar Maple, the one bar I know that sells craft brew at a cheaper/equal rate then retailers.  The one thing about this beer that needs to be noted and praised is its nose.  Probably the most deliciously smelling IPA around.  Strong citrus with fruity hops, youre almost already satisfied without even having a sip.  Tap produces a great foamy head that differs from the bottle and sticks around longer.  Taste is an amazing balance fresh citrus, like a peeled orange, paired with bitter hops that do not dominate the brew, unlike a lot of IIPAs do.  As the beer warms the malts start showing there head and become the cherry atop the sundae.  Wish this could come in 6 packs, cause $10 is a bit steep for 22oz of beer, but then again you know you are guaranteed quality craft beer at its finest.  Cheers fellow hopaholics!

UPDATED: FEB 11, 2011 Pours cloudy golden copper with solid white head and sticky lace; nice carbonation. Nose of tropical fruit, licorice, grass, pine and mint. Taste of mango, grapefruit, orange, and caramel.  A very balanced brew.
I liked this beer, it was fruity in aroma and had some citrus in the taste. Great for summer or really anytime

Bottle from Kevin at Hangar brought back from Wisconsin. Pours a golden orange with small tiny bubbly head. Aroma is amazing with tons of pineapple, mango, fresh citrus peel. Taste is tons of citrus with some bitterness and definite malt backbone. Great carbonation. Great beer!

Bottle, thanks beardface. bright orange pour, white head, sticky lacing. Aroma is in your face citrus especially orange and some peach. Flavor brings the peach out more and the orange fades a bit, a tiny bit of pine lurking in the back. Fairly sweet malt profile with not too much bitter considering, great beer and I wish there was more around these parts for us to consume.

Pours a deep orange amber color with a white soapy head.  Has an aroma of grapefruit, pine, and caramel.  Has a sweet grapefruit taste with a nice harsh hop hit and nice layer of maltiness.  Nice mouthfeel.  Nice resiny finish.  The sweet grapefruit, mango start is great.  Very excellent.  Not top five worthy in my mind, but a very good DIPA.

Imperial is the word to describe this heavily hopped, heavy and flavorful beer.  A king of IPAs this beer ranks up there with the best.  A very flavorful aroma is followed by the bite of the hops which overpower any of the malts.  Citrus and hops flowers are out in front, but it is easy to taste the alcohol in this one.

On Draft at FFF : Golden Pour, with a thin White Head. Smells of piney hops and mango, with the flavor of piney hops, citrus, peach, grapefruit, mango. Taste is slightly bitter, a light but shocking brew that finishes long and fantastic. This brew makes alpha king redundant, for me.

I am a true beer fan that will not sugarcoat it. This is a good beer. It is very smooth and light. It goes good with or without food. It tastes very similar to Three Floyds Gumball Head. It is pricey. Try it.
This is a rare and crazy good ipa. Huge hop flavor, amazing finish. Omg. Like gubna and hopslam, crazy good. Same caliber.

Pours a golden-yellow color with a short head that gathers around the edges and leaves some lacing. Some chill haze initial becomes crystal clear after it warms. A burst of citrus hops aroma, grapefruit, and fruity esters in the nose. The palate is smooth and creamy, medium-bodied with a lasting finish. Well-balanced between the malt and the hops. A soft, but strong bitterness and a honey-like sweetness. Wonderful flavor! So well balanced, and alcohol well masked. Made me smile.

Served from bottle into a Delirium Tremens snifter.  Pours a clear yellow orange with a three finger slightly off-white head that subsides to one finger very slowly.  Maintains lacing throughout.  The aroma is comprised of tropical fruit, subtle malt, and nice hops.  The flavor is of tropical fruit, malt, and a nice crisp hoppy followthrough with the tropical fruit mixing in with the hop flavor.  It has a medium feel on the palate with medium carbonation.  Overall this is a very interesting IIPA.  All of the characteristics of this one is very nice.  The hoppy followthrough isnt as smooth as usually enjoy but it is still not abrasive on the palate though.  I can see why this brew gets such awesome reviews...

Finally rating this after 3 or 4 full bottles and another 3 or 4 tastes.  Thanks to everyone who supplied this great brew.  Pours a clear golden/amber with a nice 1 to 2 finger white head.  Aroma bursting of piney and citrus fruit hop.  Taste is great.  9.5% is well hidden behind the rich fruit hop bitterness, orange peel, and sweet caramel.  Just an overall good-for-any occasion beer.

650 ML bottle to snifter. Pour is a hazy orange with a nice tight soapy head that lingers to film on top and leaves a decent lacing. Aroma sweet citrus and pungent florals and grapefruit. Taste is big grapefruit hops and flowers which leave you with a full creamy malty mouthfeel. Palate again full and creamy with a gritty chaulky dry finish. An amazing beer check it out, really enjoyable!
Poured from bomber, wow, the aroma jumps out at you, amazing bittering hops, citrus and grapefruit nose, one the better Imperial IPAs Ive had in a while, highly recommend!
Serious hop nose.  Golden with a nice head formation.  Strong amber ale-like body, then kicked in the face with hops.  Excellent.

22 oz bomber from Chicones.  Bright orange pour with about a finger of white head.  Citrus hop smell dominates the aroma with the malt making its presence known as well.  Medium body, not nearly the smack in the face that I expected.  Very well balanced, the hops come through nicely in the flavor but not overpowering thanks to the malt.  The finish is where you really notice a sharp hoppy bite.  As the bitterness fades, youre left with a nice orange note on your tongue.  Damn good beer.

Bottle reviewed from notes.  Ill rate the fresher bottle I had of this because it was a more accurate example of what the brewer intended here.  Pours a clear amber with a big head.  Pine trees and forest in the aroma, awesome use of hops.  Intense bitter and sweet flavors, really citrus like in the mouth.  Nice balance with the malt and hops.  Drank fresh this is one of the best IPAs Ive had.  Just an explosion of hops, tropical fruits, and strikes an awesome balance.

pours orange-amber with a thin white head and no lacing.  Aroma is pine, citrus and some floral sweetness.  Taste is incredibly rich.  hops against caramel arrive first followed by grapefruit.  The finish is long, sticky and bitter.  sweetness lingers. Such lovely warming sensations all the way down.  This beer makes you say "woah"

On tap at the brewpub.  Poured a clear golden yellow hay color with a white head.  Nose was full of citrus hops, some peach, slight pine, light grassy malt.  Smooth, big grassy malts, even more citrusy hops, slight sweetness, medium bitterness.  Finishes long, bitter, more of a citrus punch.  Overall just a great double IPA, the highlight of the trip to the brewery.  Wish it was more widely available.

Amber in color with white head that dissipates fairly quickly. Grapefruit, pineapple and some pine in the nose. A moderate and fairly overt alcohol burn in the mid and finish taste. The citrus in the nose does not translate well to the mouth. Overall, good flavor, but as a personal preference I would prefer a more subtle alcohol presence and more citrus in the mouth. Less balanced to me than Pliny or Yulesmith which I thought were excellent. I lean toward the West coast style IPA flavor profile.

Golden colour and clear. Has a white head, moderate duration. Aroma is heavy hoppy, citrus notes, rubber notes. Flavor is harsh bitter, nice! Has a good malty background too. Texture is dry and syrupy.

22oz pours hazy amber golden with light head. High aroma of mango and citrus not much else. Taste is of citrus slight pine and hops. I feel like this bottle isnt as fresh as it could be and the flavors have faded, disappointed. Will have to re-rate once I can get a fresh bottle.
Sweet malt and hop aroma. Bitter citrus flavor with a malty undertone. Very hoppy...best served not ice-cold.

Pours a hazy orange with a fair white head.  Nose is lots of pine and just a bit of cat piss and lemon.    Flavor is also quite a bit of pine and some grass.  Theres clearly a bit of malt in here, but it does a good job of staying in the background; the sweetness is quite subtle and not overwhelming.  Not particularly syrupy for a beer with so many hops in it, which I appreciate.  Dry finish, but not overkill.  Probably the best IIPA Ive had from a brewery east of the Mississippi, but I still prefer some of the West Coast IIPAs (Pliney and the Green Flash IIPA, in particular).

A damn fine beer, I would drink it until my liver gave way. Nothing offensive at all, just beer bliss. Would get again fo sho. Wasnt sure what to expect, it lacked some hop freshness, so i cant knock it too hard. think i was sent a slightly older bottle.

UPDATED: MAR 1, 2013 A: Dark orangey-amber like body. Thick and hazy.. Huge offwhite head. Great retention. Lovely lacing.

S: Citrus and piney hops are up front with a thick creamy caramel malt backbone that really shines through.

T: The caramel malt flavors are ever-present. This a very nicely done malty dIPA. The citrus and piney hop notes are not overpowered, but do take a slightly diminished role. Delicious.

M: Medium-heavy body. Nice bitter finish. Semi-dry and crisp.

O: For how much malt is in the flavor profile, this is an immensely drinkable dIPA.

Served in a half pint at FFF brewpub. Presented as a medium orange with a thin head of larger bubbles. Aroma is very hoppy. Flavor is smooth, with a quite bitter and citrus aftertaste. There is like an entire grapefruit in this. This is like gumballheads older and dirtier brother. I like it, but I think the style is not quite my style. Good beer though.

Bottle and tap - Ive had both. Probably my favorite Imperial IPA. Super big Hop flavors with citrus and fruit hit you square in the head. But, its smooth. You taste the high alcohol percent but - whatever magic they do at Three Floyds - its smooth and SUPER drinkable! Highly recommended!

Golden pour.  Pretty clear with a small white head that provided gentle lacing.  Aroma is slightly fruity (mango, citrus, peach?) with some piney and grassy hops.  Flavor matches the aroma, with a nice sweet caramel malt balance.  99 IBU, so pretty bitter, but very smooth.  Exceptional.  Alpha King is my favorite, but my first taste of this rates it right up there as well...
Bottle thanks to Matt! Pours clear amber with white head. Nose and taste of extreme citrus, with light pine, dry hops and coriander spices on a strong caramel malt foundation.
Im a stout guy, but love this beer.  It has hints of citrus in it which helps creates a well balanced Imperial IPA.
Strong initial flavor and very smooth aftertaste.  Definitely one of the best IPAs Ive had.  No let down with this breweries great reputation.

650 mL bottle from the brewery, served in an English pint glass. Pours a clear straw colour with a dense, white head. Head has good retention and leaves amazing lace. Aroma is primarily big American hops--pine and grapefruit--with light roasted malts, peach and a touch of tropical fruit. The flavour begins medium bitter with a slight caramel sweetness. It becomes increasingly bitter towards the finish, which is lingering malt. On the palate, light-medium in body with a smooth, slightly astringent, texture. Overall, an excellent IIPA. Its 9.5% ABV is very well concealed. Generously hopped and intensely bitter, but without being overwhelming. No sledgehammer-over-the-head bitter here. Another excellent brew from Three Floyds. 2010-06-18

Bomber from Overml1. Cheers dude!Pours a crystal clear gold. Moderate head doesnt lose much foam and lingers for a while.  Aroma is sweet, citrus, grapefruit, and peach are definitely perceptible.  Hints of the caramel notes are present as well.  Incredibly smooth, thinner mouthfeel, carbonation on the low side, nice and sweet up front.  The bitter takes a while to hit you and really creeps up on you after youve swallowed, and it lingers for a while.  Good amount of malt to stand up to the hops, but while the malt quantity seems fairly sufficient, its not very complex.  A good IIPA but there are many more that I think are a cut above.

On tap at Mikkeller bar. 
Pours golden with a white head.
Fruity and hoppy aroma on a solid base of caramel with notes of grass and elder flower. 
Flavour is hops, caramel, grape, hay and grass leaving a bitter after taste which isnt as bitter as expected.

gold with a slight red tint, very similar to blackheart, but with stronger hop.  It has a sweet and strong hop and citrus mix.  I drank these right after each other and was getting blitzed, so maybe they are more different than I thought.  Either way, great stuff.
Had this one @ CBF 2010. Orange colored brew. Flowery hops in the aroma. Flavor has citric hops, very soft and smooth. Nice.

UPDATED: MAY 16, 2011 Sasquatch just booked his flight to Munster Indiana.  Hes heard the rumors of amber colored brew with an amazing balance of piney hops and malt.  Three Floyds came thorough for our Northwest brethren with this Imperial IPA masterpiece.  The nose is duped by the overwhelming aroma of hops.  The palate also never identifies the high alcohol content of this bad boy.  This is due to the fact that the initial blast of pine, citrus, and hops is quickly counteracted by a rush of malt.  A perfectly balanced Imperial IPA, Deadnaught just up the ante for the rest of the field.....

Bottle courtesy StFun.  Oh yeah.  Glad I tracked this one down.  Absolutely ripped hops upon hops.  Citrus, pine in spades.  Even some high and tight dry hops buried artfully in the middle of it all.  Strong malt presence but it supports and does not blunt the hops.  Really one of the hands down best IIPAs Ive had - extraordinary.

UPDATED: JUL 4, 2011 Draft. Pours golden with a white head. Big pine/citrus taste, this pour is super dank. Nice balance between the hops and the caramel malt, definitely a fantastic DIPA.

Rerate: Draft at brewery. Just like biting into a fresh pineapple. Amazing.

Tap at Birrerria Paradiso in Georgetown.  Paired with beet salad with Old Chatham ewes blue cheese.  Hazy golden color, white edge head, massive lacing.  Aroma is subtle pine and citrus.  Taste has wheat and citrus.  Average.
What an ipa should be. Bitter and citrusy. Pours golden with medium white head. Very good aromas, and bit of kick in the finish.

On tap @ Mikkeller bar. The aroma has grass, strawberries, grapefruits and some pine. Bit hazy, orange coloured beer with a thin, off-white head. The taste is bitter, has some malts, grapefruits. Relative smooth, slightly sticky. Nice beer.

Bottle shared at a recent BA/RB tasting...  Poured hazy orange with a smallish head.  Hoppy, earthy, caramel, berry-fruitiness, with a decent malt balanced.  Very drinkable at its strength.  Twigs, woodsy-like earthiness.

Wonderful drink. My favorite IIPA out there. I love the citrus hop character that is perfectly balanced by the somewhat light malt backbone. Super easy to drink, making it quite dangerous. Highly recommended...

Tap @ Copenhagen 2010. Very hoppy aroma. Big bitter taste. Piney, strawberry. Decent DIPA, but I cant really seem to understand why these three floyds are so outstanding. Huge and big harsh american stuff. Wheres the balance and smoothness?

22oz bomber received as an extra from a generous trader. Thanks for the opportunity!

Appearance: Beautiful hazy tangerine iced tea with honey corners. A billowy 3 finger foam head that is rocky, retains well, and leaves SNOWFLAKE type lacing all around the glass! Absolutely beautiful Imperial IPA.

Smell: Piney Resinous Bitter Hops coupled with a dominating light and sweet caramel malt.

Taste: Exactly like the nose.

Mouthfeel: fairly chewy with moderate carbonation. Medium to medium thick.

Drinkability: its a touch heavy so not the most drinkable. But still delicious enough to entice me to have more than 1.

I love FFFs

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 02-10-2009
Excellent brew.  Lots of fruit going on in here.  The head was a little thin, but left a good bit of lacing.  I typically like my beers pretty dry, but the sweetness in this one works well.

Draught at Mikkeller Bar.

Lots of hops of course. 
Complex and interesting aroma but a simpler taste.

humle,citron,grape, Ud gylden klar, Skum: Luftigt ,Korthold, Rolig E.smag: sød morerat, Bitter;meget, Slut E.smag Bitter meget Krop: medium For; cremet Brus:blød 
(40 cl fad)[Mikkeller ]7/5-10
22oz bomber.   Shared with friends at a party.   A huge resiny, floral, citrus hop bomb.   A little more of a malt backbone than one gets from the West Coast hop bombs but equally delicious.

Pours a hazy orange with a thin white head.  Amazing aroma of peach and pine.  Flavor is mango, passionfruit, pine and just a hint of caramel malt.  Does not suffer from the cloying caramel sweetness of many DIPAs.  Outstanding beer.
Pours a nice goulden hazy brown flavor with a slightly creamy head. It has a nice strong hop taste. A slight caramel peach mango aftertaste.
great beer!  nice copper colored pour, light head.  touch of citrus and tropical fruit.  great hoppy finish.  time to trade for some more!

Cant say much else outside of whats already been said.   A dangerous beer.......cant taste the alcohol at all.  Served from a bomber into an imperial pint glass.........the aroma exploded of mango.     Hops faint at first, then settle in after that and linger forever.   Great aftertaste and a very smooth drinking brew.   Oustanding.  I prefer the Alpha King and Gumbalhead, but this beer is  a must have for the hophead.

bottle from Motortoddhead. A great pour. just beatiful color orange golden hue. A nice white head, amazing aromas of grapefuit,peach and mango. the taste was citrusy up front, sweet in the middle and finished with the hops. great balance of flavors. really great beer. wish I had more.
Tap. Medium head with medium duration. Color is golden. Aroma and taste are rich hops, caramel, elderflower and malt. Absolutely wonderful aroma.

On tap.

Pale amber color with a nice white head.

The aroma packed with fresh hops - grapefruits, grass, pine-needles and hop resins. Caramel malts back it up. Very inviting and aromatic. 

The flavor has some caramel malty sweetness to it and minimal hints of vanilla fudge. But the star of the show is definitely the fresh hop aromas of grapefruits, mango, grass, pine-needles and resins. Ends really bitter with a strong piny character.

Full body, crisp and semi-sticky texture. 

Good stuff. Dangerously easy to drink.

Tab @ Mikkeller Bar. Amber/yellow pour with minimal white head and some lacing. Very light colored for an IIPA. Aroma is indeed hoppy - a lot of lemon, lime peaches and a solid malt sweetness and caramel foundation. Really great smelling. Taste is very fruity, lemon, lime, peaches, mango, orange and some piney notes. Very awesome. Malty sweetness to back it up. Awesom taste, very hoppy and fruity. Soft, medium carbonation, big body, long duration. The IIPA Ive ever had, just magnificent!
Draught @ Mikkeller Bar. Pours hazy golden. Aroma is sweet aswell as bitter. Lots of tropical fruits. Bitter grapefruit dominates the beer. Malts are there for the balance.

Draught at Mikkeller bar. Fantastic beer. Creamy white good mostly lasting head. Dark yellow colour. Moderate malty and totally great hoppy aroma. Grass and citrus very present in perfect balance with malt. Heavy bitter complex flavor. Long fantastic finish. Wonderfull creamy palate.

Mikkeller bar.
Tap. Clear golden colour with okay head, Nice hoppy aroma. Flavour is bitter hops and sweet licorice.

Why has it taken me so long to taste the sweet sweet nectar of this fantastic beer?? Pours an illuminescent orange with a fluffy froth head. Immediate hops and grass on the nose. Pretty dank, underneath all that herbaceous aroma is some sweet fruity notes. Taste is pretty hopped up as you would expect from this beer. No laughing matter. Chewy and fresh. Awesome beer!

22 oz bottle (thanks to a trade) into a Duvel tulip.
Poured a cloudy orange with a one-finger head.  Lacing was thinner but hung around throughout.  Good carbonation was evident.  Taste was a nice progression, with a hop hit, orange, mango and licorice up front and a peppery, spicey finish with dry bitterness (not unpleasant).  Mouthfeel was creamy, oily and medium or even thinner.  The 9.5% isnt obvious in any aspect.  This IS an interesting beer and tasty for sure.  Not my favorite DIPA but a really good one for sure.

Bottle, From Crown Liquors. This stuff was FRESH (had over a month ago). Beautiful tan/amber body with a nice tight head with a beautifu. Bold hop bitterness and grapefruit notes. Overall very solid. Huge difference from the almost year-old bottle I had in January

Poured with a nice foamy frothy off white to cream colored head and some lace. Head lasts for a while. Aroma is mainly citrus hoppy along with some yeast and malt. Flavor is like aroma but yeast comes out more. Full mouth feel and good carbonation. A little bittersweetness at the end along with some alcohol. For some reason this beer doesnt quite ring my bell although I generally really like the Floyds beer.

Pours a light, shimmering golden with dustings of black sediment and topped with a resilient white head from the 22oz. bottle into a glass tumbler: Its like an army of hops holding live grenades and kamikazing straight for the tongue. Flavors of simcoe, mango meat, pine, vanilla biscuit, and citrus, mostly orange and grapefruit, against a solid caramel undertone. Piney, resinous, alcoholic finish. Sweet sweet sweeeeet. Fine, prickly carbonation, oily/dry body. Drinkability: Sugary tropical fruit bitter caramel thick pudding. Too much of a good thing is Wonderful. Everything is to the highest degree, but nothing is overly done. Very dangerously drinkable. Pairing: 4x4 In-N-Out burger, animal style. Rebuy: Fo sho. #431 on 26042010, DG.

Ive have the pleasure of drinking this twice thanks to intrepid travelers bringing this one back my way. From 22 oz bottle. This is a fantastic beer. Aroma is a light fruit, heavy hop one, full citrus body. The palate has a nice hop oil taste, but it does not overpower. Very complex. Alcohol is so well masked I had no idea it was this strong until after investigating further and discovering its 9+ ABV.

A- An aggressive pour only produced a 1 finger creamy white head on this one. The body is a beautiful translucent rusty amber color that is full and vibrant. Head fades rather quickly to a nice collar and some lacing is left behind in the glass.

S- Smell is a big and balanced combination of piny and citrus hops. The piny hops dominate the nose at the end.

T- Upfront is lots of citrus hops and a good dose of piny hops. A whole lot of hop flavor upfront. The finish is a smack in the face of refreshing piny hops with hints of fruity citrus subtly making a presence in the background. What lingers is a big piny hop flavor. The bitterness is definitely present but not strong until a second or third swallow is made after a gulp of this brew. The hop flavor is definitely the main character here.

P- Medium carbonation and big thick oily mouthfeel. Smooth and creamy.

O- This is a pretty darn good DIPA. One that is hard to find and it was definitely a treat for me. The 9.5% ABV is well hidden but takes its effect pretty fast. One I will revisit when I see it again (not available around here-and soon not available in OH either.) My first brew from FFF . I have Rabid Rabbit that I am looking forward to also-but I would like to try others from FFF.

Serving type: bottle

lucent copper, dense creamy white head, fine low co2, oily smooth very full body.

aroma: very fruity sweet citrusy hops (some mango/peach).

taste:
T1= lots of piney citrus hops.
T2= smooth, oily, fruity hops (mango/peach).
T3= palate-numbing hop oil, peach schnapps.

initial impression is of a DIPA with a peach schnapps bomb.  not a session beer, its just too heavy and oily for that.  nicely balanced as i drink it, but leaves a lot of oily hop resins behind.

UPDATED: MAY 19, 2010 This is a solid beer, nothing wrong with it. ti has a nice citrusy aroma, the body is solid orange with hops on the nose, goes down smooth and is very solid in every aspect, including the complex mixture of several hops. Its perfect beer.
From bottle. Doesnt get much better than this. Complex, with many fruits on the nose and on the  palate, very balanced without one hop variety overwhelming. Goes down with ease, awesome beer.

UPDATED: JAN 4, 2014 On tap @ Sugar Maple!  Nice orange color.  Aroma is sticky, stanky hops - love it!  Bitterness is much of the same, nice caramel malt background.  A bit of a sour, citrus finish.  This one walks the walk and talks the talk.  An incredible Imperial with a capital I.  SO glad I got to try this on tap!  Re-rate: bottle and tap.  Much better on tap.  Bottle okay when fresh.  Pretty bland malt backbone.  Can be very one-dimensional.  Reality rate -0.4

Golden pour. Slight head. Aromatic smells of hops, flowers and slightly sweet of peach. Predominantly bitter hops, subtle peach and citrus flavor (more peach than citrus). Wonderful beer. Demonically good.

Hands down my favorite beer.  Very complex flavors with citrus, woodsy piney notes.  A fantastic malty mouth feel.  Hardly any alcohol in the finish, but maybe thats because im so used to it.  Took me maybe two pints to get used to the IBUs, but this is the beer that made me a hop head.  Big time cheers!
This is about as good as beer gets. Extraordinarily complex nose, beautiful citrus and pine, incredible hop bitterness with a robust malty finish. My favorite beer to date. Cheers.

Surprised Ive never rated this one.  Ive had it numerous times.  Pours clear golden orange with mostly diminishing head, excellent lacing. The aroma is hoppy, citrus and a little resin. The taste is hops and bitter, creamy almost a sweetness there too.  One of my favorites.
The sweet citrus hop aroma is awesome. The hazy orange color has a small decent head to complement the color. The flavor of sweet, citrus hops is nice and refreshing on the palate.

Wow a standout beer, even for Three Floyds.  A lot going on in the nose,  my buddy even picked up some coriander and the mango was very noticable. I picked up some trademark grapefruit from the hops. Taste and palate offered so much. One of those great dbl IPAs that walks the delicate line of maintaining the crisp hoppy bitterness without being excessive and then still offereing some malty sweetness from the residual sugars, Nice work. Definitely will buy more.

UPDATED: APR 6, 2010 Bomber from Archer Liquors, consumed with much anticipation last weekend.  FOUND my tasting notes!

Pours hazy light orange with a bubbly white head that leaves good lacing.  Aroma is caramel layered with sweet fruit (pineapple?) and raw sugar.  Flavor is a spectrum of hoppiness, ranging from pine to oily resin to a slight citrus finish.  Mouthfeel jumps around as well, from slightly oily to dry to a creamy finish.

Quite good, but not a match for the great Pliny!
Smells of hay grass hops and slight citrus tastes of hops hay and a bit of fruittyness not muchalcohol kick very good beer

This brew pours clear golden yellow with a thin white head, very close knit carbonation bubbles and little to no lacing. The aroma is of pure hops - flowers, citrus, peaches, pine tree. Very sweet and bitter front. The taste is not much different from the aroma and starts off with a nice bitterness that quickly fades into an orange citrus and floral finish.
A great imperial IPA. Syrupy body. Aroma of citrus and peach with a malty yet fruity flavor. Citrus and orange from the hops dominate both the aroma and flavor. Very drinkable.

22oz bomber into a goblet. Deep amber color, hazy, thin off-white head. Smells very piny and citrusy. Malty, grapefruit taste. Bitter, but not overly so. Thick mouth feel, a bit on the viscous side. Decent IPA from the midwest.
Resiny hop aromas, hints of grapefruits with tropical fruit notes.  Pours a pale golden color.  Bitter hops upfront, earthy bitterness with traces of pine, caramel malts.  Pretty good.

Pours a cloudy light orange.  Ginger, candy, and citrus on a very hoppy nose.  Very bitter but well balanced with a hint of sweetness to it.  I think I pick up some caramel or something.  Sure, I like it.

Poured a golden amber with a big chunky head. The smell was the best part, big sweet citrusy hops dominated, and kept you going back for more. Taste was also big and hoppy, but seriously, with all the hype, I felt it kind of finished on a thud. Dont get me wrong, this was an "A" beer, but I was expecting something more. Mouthfeel was a little light, but overall very drinkable, ill have another.
22 ounce bottle. orangeish pour a fruit mango citrus aroma taste o fcitrus, floral, caramel, A nice real super qaulity ipa.
22 oz bottle, grapefruit, roasty,citrus, average carbonation, sticky, full body, bitter, hazy, golden,
From a 22 oz bottle. Grapefruit is a strong flavor that comes to mind.hazy, golden, minimal head, medium bitterness, fizzy, sticky,

Bomber bonused via trade with phaleslu, thanks again Peter!!!! Pours a moderately hazy coppery amber with a 1 finger creamy off white head that has great retention and leaves respectable sheets of lacing. Aroms is full of citrus, pineapple, mango, a hint of peach, plenty of creamy caramel, a little biscuit, straw, a little grass and a vanilla like sweetness. Fantastic aroma. Flavor is sweet, creamy caramel, toasted grain, biscuit, sweet malt, grass, sweet citrus, red grapefruit, blood orange, vanilla pudding and light mineral notes. Finish is somewhat bitter citrus, caramel, vanilla, burnt sugar and a lingering mineral and sweet tropical fruit fade. Palate is medium bodied with a creamy entry moderate slightly prickly carbonation and slightly creamy, mostly dry finish. Just a fantastic beer, another great brew from Three Floyds.

Thanks to Exiled for sharing this bottle with me. This was beer No. 1200 for me.

Pours a slightly murky golden color with a white head. The aroma is lot of hop flavor: mango, citrus and orange.  The flavor is orange and other citrus with medium bitterness. Medium-thick mouthfeel with medium carbonation. Definitely lives up to the hype.

At woodshop 5.0.

Appearance: Pours a cloudy bright yellow with a big soap sudsy head.

Aroma: Big citrus and a little catty.

Taste: Spicy malt, citrus and a bit of pine.

Mouthfeel: Full bodied moderately carbonated.

Overall: Really good, but could have been fresher.

A: Deep amber color, hazy, thin off-white head.

S: Tons of citrus, mostly orange. Nice piney, resinous finish. Its got my mouth watering already.

T: A burst of grapefruit and orange initially, followed by a caramel sweetness and a bit of alcohol on the finish. Bitter, but not overly so.

M: Very smooth, great body, and perfect level of carbonation.

D: Despite the high ABV and the slight alcohol bite, this one has such great flavors that you could drink it all day.

This beer poured a nice dark ale-like color and had a great hopped up nose.  However, here is where I disagree with the majority of raters - Im not quite sure what all the hype on this beer is - sure, its a nice beer but it is not really that great.  Certainly I finished the bottle and will finish what I purchased, but this is just a normal, run of the mill, DIPA.  Not over the top or great, not bad.  Well, made, pours nice, smells nice, tastes nice.  This is not, however, a "Pliny the Elder," "Alesmith IPA," "Alpine Nelson" or any other of the top rated beers.  Perhaps I got a bad bottle?  Certainly I will try it again and change my rankings if so, but right now, this one isnt even in my top 50...

A hazy orange color beer with a small head. The aroma sure did not smell like the #2 DIPA in the world with a lot of caramel sweetness & if I really try I may have smelled some hops. Obviously this is not a fresh bottle-Damn. The taste was sweet with a dash of hops but they have faded by now, shitfuck this is a travesty. I sure do hope I can try a fresh one.

22 oz bottle thanks to Nflmvp. I shared this with a good friend and poured into two pint glasses. The color was a bright orange and hazy. The head was white and fluffy. The smell was faint but my sense of smell sucks most days. The taste was pretty damn awesome. I definitely tasted the simcoes in there. Pine and citrus are of course present. This was a really awesome brew but certainly not worth $10. They need to drop that down to around 6~7..

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 03-02-2007 19:14:51

Bottle shared with Gloulou and bro.
Aroma : Big hops, passion fruits and mango. Resinous hops

Taste : Mango and passion fruits, resinous hops.

Finish : Very bitter and very resinous.

Overall : Awesome brew. Very fruity. Thanks so much Dany !!!

Copper blonde topped by a white veil, quickly disappearing. Piney, citrussy. lovely hoppy nose. Almost full body, all hops on the attack, low carbonation, bitter but not astringent, very chewy, again with resinous and citric hops. Loads of flavors in this 2IPA. Long and tasty bitter finish. Lived up to the hype.

Bottle. Dark golden with a stable head. The hop blast was instantaneous once the crown was removed from the bottle. Theres no shadow of doubt this is the hoppiest beer Ive ever had. The nose is superb. Its in your face, brash and makes no excuses for it. Massive tropical fruit basket of goodness. Grapefruit, citrus, mango, pineapple and even slightly herbal (minty) as well. Tastes great - plenty of caramel malt to support the hop bomb. The flavour is very toffeeish when it all comes together. As expected the mouthfeel is sticky but no sign of the abv. Huge bitterness right through to the finish. As I mentioned this is one hoppy mofo with palate destroying bitterness. Awesome stuff! A good bottle to share - too much and youd suffer palate fatigue early on - this one reaches the threshold! Massive props to Jase (volcanicbeat) for sharing!

Wow. Nose is HUGE. Citrus, mango,pineapple and some pine just blow you away. In the mouth it is full bodied - caramel and citrus coat the tongue and the resinous bitterness sits on the back of the tongue for a LONG time. The only bad thing i can say is that in the mouth it doesnt quite have the complexity of the nose, but is still a wonderful treat. Reminded me of Hop Stoopid. Really lucky to try this - thanks so much volcanicbeat!

Bottle at home.  Pours a hazy deep orange with a very thin head that disappears quickly.  Smells strongly of orange, lemon zest and ripe grain.  Crisp with a ringing hoppiness.  Nice and bitter with a little sweetness.  Clearly a great IPA. love it
Pours amber with a thin white head.  Aroma is very citrusy.  Tastes very hoppy.  Sweet upfront with a nice bitter finish.  Another winner from 3 Floyds.
AHHH GOD Ive been attacked and it is GOOD!  Please pour more of this all over my face while I drink it from the largest glass ever!  When will FFF make it to Washington already?!
one of the best beers ive had. a perfectly balanced imperial. absolutely delicious!

Pours amber with a white head. Aroma is malty caramel, hoppy, pine, citrus, grapefruit and light phenolic. Flavour is caramel, light alcohol, hoppy, citrus and grapefruit, light nut. This is completely wellbalanced.

Bottle: Pours pumpkin in colour, big off-white head. Heavy lemon and orange aroma, lots of floral hops. No question this is a big daddy IPA. Then, the unexpected in the flavour. Toffee and bread, pepper and grapefruit, and some massive citrusy hopping. Extremely oily mouthfeel it just coats the tongue. Share it with friends, the first few sips were incredible but this one can wear you down if you hold on too long. Great stuff.

Pours clear orange with a thick white head. Aroma of sweet grapefruit, zesty lemon, pine, sweet hops. Taste is perfectly balanced between bitter resinous hops and lighter citrus flavor. Dry short finish. Nothing harsh but incredibly hoppy.

22oz bomber.  Not much of a hiss when cracking it open but  wow.  I had this one when they used to distribute to Maryland in the early 2000s and wasnt that blown away with it.  Just had it again in 2010 and Im blown away.  Hazy, glowing amber-orange color, with a patchy, soapy head.  The aroma really does capture those exotic fruit scents.  There is certainly some citrus in the flavor as well.  The palate of this beer is what sets it apart...so clean and drinkable.  Somehow mellow and full and complex at the same time.  Wow, one of the best IIPAs out there..for real.  Big ups, you overpriced bandits!

Pours a nice orange-tinged golden color with a full, soapy head in a large mug.  Very fruity aromatic, almost peach like, to the smell. Hops aroma is nicely tucked in.  Taste is sharply bitter citrus well blended with a nice malty backbone.  Alcohol is unnoticeable in the taste.  There is a nice kick up front followed by a long duration on the tongue of hops, citrus, and malt blend.

I bought this for comparison with Dogfish Head 120 IPA and 90 IPA.  While I like them better than this I have to say that the Dreadnaught has a nice subtlety to it.

This is a great beer.  I love IPAs, though, so I might be somewhat biased towards them.  Hops is where its at.

reddish orange with large white head.  moderate carbonation for style and somewhat thick mouthfeel.  nose of citrus and herbal hops.  moderately bitter for the style, with much greater hop flavor and aroma than bitterness.  hop flavor is of citrus, herbal hops that immediately mesh with alcoholic warmth and rather high residual sweetness.  tremendous depth, absolutely remarkable, a flawlesss brew that is the paradigm of the style, not revolutionary, but the archetype

Pours a murky dark orange with very little lacing. The aroma is very sweet, with notes of pine, caramel and grapefruit along with grass and resin. The flavor is somewhat sweet with what seems to be a moderate bitterness even though it is stated to be 100 IBUs. I think fresh this would be a different experience

Beer poured a beautiful orange with a very thin white head. The aromas are dominated by fruit, specifically lemon, orange, grapefruit, and a small amount of pine. The taste is again of grapefruit and lemon, but also mixed in are bits of pine, caramel, and malt. You get a big kick of alcohol from this one. This is the best Imperial IPA I have had so far. Awesome beer.

20th October 2008. Hazy orange beer. Super smooth silky IPA. Almost creamy palate. Bags of hop flavour but not really that bitter. Juicy grapefruit, orange and peach with a just a hint of tea. The finish is very slightly bitter and a little bit spicy - just enough to make you crave the next fruity mouthfull. Highly superior IPA.

Bottle and on draught at 3 floyds, Pours a hazy amber with thick soft white yellow head that disipates quickly. Aroma is HUGE floral hop, spice and sweet malt. Taste is through the roof big floral spicy and malty backbone. wow a fantastic beer.

22 oz bottle from a store in terre haute. light amber color, thin white head. huge grapefruit, citrusy aroma. huge, complex hop flavor, mostly citrus with some pine. 100 ibus but somehow not overly bitter. mindblowingly great beer. one of the best double ipas ive had.

Rating is from a draft pour.  Pours a slightly hazy orange amber color with a larger off white head.  The aroma is a wonderful blend of caramel malt, citrus, peach, grapefruit, and a small hint of pine.  The flavor is a perfect blend of the caramel malt with the citrus, and pine hops.  Other fruity flavors such as peach and mango are present.  The beer is med/full bodied and is a pleasure to drink.  The alcohol remains well hidden throughout.  If this is fresh, it is as good as any DIPA Ive had.

On tap at the Three Floyds on 7/21/09.  Pours clear light orange/dark gold.  Eggshell head.  Aroma of pine, lemon and grapefruit.  Touch of vanilla on the tongue, then a long bitter finish.  Fantastic imperial and the only knock against it is that the alcohol is a bit too heavy and present.

Pours a slightly hazy with amber yellow with a light yet thin white head. Aroma is a mix of orange/lemon citrus with sprucie and some cheesey fatty undertones. Flavor is very earthy and thick with some banana undertones covered with banana notes  and raisin.

I just found a bottle of Dreadnaught in my beer cellar and think it overstayed its welcome by a year or two.  Thats right kids, you shouldnt cellar Imperial IPAs or they end up tasting like barleywines.  This one actually hasnt turned yet.  Lots of caramel and cotton candy sugar up front.  Grapefruit and toasted malt lingers.  A little oxidation but too be expected for sitting a while.

On draft @ Sergios World Beers. Tons of grapefruit dominate the aroma. Pours with a tall, lingering white head that laces on the glass as you drink it. malt sweetness comes through the hop bitterness and both last into a long finish. Great beer.

Draft @ pub. Straight from the source. Wow! Been a long, loong time since Ive had a bottle of Dread. Mostly the price. And my broke ass. 

[A] Sugary grapefruit. Peaches. Definitely a nice fruit variety here. Bunker said he could smell it across the table. Solid caramel malt sweetness. 

[A] Amber. White head. $5/8oz. Pretty comparable to bomber price. Nice lacing.

[F] Taste is obviously very citrus. Bitter hop. Fruity. Sugary sweet. 

[P] Profile is very sugary sweet. I no longer have a feel for 100 IBUs. Came off quite bitter, but not the pine like slap in the tongue I enjoy. Drinkable, and greatly @ 10%. Without the heat.

[O] Not sure what to say about this. Okay. Well. Its NOT ALL THAT. Ive had better. But it is pretty damn nice. Good depth. Sweetness is a good thing. Maybe I just hate this for being so damn great. Or maybe my palate was crushed after Grober, BA Klaus, and Ham On. Doubt it. Someone else suggested it was a little off, too. Id still give it another shot. And I cant quite say Ive had anything exactly like it.

Aroma of grapefruit, tart apple and spiced grape. Appearance is gold and transparent with plenty of carbonation; creamy head. Flavor matches the nose perfectly, with more of an emphasis on the grapefruit. Palate was lively. Pretty good.

22oz. into tulip.  Cloudy, medium orange/gold with moderate beige head.  Head diminishes to thin with yeast circles.  Aroma of citrus and pine - orange.tangerine, grapefruit.  Good lacing lingering.  Well-balanced brew with nice dry, bitter finish but not overwhelming.  Alcohol is completely hidden in my oipnion.  Very, very nice offering.  A kick-butt Imperial IPA!
Tap at FFF. Orange gold, semi-hazy pour. Bright citrus hop nose, creamy mouthfeel. Complex palate of citrus flavors with hoppiness that is borderline too much for me. Great stuff.

Rating #900. Bottle from a trade with StFun. Pours orangish color with off white head. Strong citrus aroma of grapefruit and oranges and some sugary sweetness. Nice amount of hop bitterness without overdoing it. Lots of citrus and some pine balanced with a touch of sweet caramel maltiness, no too sugary or syrupy. Medium body with average carbonation and a resinous mouthfeel. Excellent!

22 oz. bottle from City Wide in South Bend, picked up by shawnm213.  Thanks, Shawn!  Pours cloudy orange amber with an inch thick off-white head that leaves beautiful lacing behind.  Aroma of sweet caramel malts, pine hops, orange citrus, tea, mango, apricot, and yeast.  Flavor of caramel malts, floral hops, orange and grapefruit citrus, mango, peach, apricot, pine, tea, and just a little warming alcohol.  For 9.5%, its well-hidden.  Medium bodied, sticky, complex, and well-balanced.  Feels awesome in the mouth- sweet from the caramel malts and mixed fruits, bitter from the hops, malty, and a bit bready.  Perfect aftertaste of fruit, hops, and malt.  This is fantastic.

pours a bit hazy with a decent 1 finger head on top. aroma is really nice with lots of malt and citrus. taste is nice, however i found vanilla to dominate a bit, but still a nice balance. would like a bit more hoppyness to this one, but hey, i like my IPAs super hoppy...overall a fantastic brew.

Gift from Joe for watching his mutt. Nice hop aroma, notes of caramel. Amber in color nice white lace around glass, lively carbonation. The malt to bitterness ratio is perfect. Light sourness, medium bitterness. Nice medium body with a hop sticky texture. If you love Alpha King you will Love this beer.

This brew is so perfectly balanced that the monster abv% and hop content somehow mesh into a simple, citrusy explosive flavor with minimal indication of those elements that so often overpower IIPAs. This is on the level with Bells, Founders, the best IIPAs around.
