The mouthfeel is perfect - it starts full in body but seems to get lighter as it finds its way towards your gullet. The carbonation level is nice - it adds a subtle sting that complements the big hop flavor nicely, and it makes for a nice creamy texture. Overall, very nice - I really want to try a fresher bottle now to see just how big and bold the hops are.

22 oz bottle from a trade with ughsmash. pours hazy orange with no head and fizzy carbonation. huge citrusy hops aromas. i could smell hops as soon as i opened the bottle and i could smell them across the room from my snifter. flavours are all hops with citris and some pine. very bitter black tea finish. a true IIPA. tasty but suffers from a lack of drinability.

Pours a cloudy light golden color with a medium frothy head and lots of sticky lacing.  Aroma is grassy, orange, pineapple, and peach.  What an interesting taste and mouthfeel.  Is a bit bitter and grassy up front and then finishes off with mango and pineapple.  Would have been perfect if the bitterness was tugged back and the citrus flavors brightened........but then you’d have the Hopslam.

Bottle. [thank you, Yespr]
Pours a great-looking hazy yellow-orange golden. A small creamy film head on top. Aroma is bitter, hoppy and lightly fruity. Super nice mouthfeel. Flavour is complex bitter, lots of oranges, pineapple, grass (is there English hops in this?). Not as bitter as the Green Flash, but a wonderful balance. I slightly prefer the Green Flash, but this is still wonderful.

Pale deep golden. Dry hoppy and fruity soft aroma. Very good soft mouthfeel. The flavour is rather sweet with a good ripe fruitiness, soft bitter hoppiness and citrus. Comfortable smooth Imp. IPA. Thanks a lot for the share of this treat yespr!

75 cL bottle, trade with ygtbsm94. Pours hazy orange with a lacing white head. Pine, dry grapefruit. Flavour is mild caramel malt, very balanced fruity hops flavour. Lovely complex flavour of fruit, soft english hops, mild sweet caramel malt base, nice bitterness and with little raisin sweetness into the far finish. Smooooth and complex, lovely.

UPDATED: MAR 26, 2009 [Courtesy of yespr, session @ yespr] 
Hazy golden with tiny short lasting head. Aroma is sweet and fruity with hoppy notes. Flavor starts hoppy with sweet middle and nice bitter finish. Fruity with raisins, peach and grapefruit. Nice
UPDATED: DEC 22, 2008 Delicious! Smooth and creamy yet bitter and metallic. Pours a deep dark orange, armoa is all citrus and metal. Flavor packs a wallop. Hits hard, but never overpowering.

UPDATED: AUG 24, 2011 Pours an orange-brown; deliciously fruity aroma.  Peach, mango, pineapple.  Spicy, tropical fruits, bitter hops.  Alcohol burn at the end.  Its so good I hate myself.  Different and awesome.
very strong burst of flavor. Plenty of hops and fruits. one of my first craft brews. three floyds never dissipoint
Pours hazy amber brown.  Smells like rotting fruit, malt syrup, floral hops.  Flavor is citrus and floral with a little kick of spice,  Smooth.

Bomber shared with dpjuart, Nate, and foureyedgeek.  Pours a hazy orange with a very small off-white head.  Really fruity floral hop nose with a hint of rich, sweet caramel.  The hop flavor is a lot more floral than citrus, but has a little bit of earthy undertone.  The finish tastes like a sweet tea.  If I had to find on thing against it, there was a huge contrast of sweet and bitter, but nothing in between.  This caused a kind of weird sensation with the tongue where the front and back are going crazy and the middle feels left out of the party.  Had a pretty milky body with an insane amount of taste layers.

22 oz. bottle via trade with Ty.  Shared with Naka, Nate and foureyedgeek.  Pours Orange w/ amber hues.  Hazy with a small, off-white, foamy head which dissipates to a thin ring.  Nose is big and caramely w/ a faint resiny citrus aroma lurking around.  Sweet caramel background with viscous, resiny and sticky floral and citrus hops.  Almost tea-esque.  I didnt expect this to be as sweet as it is, almost too much malt. Complexity was there.  Great beer overall, just not quite what I expected.

From bomber, courtesy of dpjuart. Caramel and mild toffee, biscuity sweet. Underlying hop aroma that feels as though theres a beast underneath calm waters. Brown sugar, pine resin, grapefruit rind, and musty funk. Lustrous amber-orange hazy with thin off-white thin lacing head. Heavy watery body with mild-medium carbonation. A bit warming. Starts sweet with caramel and biscuit, brown sugar, and huge malt character. A bit too syrupy sweet. Hops come in hard with apricot, grapefruit, and pine resin. Sweet sticky finish with medium bitter. Sweet after. A bit overpowering. After is bitter on tongue.

The beer poured a thick head with medium sized bubbles which immediately began to dissipate.  This was a very clear copper in color and the nose was filled with scents of grapefruit, piney hops, caramel and spice.  In the mouth the midpalate was rich and mouth-coating with solid weight.  While there were tons of hops, they were well-balanced with some sweet malt.  Again, with tons of hops, the finish had the bitterness one would expect but it was well balanced with malt that it did not come off as overtly bitter and dry.  This is an extremely balanced with that has lots of everything.  Yum!

One word comes to mind...JUICY!!!  Once the bottle opens, the aroma pours out and the salivating begins.  Thick pillowy head and burnt orange liquid fill the glass.  The brew starts sweet, but the hops kick in quickly...amazing balance.  Undoubtedly, the best Double IPA Ive ever had!!!

I love this beer. I live in soCal, so its nowhere to be found. Fruity, hearty and wonderful. Maybe a bit too sweet, but its a very, very minor complaint. Found it while with my girlfriend outside her folks place near Chicago. I had it  to celebrate the Patriots going 16-0, and it did NOT disappoint. I have one more bomber left, and will drink it when the Pats (hopefully) go 19-0. Cheers! And someone tell these guys to broaden their distribution. All of their stuff is dynamite.

Wow. Pours a thick orange color with a medium sized bubbly head. Nose is marijuana. seriously. intense hop oil aroma. Notes of pine and some grapefruit. Mouthfeel is fantastic and feels thick on the tongue. Warming finish. Tastes like a christmas tree and a bag of pot. I dont know how else to describe it. Great beer but a bit overwhelming.

Bottle, 22oz. (RBNAG 07) Pours an orange-golden, almost clear pour with an off-white to beige head. It sure has a hop-dominated aroma, fruity, tropical fruits and citrus, pine and resin, with a heavy maltyness in the supporting role. Nice flavor too, fruity, piney, malty, quite sweet and sure bitter. Fruity, piney, bitter finish as well. Full body. Loved this IIPA, beautiful mix of hops and malt. (071103)

Bomber from Crown #15, in Fishers, IN. Pours a pretty, cloudy, deep orange with a bit of sediment and a creamy beige head that laces nicely. The nose is a hop-lovers dream: big sweet malty caramel front with huge, fruity, citrus hops. Very nice. Medium to full-bodied and slick with a big bitter, yet balanced, finish. The flavor is just a touch below the nose, but is exactly what I like in an IIPA: a big, sweet caramel malt front with equally huge citric and piny hops. This is a very good beer, and once again I am thoroughly impressed with a 3F offering. Its not hard to see why this is rated so highly.

Pour is a deep copper with a small white head.  Aroma of citrus, with grapefruit dominating.  Lemon (?) is present as well.  Flavor is also heavy with citrus, with grapefruit being the main player.  Finish is very heavy with hops.  Finish coats your mouth with heavy bittering hops.  Carbonation is pretty heavy as well.  Excellent IIPA with great bittering.

I like this beer but I was expecting more from a name like Dreadnaught. Not bad at all but just a little too sweet. Pours a cloudy honey color with a thin head that is white and dense. Not a huge nose on this brew, slightly citrusy with a little bit of a grassy, hoppy smell. Tastes very sweet up front with a good amount of bitterness on the back of the throat and tongue. Some citrus in there maybe a bit of grapefruit and some caramel sweetness. Pretty thick with decent carbonation. Not a bad big IPA.

In the world of Imperial IPAs, theres simply nothing better.  This is one amazing beer as is every Three Floyds that Ive had the opportunity to try.  

Pours incredibly hazy orange, not much in the way of a head but no matter....

Good grief, I smelt this thing 3 seconds after cracking open the top.  Super, super citrusy hop aromas with a huge pineapple or peach influence.  Man, this is right up this hop lovers alley.  

Mmmmm....  Everything I hoped it would be.  This is just over the top hoppiness all the way here.  100 % juicy citrus hops here and I love it.  You know what youre getting when you crack this open and it certainly doesnt disappoint.  

All other IIPAs bow to this one as king.  Unfortunately, I have to drive 4 hours to get my hands on this.  I have 5 bombers of this left and wish now that I had gone ahead and bought a case.  

God, these guys know how to make beer.  Theyre over the top, in your face brews and thats just the way we like it.

I was shocked to realize that I have never had this, couldnt pass it up.  Not overated at all, an incredible DIPA.  Despite the IBUs, not one flavor dominates with the citrusy and sweet backing.  Thick with almost no foam, it goes down real smooth, but take it slow.  Will definetly grab more the next time I see it.

UPDATED: FEB 18, 2008 Pours a murky orange with the slightest bit of head.  Grapefruit and malty aroma.  Tastes similar with a bit of hops and other citrus fruits like lemons and orange.    Syrupy with little to no carbonation,  no sign of the higher ABV.  Slightly bitter but the malts balance that out.  A decent IIPA.alright,  after 3 or 4 more bottles I finally got one with a good hop character.  It still isnt quite as hoppy as most people say,  but it sure bumps it up.  Original score was a 3.2

UPDATED: DEC 19, 2016 11/24/2013: its been 6 years (and many beers) since I last tried this and its still great - but my perspective is likely different: bomber from Andersons in Sylvania.  Aroma is earthy, grass, and citrus.  Tastes are citrus rind, grapefruit, pine with just the right amount of malt sweetness.  Texture is creamy medium with a spike of carbonation.  8.6
12/25/2007: bomber from marinos in toledo.  Id had this at the 3floyds brewery but hadnt done a proper rating.  hazy orange pour with medium to large fluffy head.  grapefruit and hop aroma.  hoppy and citrus flavor up front then lots of malt to balance.  long crisp finish.  one of the best beers Ive ever tried. 10,5,8,5,15: 9.4

Pours a hazy amber orange with small head but great lacing. Smells of huge hops, piney, grassy and citrus rind along with grapefruit. Taste is a wallop to the buds and I love it. Delicious, power packed hops but as soon as you want to pucker a nice balance of fruit and malt make this an incredible balanced DIPA. Alcohol is not present other than a little warming. Carbonation is perfect as is the medium mouthfeel and crazy drinkability. Finishes a little dry and bitter from the hops but does not sting or linger. If I had access to this I would have it batting cleanup. A must try for any true BA.

Ruby color with a rich, creamy, white head that slowly dissipates. Tiny bubbles shoot up the glass to the little island of head in the middle, leaves a nice lacing. Lemon, citrus, a lot of grapefruit aroma, actually smells thick with grapefruit. Taste is loads up with the lemon and citrus, but the grapefruit is most definately dominant, almost like a concentrated grapefruit juice. Be prepared, full of juicy hops. Thick, sticky on the tongue, full bodied and high carbonation explode flavors onto your tongue. This is great on occasion, but would probably wear out your palate if had too often. Get some if you can.

Hazy orange pour with a lasting creamy beige head atop.  Smell is nice and aromatic with big fruity, citrusy hops in the nose.  Taste was hopped but not nearly as much as expected and had strong notes of orange, peachiness to it.  Candied bitter orange peel flavor to it.  Much more balanced than expected.  Decent body and a bitter orange finish.  Mild alcohol presence but a very nicely drinkable IIPA.  My rating will probably go up drinking this in more than a sample glass size at a time and looking forward to trying it again.

The best IPAs Ive ever had.  The nose  is amazing and so smooth.  I will add to this later and give a better review when I go bac to Piccolos for more.  Right now I want to drink this beer and watch a hockey game.
had a hard time getting this one...then luckly came into a case.  Very nice pour great smell.  Left a sweet taste in my mouth, craving more.

very excited to try my first 3 floyds beer at the SE winter yeha.  actually 6 floyds!  so that would make it 18 floyds??  anyway.......
2003 - cloudy orange, almost milky looking.  hops and bready malt aroma.  flavor is hops and butterscotch.  extremely smooth and full bodied, milk-like palate. 8/5/9/5/17.  2004 - cloudy orange with a small head.  smooth palate.  sweet caramel flavor with some burnt toffee and butter.  slightly less "milky" than the 03. 8/5/9/5/18.  2005 - cloudy orange.  not as smooth as 04 but still great. 8/4/8/4/17.  2006 - hazy orange with a small head.  apricot, caramel, hint of alcohol.  hoppier and more bitter than the previous years. 8/4/8/4/16.  2007 - hazy orange with a small head.  even less smooth and more bitter than previously.  7/4/8/4/16.

Bomber courtesy of alexanderj, shared with kleyland before the Liverpool v. Manchester United match.  Pours a hazy orange color with a good amount of floaties.  Medium sized off white head.  Very sweet grapefruit aroma.  Body is nice and thick.  The flavor is a really nice balance of sweet malts and the citrus hops.  I would have prefered a bit more hops near the backend, but maybe my palate wasnt ready to work at 7:00 a.m.

Bottle, many thanks to bu11zeye for this one. Pours a clear orange amber color with a small off-white head. Malty and very hoppy grapefruit aroma. Sweet malty very bitter and slightly harsh flavor with lots of citrus hints. Long hoppy grapefruit finish going over to a long bitter aftertaste. Very good!
Bottle at RBNAG 07. Golden / orange colour with an off- white head. Aroma is hop , citrus. Flavour is sweet, hop, citrus, malt, flower. Nice beer.

Had this numerous times. Pours a very pale orange. Not so much head but the aromas take over all my senses. The apricot and grapefruit rise up from my tulip. The flavor was great and is one of the best IIPA I have ever had.

22oz. Growler. Pours slightly cloudy pale orange, like an IPA should. Thin head, which is surprising since they add yeast to prime. The nose is a knockout...it smells like a harvest ale, with strong grapefruit. First few pulls are so bitter your palate has to adjust. Cascade & Chinook hops outdo all flavors with the grapefruit, though you can taste the sweet malty backbone. Finishes with a cloyingly sweet tang, which fades into a buttery ester that isnt all that unwelcome in this style.

i took a special trip to indiana just to have this beer. i had been reading about it for quite a while and just felt like i needed to have it in my life. this is a PERFECT beer. i was told by my traveling partners that i even had a whole new look of joy on my face when i tried it. a case of 12 bombers set me back 100 bucks even but it is worth every cent.

UPDATED: JUL 15, 2008 In the movie Beerfest, theres this scene where they are first trying Germanys greatest beer. This must have been that beer, except it isnt from Germany - its from Indiana. It poured like liquid honey into my half-yard. Immediately I could smell the mangoes...the grassy earthy hops that you could smell if you were around the bottle. The first taste - and its sweet. Not the brutal dominatrices out here on the West Coast, but a sultry soft Midwestern girl.  It peels back into a welcoming bitter, that lets you know its an IPA. But at no time does it feel like a IIPA - but it is. Oh brother, it is. ON SECOND ANALYSIS: This is an even better IIPA fresh. You really get the spicy, dank hop notes that make a truly perfect IIPA.
A fantastic smelling beer.  A dark brown with a little bit of a ruby color.  Thin head.  Well balanced, one of my favorite IPAs.  Lots of hops...well done!

UPDATED: MAY 9, 2008 Clear orange-golden body. Low head. Delicious and strong fruity hop nose. Full malty taste with a perfectly balanced hopbitterness. Oily mouthfeel. Full body. Awesome! (Bottle @ RBNAG07)

Dreadnaught pours an amber color with a slightly off white head. It has a sweet aroma that isnt as full as hops as I would have assumed. There are some hop aromas, but it is mostly malty sweet aromas. The taste is similar to the aroma. There is no blast of hops that I would expect from a double IPA. There is a very strong sweet malty taste and enough hops to balance and stand out, but again, they dont dominate the flavor. I think that Im getting more accustomed to hoppier beers, so it might be a bit before I can get a stable base to review from. That being said, it is still a good beer. It tastes fairly full bodied for a lighter beer, and is pretty good to drink. I would definitely drink it again.

Edit: On the second half of the bottle as it warmed up, it got hoppier and got better.

22 oz bomber courtesy of Ughsmash, thanks Jason! Drank at 55.4 degrees (courtesy of my little temp laser) Poured into a tulip glass with an hazy amber colour and a medium creamy off white head. Carbonation bubbles suck to the sides of the glass. Nose of grapefruit hops, dark fruits,sweet malts, and a touch of alcohol. Initial taste of light tingly bubbles over the tounge touched with a velvetly sweet malts covering the mouth. Oily and slight chewy. Caramel malts begin to surface. Finising bitter hops and sweet malts on the palate. The balance of hops is good and doesnt outweigh the begining malts. Palate duration is warming and good. Some head retention and nice thick sheets of lacing. Medium body. Chalky finish. Very drinkable.

Second time Ive had this, first at the Chris_O bash, then just this evening.   Lovely IIPA.  Malt and hop balance in the extreeeeeme.  Yeah there are the heavy citrus/Pine and zesty notes - but they are together as one, rather than leaping like misguided springs.    I love the oilyness - more a note that Id expect from a RIS, weird, but in a good way.

Yeasty cashew and walnut aroma. Hazy copper color, floating sediments, and no head. There is a strong bitter flavor of orange, pine, and yeast. Pine needle finish. Full bodied, more than strong enough, decent balance, but not great tasting.
[ Thanks to fonefan ] Amber of color with a beige head. An aroma of pines, frash fruits, hops and notes of malt. A flavor of malt, hops and pines.
Probably one of the better IPAs out there.  Nice bright orange, little head.  Very nice floral smell, fruity.  Good hoppy aftertaste.  Left flavor on the tongue minutes after drinking.
bottle. it has a slightly murky golden color with a large head. the aroma is nice and spicy. great bitter taste of hops. there is some sweetness present as well.
Draft from Three Floyds Brewpub.  Wonderful citrusy aroma, hop flavor and bitterness.  Definitely going to drink when ever I can get it.

UPDATED: MAY 7, 2010 Bottle (MT) at ØLklubben (2006 edition). Clear golden - white head. High hoppy, peach, pepper, caramel, nice light sweetness, light soapy, light toasted. Fantastic........Re-Rate: Draught at MikkellerBAR.
Clear amber - white head. Grassy, piney, Nice hoppy, sweetness, caramel, cactus, light bitterness, lovely fresh.

Medium offwhite head. Orange body. Citric straw and malt aroma with caramel notes. Dry medicinal straw taste with sweetish honey and resin notes. Fantastic richness in the taste. Excellent! (0.66l bottle at RBNAG07. Quite late, so want to rerate this.)

Bottle. [ Courtesy of drewbeerme ] Unclear medium orange color with a average, frothy / creamy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate to heavy hoppy, grapefruit, citrus, mango, peach, moderate malty, caramel. Flavor is moderate sweet and moderate to heavy bitter with a long to average duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. (271007)
Bottle, not very fresh from what I can tell. Citrusy hop aroma. Definitely get some mango. Not much of a head. Seemingly harsh flavor with little hop character. Wish I could get a fresh brew.
Sampled bottle, RBNAG 2007 in Grimstad. Orange colour. Intensely hoppy aroma and flavour. Another example of overkill.
Cloudy orange. sweet with floral aromas.  sweet hop flavor with some malt.  top IPA

Aroma of sweet pineapple, malt, light cheese.  Amber orange color with off white head.  Very well balanced initial flavors.  Hoppy bitterness is evened out with a honey sweetness. Light saltiness.  Alcohol in not present at all.  Very creamy palate.  Nice balance.  Very good overall.

My third bottle of Dreadnaught, but the first with reliable provenance regarding freshness.  Pours a nice clear copper-orange color wtih a sparse thin white head.  The aroma was heavy, resinous, spicy, fruity, rich, and lightly alcoholic.  Very piney.  While the aroma was piney, the taste was more grapefruity and much hoppier than the aroma indicated.  The jarring hop blast occurs throughout the bottle, not just on the initial taste.  The finish lingers and tingles on the palate for a while.  The thick syrupy palate and low carbonation allow for proper chewing of this trademark brew.

Tak til Heidi og Kenneth som købte den med hjem til os. Drak den til ølklubbens smagning.
Ravfarvet og uklar, skummet forsvinder lynhurtigt. let støvet i duft og smag, græsset med noget peber og sæbe. Slet ikke den bitre humlebombe jeg havde forventet. Nærmest lidt for sødlig men "det amerikanske" er der stadig.
jeg er ikke tilfrds. Lidt flad.
66 cl bottle. Amber color, medium off-white head. Very hoppy, fruity and sweet. Balanced beer that I liked a lot. (RBNAG07 in Grimstad Nov. 3th.)
An Excellent IPA. Many flavors on the nose and palate, easy going down, accompanied with a nice grit. Powerful, but not obvious, left without any disappointments.
Fruit salad aroma.  Peaches, grapefruit, and watermelon.  Crispy hop bite with a lingering resiny finish.
Yum.  This is one very well made IPA, awesome all around, from nose to finish.  I wish they were still sending this to my area.

bomber thanks to Joe at the liquorette. what else can be said for this beer besides its awesome. this beer is ultra balanced and extremely tasty with a satisfying full bodied hop taste. high ABV completely masked by many drinkable qualities. kinda pricey since im in L.A. but a nice treat.

22oz bottle shared with IPA-loving friend. My foray into craft IPAs began with Dogfish 60 and 90, which remain two of my faves. This is just a special beer. Pours big, nice body, nice nose. Citrus, mangos, pine aromas. Deliciously hoppy with a clean finish.

Tasted 9/30/07.  22oz bomber.  Tasted this after the Boulevard Double wide IPA.  So much of this is a comparison.  Slightly darker hue than the previous.  Less initial head.  Smoother aromas.  Milder nose.  Full bodied with higher gravity.  More rounded, smoother and bigger.  Better melding and more of a hop profile.  Hugely bigger alcohol burn.  Less dry, but so much bigger.  Citrus piney perfumy peppery long trail of hop flavors.  More so tart.  Hits the sides of the tongue and moves south.  More of a candy sweetness.  Im so glad I didnt share this!  This is such a huge beer!  Super big comparitively, but this in itself has few rivals!

okay so i only had a few ounces and i was slightly toasted but this was one that i wanted to taste, for shizzel dizzel.  amber with a haze orangy look.  nose of citusy hops and sifted flour.  flavors of beautiful apricot palate with a grassy crunch that was quite delightlful. cant wait to try it sober.

UPDATED: FEB 7, 2008 Yummy! This beer like all Three floyds is tasty. Mango, Oranges, peaches, hops and malt very noticeable. Alcohol hidden. not much head. I just had the alpha Kong so this beer seems weaker in many aspects. Still one of the best beers I have had.

All I can say is WOW. Ive been waiting to try this beer for a long time now. Finally it is a few inches from my lips. Immediately a huge bold citrusy and fruity smell hits my nose. This beers aroma is HUGE! Flavor follows the aroma perfectly big and citrusy, very bitter but a very SMOOTH bitterness that lingers on and on. Alcohol is completely hidden. Ive only rated a few other beers as perfect 5s, after tasting this beer Im going to have to go back and reduce all those other ratings. This puts all other beers to shame. Best beer ever.

From bomber courtesy jcr, thanks John! : Pours a hazy orange-apricot looking color with not much head.  Very aromatic, with hops and mango.  Medium body smooth in the mouth and bitter on the end.  Alcohol is pretty well hidden.  Hop flavor with fruity citrus notes toward the end.
Finally got my hands on a bottle. Well worth the wait and hunt. Very aromatic and wonderful. Nice hoppy flavor through out, as well as some fruit notes towards the end. Very Very good. A+++
I love this beer.  Great aroma and color.  The nicely hopped and the right amount of bitterness.

UPDATED: OCT 30, 2007 Tremendously aromatic, lots of peach; brown-apricot color; wow, the hype is for real: alcohol is well hidden under a really flavorful hop sting; not at all sticky but leaves a great aftertaste and sting with you; pretty awesome.
[tasted next to a Pizza Port Hop 15]
(not suprisingly) the Dreadnaughts peachy, the Hop-15 is piney, and both are superb.
[tasted next to a Green Flash Imperial IPA]
The Dreadnaught is peachy in the nose; the Green Flash is ganja and grass. Not suprisingly, the taste matches. Besides that, the Green Flash has more hop sting aftertaste; the Dreadnaught has more of a warm syrupy aftertaste. Both impeccable. I personally prefer the Green Flash.
[tasted next to a Moylans Moylander Double IPA]
Both very fragrant, but the Dreadnaught is a lot of peach compared to the malt-pineapple Moylander aroma. The taste matches their aroma. The Dreadnaught is also very rich on the palate by comparison.

22oz bottle.  Pours a crystal clear deep amber color, foam is surprisingly short lived and leaves almost no lacing.  Aroma is lots of citric and piney hops rolled in crystal malt and then marinaded in ethanol.  Flavor hits you at first with a smack of alcohol, then kicks you with boot covered in "C" hops and covers you in a thick malty blanket.  I never got over the alcohol, just way too much for me.  Also, despite the claim of bottle conditioning, it was crystal clear the entire way down and had no sediment.  Bastards.

Everything it claims to be and more. Hits you hard with the scent of forest floor, grass, grapefruit, a bit o honey. Balances very juicy hops with a strikingly bitter and long finish with thick, toffee-malt sweetness. Has it all, does it very cleanly and its still got plenty of balls. This is what beer is supposed to be, people.
UPDATED: JAN 7, 2008 By memory- orange color, almost overly hoppy, flowery sweet start, dryer finish. Fruit/hop/pine tast, intense hop expericance.
From the hype that surrounded this beer I was not overly impressed.  Not enough malt to give it a smooth finish. Great hop filled aroma.
Wonderful.  Cloudy amber pour with a small white head.  Aroma of piney hops and some citrus.  Complex mouthfeel with bitter finish that keeps on giving.  A Hop lovers dream.
Amber color with a nice that disappears quickyl.  Extremley hoppy beer in aroma and in taste but does not over power the drinker.  Good repersentation of style, extreme but nice.

I was invited to the NBH for a home brewing display.  The owner shared a glass of this with me.  It stands there beside the Maharaja shoulder to shoulder.  A smotth, balanced hop cocktail.  If only I could get this in Minnesota.
my favorite regular offering from my favorite brewery, topped only by their anniversary ale and of course, dark lord.
Pricey, but excellent.  It did not have one characteristic that was overly dominating making it a maze of flavors.  The bitterness was there, but quickly turned into citrus flavors.  Very impressed.
The best Double IPA I have had to date.  Perfecto!  I have had this beer on numerous occasions and its wonderful hop flavor and controlled bitterness has never let me down.

UPDATED: JAN 31, 2008 One 22 got me drunk. It seemed to go from unbalanced, sweet, vodka then perfect. I need to try it again and give a better review. The memory of it draws me to want to drink more. rating going up.

When you were young you were harsh brash... kinda a real asshole. I mean I got it... All up in my face bitter dareisay, immature.                                                                          You needed some time to grow up, six months did the trick. With the dignity of a a barely wine you matured. Got a little sweeter, less aggressive. You mellowed as you got sugar sweet became caramel.. . melting in my mouth.

UPDATED: DEC 1, 2007 I might have had my expectations to high, but it was a tremendously enjoyable brew. Very fruity. Quite refreshing actually. It wasnt the blow out that I expected.
--After thinking about this one for awhile it occured to me how superior this really is. My other favorite selections just didnt stack up to this briallant gem.

650 ml bottle from archer liquors.  Hazy orange brown with a fizzy white head.  Sweet fruity aroma.  Sweet caramel and citrus taste with a lingering bitterness and crisp finish with a distinct orange flavor.

UPDATED: SEP 5, 2009 From a bomber, (thanks Matt! mreusch) pours amber with no head, nose of floral and piney hops. This is an outstanding brew. Flavor is a little pineapple, citrus and fruity hops, caramel, with a viscous mouthfeel that makes this such a smooth beer! This is my first 3Floyds, and I am longing for more. Great beer that lives up to the hype.

UPDATED: APR 27, 2009 
Name: Dreadnaught
Date: November 28, 2003
Mode: Bottle Conditioned
Source: Whole Foods Market, DC
Appearance: clear dark amber, fine thin head
Aroma: sweet grapefruit aroma like sugar sprinkled on a slice of morning grapefruit
Body: excellent body
Flavor: aroma slowly fades into a light barleywine aroma that is matched by the flavor, wonderful interplay between the carmel sweetness and well tempered hops, a lighter more drinkable barleywine
Overall: no wonder its $90/case

Name: Dreadnaught
Date: April 29, 2006
Mode: cask
Source: brewpub
Score: ii+
Appearance: yellow, frothy white head
Aroma: light hop aroma
Flavor: sweet hop flavor, long bitter finish

Name: Dreadnaught
Date: April 29, 2006
Mode: draft
Source: brewpub
follows the bottle fairly well, 

Name: Dreadnaught
Date: May 03, 2006
Mode: fresh bottle
such wonderful sweet grapefruit aroma and flavor, still stands out amung the plethera of grapefruit juice double IPAs, easily roused fine beige head, bits of drippy lace, 

Name: Dreadnaught
Date: December 15, 2007
Mode: bottle
Source: vertical tasting 2003-2007
2003 still has the hops in the aroma but the flavor is all sweet crystal malt with only a hint of the hops, 
2004 is still mostly sweet crystal malt with a bit more of the hops coming in the flavor but still light on the bitterness, 
2005 aroma is same oxidized malt but the flavor is picking up even more citrus hops and a long bitter finish kicks in
2006 still has the oxidized aroma with just a touch more hops, flavor is well balanced between the hops and sweet crystal malt, 
2007 aroma is spot on with fresh hops to balance the crystal malt, flavor is well balanced between the big hops and sweet crystal malt, lasting bitter finish carries the hop and malt flavor, 

Name: Dreadnaught
Date: April 24, 2009
Mode: draft
Source: brewpub
grapefruit is down and bitterness is up, sweet pine making an appearance, 

Aroma: 8/10; Appearance: 8/10; Flavor: 8/10; Palate: 7/10; Overall: 16/20
Rating: 4/5.0Drinkability: 8/10
Score: ***4

RIP Michael Jackson, I drink this in your honor. Im a huge fan of double IPAs and this one has such a malty biscuit-juice like backbone, I was pleased how that layer counterbalances the bitter pine cone grapefruit-esque hops which stand out in the finish. Balance is not an operative word here with the intensity of flavors all around. A bit too much on the tea side with that bittersweet honey biscuit flavor but all around an enjoyable beer. Vanilla seems too accentuated. Its also a bit astringent with the overload of hops. Thank you NEPA case split club for this bottle.

UPDATED: SEP 14, 2014 Bottle from Capones gift from Stegosaurus, sampled with Dennis Bell.

I will keep this short. Absolutely the best IPA I have ever had. Looks great tastes great is great. WELL BALANCED ! The cerimonial humping of the bottle was done.

Re-reated in 2014, not as good as I thought when my palette was younger.
Smoother than most IPA.  Citrus nose, taste of apricots, nice smooth finish.  very drinkable.
user_location: Middle of no where, Ohio, USA

text: As Ive mentioned in other reviews, I am not a hop-head.  A double/Imperial IPA can not be just a hop bomb that is unbalanced and just hoppy for the sake of being really hoppy.  But this gem of an double/imperial IPA is a true gem.  Just a fabulous beer overall, as it has the strong citrus aromas of the hops, but is balanced with a delicious sweetness in the malt.  Beautiful copper color on pour.  I would go out of my way to get this beer, as its not available in my area.  Loved it.  The guys at Three Floyds are awesome.
Thanks Ramenen. Bottle: Excellent balance, alcohol, hops, herbal, bitterness, colour and aroma; its all there. Just great.

UPDATED: AUG 24, 2007 I will admit right now, double IPAS are not my favorite style.  I love my IBUs in a IR stout, but when the beer is straight-up hops slapping me in the face, Im not so much a fan.  This is undoubtedly a hell of a brew.  It pours a viscous copper, and sits in the glass with the color and luster of gem-grade amber.  A tiny off-white head forms slowly and laces like crazy.  the scent is delightful, syrup-thick with grapefruit, tangerine, apricot, all other manner of tangy fruti, and mountains of bitter floral hops.  The smallest sip coats the mouth completely, assaulting the palate with hops.  Grapefruit dominates, with hints of other fruits and a touch of resinous pine on the finish.  This brew is  full of molasseses sweetness, too. That would actually be my main complaint; the sweetness can realy become cloying by the end of the glass. The finish is long, with bruising hop bitterness overpowering the sweetness of the lingering body.  Overall: wow, the flavor is INTENSE.  I had to have a sip of water after each sip of beer to keep my thirst under control and clean my palate.  I can certainly appreciate this beer, but Its not my bag.
22oz Bottle Pours out a hazy orange/amber topped with a very small white head. Sweet aroma of hops and fruit. Tast is very nice a big mouthfull of sweet hops. Tast is not bitter at all very nice 2IPA

UPDATED: AUG 22, 2007 I wish I could get this on the regular!  Thanks to miketd for the 650 ml bottle!  pours copper with minimal head and lacing.  plenty of  bubbles rising to the filmy surface.  it has a pleasent papaya odor. this very complex and balanced starts of bitter and has a slighty sweet acidic finish that is close to perfect.

Bottle, Chris_o shindig. Copper, smallish white head. A very 3 Floyds aroma: melon, musk, mint, faded orange peal. Full chewy hop flavor. Good, though I think not quite at its best. I bought this bottle many months back, and while its been kept well, this certainly is not a beer to improve with age. Just couldnt justify opening it alone.
Beautiful IIPA, great balance between malt/hops, with great pine and citrus tones.  Sweeeeet.

UPDATED: NOV 5, 2007 Poured a cloudy orange and copper color with a nice creamy off-white head that lingered and offered up good lacing.  The aroma was the expected citrus and pine notes along with some softer fruits (that Ill assume are the mango and peach notes).  The flavor was citrus, malt, pine and butter.  A tad too much butter flavor came through on this one for me.  Not the buttery caramel thats often talked about, more land olakes butter.  Great mouthfeel with barely a hint of alcohol noticed.

Bomber courtesy of my Secret santa (thanks!).  Poured a beautiful orange color with traces of white head.  Beautiful aroma of piney and grapefruity hops.  Even my brother, the non-beer drinker thought it smelled great.  The taste didnt quite echo the hoppiness I was expecting, though it was still pretty good.  Some caramel maltiness up front followed by grapefruity hops in the back. Really tasty.  Finish was bitter and smooth, without much carbonation.  For a beer that was 9.5%, this went down extremely easily for me, which gave it some extra points.  If this bottle wasnt fresh, then I may be in for a real treat should I find a fresh bottle.  Really glad I got to try a very-well regarded beer such as this one, and I wasnt disappointed at all.
UPDATED: DEC 27, 2007 Bottle Chris_o Shindig.  Amber, thin white head.  Great aroma of piney hops.  Some tea flavour in the mouth.  A lot better than I was expecting.

Orange body (call it tangerine), small off-white head, citric hoppy nose with some sweetness. Body is firmly sweet with substantial hop bitterness and grapefruity citric notes. Excellent mouthfeel, balanced, hides the alcohol well.

Bottle-Hazy golden, copper color with a medium fuzzy head.  The drink left copious amounts of lacing.  The aroma had the typical citrusy, hoppy smell. The taste was citrus and hops, the palate had the hoppy, oily feel to it.

1000 miler bottel
This is by far the best IPA on the market.  The hops are balanced perfectly with the malts to create an amazingly smooth finish.  For a beer that pushes 9.5% with 100 IBUs, this is an amazing brew!
Bottle, chris_o shindig. Slightly hazy, yellow. Nose is soapy hops, citrus. Mouth is sweet malt, which lingers to the finish. Too sweet on the palate for my liking.

Cloudy rust orange pour.  Head recedes quickly.  Oak heavy aroma.  Sour mash whiskey, apricots and citrus scented hair spray.  Peaches, honey, and weeds.  Dirty.  Flavors of tobacco, hot grapefruit juice, wet oak chips.  A bold rush of green tea leaves in a firey wave of hops.  And booze.  Similarities to poorly rendered scotch are rampant.  Powerfully earthy and woodsy like soil wet with rainwater.  Hot with cayenne pepper at the finish.  Slick and menacing.  A hint of vegetable frying oil  the kind that coats the floor at your local fast food choice.  Palate is abrasive and belligerent with boozy aggression.  Not that detailed or drinkable.  Mostly hype.  Thanks Brian!

Pretty much a standard Imperial IPA with lots of hops. Still more drinkable the some althoug one glass is enough.

on tap @ FFF. medium copper color with no head on my pour. appears to have very low carbonation. grapefruits, other citrus fruits,  mango and a nice grain smell all pour from the glass profusley. this one is dripping with lush citric hop character and is close to perfect. smooth velvety mouthfeel is extremely well structured never revealing its strength.  lemon drop candy and pine show off big time with glowing results. my one complaint is its too easy to drink!

UPDATED: DEC 29, 2007 [485-20070804] 22oz (c/o HogTownHarry). Sweet fruit aroma with strong citrus hops and some pine resiny notes. Hazy, amber red body with a medium-lasting foamy white head. Great big boozy citrus hops flavour. Full body has noticeable alcohol. Rather impressive, though not yet a favourite. (8/4/7/4/16) 3.9

[754B-20071012] 22floz. Citrus lemon rind hops aroma has some grapefruit. Hazy, dark orange brown body with a medium-lasting creamy light tan head. Bitter grapefruit and navel orange hops in the flavour has a boozy almost sweaty notes. Medium body, very bitter finish. Bitter and hoppy goodness. (8/4/8/4/17) 4.1

22 oz bottle.  Pours golden with a slight off-white head.  Aroma of pine and citrus.  Flavors of sticky hops, it seemed to be all about the hops.  It could have used a little more malt to balance.  Didnt live up to the hype for me.

Bottle thanks to fordest and toncatcher for sharing. I wish this was tasted independently with nothing else. Unfortunately we did a horizontal of some FFF. By the time I got to this one I was fried. I think the hops were a little too much, but I dont usually say that about double ipas unless its Hopsickle. I need to retry this one.
Thanks to Juancho.  The best Imperial IPA I have tasted so far.  Perfectly balanced hops, complex, starts citrus and ginger, finishes with honey notes.
Rich flavor. Deep malts. Nice hops. Sweet too. Another brilliant beer from Three Floyds.

UPDATED: NOV 2, 2007 Bottle from iowaherkeye.  Tasted at http://www.ratebeer.com/events-detail.asp?eventID= with DenverLogan, and Quaff members.  Before tasting, I have a slight negative bias, thinking this beer cant be as good as its rating, but I was wrong, what a wonderful IPA.  1 finger small bubble head that dies quickly.  Orange-yellow color.  Nice hop aroma that demands to be smelled over and over again.  Why is the smell so pleasant, but the bitterness is low in the taste.  Extremely well balanced taste.9,3,10,5,18:4.5
Rerate 10/12/07:  Bottle from Dave at Stone, tasted at Churchills with deftim13, Ivan, and Aaron.  Nice melanoidal malt aroma.  6 months old.  Hops have mellowed, but still great. 9,4,9,4,18:4.4

Bottle courtesty of MrRomero, Nice crisp hop aroma, good malts, citrus. Flavor enters slowly, but lasts for a long time, infact it seems to build upu in your mouth. A touch of citrus sweetness, that slowly becomes more bitter. Very good alcohol is non existant. Very,very nice and great lacing with a nice beige head that dissapates quickly. Delicious.

Tap at The Map Room, Chicago.  I am assuming this is the current vintage, as it was very fresh.  Pour is a clear orange copper color with a quickly fading white head.  Aroma is hops, very bright (head clearing) hops.  Taste shows a lot more maltiness than I was expecting, and of course the hops throughout.  The hops are really diverse, there is citrus (more orange than lemon) floral and sweetness.  The finish is a nice sharp bitter hop affair.  Really nice brew, glad I was able to try it on draft.
2005 Vintage.  Tasted on 06.30.2007:  Yellow hazy color.  DOUBLE IPA!!!  malt flavors.  very hoppy aroma  lots of fruit.  sweet sweet malt.  Heavy malt / citrus, bitterness.  nice balance
Nice strong tasting double IPA with aromatic hop character and aftertaste.  This is a great example of a mid-west D-IPA.
terrific hoppy/floral aroma that made for great anticipation of a taste.  very refreshing taste, strong yet sweet. satisfying to the end.

65 cl bottle, Shelburne (via Munster). Deep amber, strong citrus/alcohol/hop aroma. Long aftertaste, thick in the mouth, almost syrupy, nice bitter finish that sits at the back of your throat for a long time.

UPDATED: JAN 26, 2008 Thanks to BillVanE and dra19.  HOPS!  hops like crazy, but  I could barely guess it was IBU of 100.  goes down smooth as it could, with a taste that just lasts and lasts.  i dont think another beer will taste right after this one.  filling in the mouth, but i split this one with the other 2 guys and now i need more.

I flew to Chicago and drove to Munster, Indiana for this beer. After loading the rent-a-suv, I drove straight home, to Boston with it. 

This I.P.A. Came in a 22oz. Bomber. Once poured (into one of those new engineered Sam Adams glasses) the head is small and disappears quickly. The beer has a fairly floral hop aroma. 

It has a very fruity hop flavor that lingers for a few moments. You will honestly want another gulp and then another glass. It feels a little filling in your mouth with the pops of various fruit and that delicious hops. Once down the hatch you quickly find a beer that isnt as filling as youd assume. 

I find this beer to be an awesome example of what an IPA should be. Hoppy floral aromas with a fruit/hoppy taste and after taste that doesnt overwhelm. This beer aims to please the hop head with making you feel like youre chewing on hops. Over-all an aweseome beer. Heck I flew to Chicago and drove to the brew pub to buy this stuff. Then drove home 18 straight hours for it.

Cloudy orange poor with a thin off-whit head.  Aromas of peaches, cranberries, honey.... very floral and verry hoppy.  Extremely incredible IPA like balance, great bitterness and very creamy mouthfeel.  Very similar to DDCs imperial IPA.  Very nice peppery taste as well... orange zest. GREAT!

WOW! Deep hazy orange, creamy white head. Nose is full of sticky sweet pine, grapefruit, caramel and a hint of apricot. Flavor is an intense hoppy bitterness with a sweet rich malty backbone for balance. WOW! Full bodied, soft carbonation, smooth, bitter-sweet dry finish. Now I know what all the fuss was about.

UPDATED: MAY 30, 2009 Pours a cloudy orange color with small, quickly diminishing white head.  Aroma of floral and piney hops, a brown-sugary malt note, peaches, and other citrus.  Initial taste is a blast of sweet, hoppy goodness.  Smooooooth!!  As it opened up a little more I could pick up on a rock candy quality which still retained that big hop kick.  What I ultimately like about this is the hops dont overpower the other flavors bounding about in it, they do their business, put the money on the table and jet, leaving an indelible mark on my tongue.  This is a very fine IIPA, probably my favorite of the IIPAs.  8, 4, 10, 5, 19.  Draft re-rate:  Dark orange in color with a nice white head.  Nose is big on the grapefruit with some other citrus and a subtle pine note...pure hop juice.  Flavor is so ridiculously good on this...citrus bomb with a lean towards the grapefruit end of the spectrum.  Biting finish of grapefruit and a bit of pine.  Great beer.  Rating reflects re-rate.

UPDATED: OCT 25, 2008 draft at brewpub....aroma: light citrus, grapefruit nose w/ sweet sugary malt that also chimes in and makes its presence....appearance: glassy golden brown topped with a medium ivory head...taste: nice pine essence with additional citrus hops playing a role as well.  taste gives way to the sugary malt and then finishes off with grapefruit......very nice off the tap.
 9/17/08 lot less palatable this time around on tap at the brewpub.  dinish is a little too sweet and bitter which doesn’t make for a good combination.

Pours a deep hazy orange color with almost no head...it even looks thick and viscous.  Pungent sour grapefruit aroma with honey, malts, brown sugar, melon, and a strong piney hoppiness.  Flavors were hugely malty with an equally huge pine/citrus/grapefruit hoppiness.  Hints of caramel, melon, pineapple, mango, and a slight woodiness.  Very soft and syrupy mouthfeel, lightly carbonated.  Some light alcohol warmth, but not at all overpowering.  Really great...crazy stuff... certainly lives up to the hype...

[fresh bottle, courtesy of Darkmagus] Clear copper appearance, with a dense, sugary hop aroma. Skunky. Massive hop flavors up front;  pine tar, grapefruit and citrus rind, combine with a nice malt foundation. Really bitter but fruity finish, indeed, with peach and mango, perhaps some pineappl\e sweetness blending in with the hop syrup. An outstanding beer!

UPDATED: JUL 7, 2007 My 50th beer rating.  Color was a nice cloudy orange, aroma was hoppy citrusy, and slightly sweet.  Unfortunately I tried this beer a little too cold, and at first it didnt seem much like a double ipa to me.  When, cold, the hops dominate, with citrus up front, subsiding to a piney dry aftertaste.  Still, it is remarkably well balanced, and smooth.  Again, it did not seem much like a double ipa, because it was lacking a strong malt sweetness to it.  Then I let it warm up.  This beer probably had the biggest change of any Ive had when it came to temperature.  After it had warmed, the hops seemed to intermingle with a nice warm sweetness from the malts.  It became more balanced.  The flavor became much sweeter and a mango-hop flavor appeared.  Overall: a nicely balanced iipa, with wonderfull complexity that appears as it warms.  I dont if Id pay $12 for it, and travel out of state, but it was certainly one of the most enjoyable beers Ive ever had.

poured into tall tulip.  oh yeah, gooood... fresh clear smooth hoppy aroma, smooth hoppy finish, no overwhelming bitterness on the back, a smooth and creamy palate that "spreads and dissipates" (thanks Julie) across your tongue... great beer, fun, and it is good.

UPDATED: JUL 18, 2007 bottle.  wow a chance to try one of the worlds best.  pours hazy amber with a nice head and little foam that stays on top the way I like it.  Stone ruinition and GDs hercules also has this kind of head.   This one has a delightful lacing on the sides as well.  Nice mouthfeel, nice body.   Extremely well balanced. Yes maybe I smell mango and peach hints. Big hops that rise in the aftertaste then fall off and leave a bitter dry mouth feeling.  This occurs with such speed that it reminds me of the way wasabi grows hotter then fades quickly.  There is also a faint sourdough (yeast) taste that I dont like.  The main beer guru that I visit regularly said this used to be better without that sourdough taste.  As a native of Indiana, I am so proud to have this brewery here in Muenster, IN.  But I have to tell the truth.  This isnt the best, and even if it is the top echelon of Imperial IPAs, it has a lot of fast company. rr.....  although this may not be my favorite right now ... it is one of the most distict IPAs.  If you like this also try Averys the Great Majaera
Aroma is quite strong, hoppy and rich as hell.  Standard IPA appearance, a little darker though.  Flavor is fantastic, well balanced for such a strong IPA.  Great!

I poured this ale into a standard pint glass which produced a almost non-existent head of white foam.  The body of the ale was a cloudy amber, with no particles in the first pour.   Perhaps it was the fact that I chilled the ale first, but I could not discern as dynamic of an aroma as I have experienced from other Floyds products.  Once the aroma started coming in, I was able to scent a bit of floral and hops, with the peach mentioned in the original description. The first sip grabbed me by the lapels (which was a sharp contrast from the light aroma.  Sharp bitterness ran down the center of my tongue as a bit of sweetness crept into the side.  I found this contrast to be a little jarring to the overall experience.   The bitterness of this ale was almost overpowering and lasted for quite a while, perhaps to cover the back notes of alcohol.  Overall, I was greatly put off by the bitterness, my taste  buds were blind-sided by this this brew, but I will forgive Three Floyds since this does provide a good quick buzz.  Not a chuggin beer!  (Take Two): Second pour, since this was from a 22 oz bottle, produced the following:  Head was better and lasted longer, rocky and settling into little islands of foam.  Aroma was stronger with the aforementioned hoppiness and peach.  Flavor was more balanced on the second go as well, with the sweetness becoming more prevalent as the brew warms up.  The pine flavor and bitterness is still there, though not as strong as before.  Id be lying though if I said that you cant tell theres alcohol.  The 9.5% sneaks up on you and its not wholly unpleasant.  This ale has taught me an important lesson in serving temperatures: Not all beer should be served ice-cold.

A dark maze color with thin cream-colored head.  Aroma was heavy with hops.  Flavor was powerful and bitter but tamed just a bit by a malty something that thinned the taste out and did not leave the finish as dry as I had expected.

22 oz bottle purchased at From the Vine. Golden amber in color. Nice off whie head. The aroma was intense. Hops, citrus, floral. The taste was just as intense. Hops, citrus, some carmel. Lingering bitterness. If there is a better IPA out there I would love to get my hands on it. This was everything it was cracked up to be.

Poured amber with a white bubbly head that lasted awhile. The aroma was very complex with mostly hops followed by citrus, pine, and fruit. Taste was sort of disappointing. Mostly sweet malt and citrus with hints of hops. The hops deminished big time. I would love to try a fresh bottle, has very good potential.

650 ml bottle poured in a tulip.  This highly anticipated beer finally came my way thanks to a trade with mdm46410.  It smells like citrus hops and hay.  It pours a cloudy tangerine color with a gravely head.  It has an initial hot pepper and vegetation resin flavor followed quickly by hops, mild lemon and the essence of pure bitter.  The last drop of the swallow leaves your sour-buds quivering and your saliva glads in an frenzy of juice pumping.  This beer is not for the faint-of-heart.  Its a beer for those who value taste, flavor and boldness.  Of over a 1000 beers tasted so far this is in the top 5 easily, possibly in the top 3.
hops pretty much sums it up.  great citrus, floral aroma. Great hoppy flavor.  there is some malt flavor in there but dominated by hops. great beer

Courtesy moejuck.  Pours a glowing orange red with a thin, white bubbly head.  Just a huge floral citrus hops aroma, a little grapefruit in there too.  Pretty well balanced for such a big beer although the alcohol was quite noticeable.  Monster hoppy taste with a touch of some cinnamon, especially in the finish and the aftertaste.  Really limited bitterness for so much hops, which really made the beer for me.  Just ful flavored to every extent.  Kick ass brew.

Golden orange body with nice white head.  Fantastic tropical fruity aromas and flavors... grapefruit, pineapple, mango, orange.  Citrus flavor is complemented by a sweet caramel maltiness.  My favorite IIPA so far.

Bottle. Pours copper infused amber with mahogany highlights. Pretty nose: nectarine, sweet/stale musky wood, bananas sweet hops. Viscous and creamy on the palate. Intense hoppiness  fading into nice notes of eucalyptus and some sweet malt. This is a very unique IIPA. I love the different aromas and flavors. Wish we could get it in MN.

Bottle. Pours a slightly hazy copper with a small short lived white head that leaves minimal lacing. Aroma is loaded with citrus hops( I think Amarillo, Centennial, and Cascade), and sweet malt. Taste is the same as aroma with a nice malty sweetness. Medium full mouthfeel with a wonderfull well balanced hop bitterness and well hidden alcohol. One of the best Imperial IPAs ever.

22 oz. bottle. Trade with Ohiodad thanks Scott. Amber with small off white head. Delicious grapefruit aroma. But the palate was a little viscous and the tastes somewhat muddied. Not bad. Wouldnt turn it down but Hop 15 is much better.
Absolutely brilliant.  What a wonderful IIPA.  A hint of sweetness and a whopping load of hops.  Full of booze and wonderfulness.

Bomber as pictured.  Hands down the best IPA that Ive had to date.  Amber gold with tan cream head. Hoppy citrus aroma.  For me, what set this IPA apart from others was that rather than just tasting of sharp biting grapefruit citrus, it had a mellow sweet glow.  It has to be the addition of the peaches and mango to the intense hops.  Finish is fresh, crisp and takes a long time to fade bitter.  I really liked this IPA and will drink it again.

UPDATED: JAN 18, 2008 Wow, nice beer here.  I am not a huge hophead, but this was great.  Poured a dark orange color, real thick with a small white head.  Smelled of orange juice, pine.  Taste was much the same, some tropical notes, even mango as the label would suggest.  Quite a bit of malt and sweetness as well.  Good stuff.

re-rate:  have had this quite a few times now, on tap at the brewery and elsewhere.  This stuff is part beer and part magic.  Really unbelievable.

Cloudy amber pour with a smallish off-white quick diminishing head.  Huge malt backbone on the nose, small amount of piney hops underneath, a little bit of pepper, not near enough hops on the nose.  Palate is a bit sticky, lightly carbonated.  Flavor is a bit too sweet overall, some floral/piney hops, but not enough, great hop bitterness in the finish.  After all the hype, this beer was a bit disappointing, but maybe it wasnt the freshest sample.

Its a good Double IPA no doubt however I feel like it is similar to many other I haver had. It doesnt have a big hoppy taste. Not too much malt, and some sweetness. I think they poured some grapefruti juice in the beer.

Chicago Trip. Sunday 10:35. Orange. Not for the faint of heart. Intoxicating alcohol hop nose and flavour. Overpowering, in league with Devil Dancer. Hop level is too high for me. I try to pick out the malt but the hops club my tongue. Halfway through a bottle I can sense some malt sweetness.

What makes the score of this one so much higher than other I2PAs?  Not sure.  They seem fairly similar to each other to me.  This one does have nice balance (read loads of malt to go with the gobs of hops), a very nice appearance (dark orange, with a nice head), a very nice mouthfeel, creamy, which helps extinguish some hops flames.  Other than that the normal - piney aroma, a bit resinous, etc.

UPDATED: MAY 28, 2007 Thanks to my friend Ryan on this one.  Was a great score and I owe you one.  RIght off the bat, ripe grapefruit.  Big orange glow in the glass.  I was skeptical of smelling mango in the nose as the description says, but its very apparent.  The alcohol is really noticible when served cold. Once it warms, the flavor smooths out and the mouthfeel is super silky.  An amazing acomplishment for such a high IBU rating.  If the money doesnt matter, dont even bother with anther double IPA, theyre all amatuers compared...

22 oz bottle. Slightly hazy orange body with a big creamy head. Aroma is citrus hoppy  lots of it! Flavor is of course hoppy but also very well balanced fruity and malt. A great experience that clearly shows its possible to make fine beers at extreme IBU. Enjoyable.

Bottle purchased in Chicago and shipped back to NYC.  Pour is cloudy orange, aroma is strong on the citrus and hops, strong hoppy flavor but smooth.  This is a very good brew but Ive had Double IPAs that Ive liked just as much as this and they didnt cost me nearly as much.  Still, worthy of a good rating.

22oz Bomber
$9.99
Binnys Orland

As soon as I popped this open I could immediately smell grapefruit. Poured into a snifter a hazy orange/amber. Big bright orange highlights when held to the light. With a big creamy head on top that lasts. Moderate sticky lacing throughout the entire glass.

The smell is unbelievable. Its loaded with big juicy citrus hops. Sugared grapefruit along with a sprinkling of orange juice that smells like it was freshly squeezed. There is tropical fruit as well. Mango...all kinds of deliciousness. There is a touch of pine in the nose too. I sit here smelling this and my mouth just waters uncontrollably. Exceptional!

I almost expected to be let down when I drank this because of all the high praise. Im not let down one bit and I now understand why this is praised as much as it is. Theres a ton of the citrus in the taste thats in the aroma. As I drink this my mouth actually waters after the swallow. A smooth bitterness but by no means overwhelming. Amazing!

I find it difficult giving such praise but I try and find faults in Dreadnaught but have a very hard time doing so. Its medium bodied but coating. Balanced. The alcohol is non-existent in the mouthfeel. Unbelievable!

The drinkability for a beer of this size is downright sick. This my sound cliche but Dreadnaught is very dangerously drinkable. Every sip makes your mouth need another immediately afterwards. Dangerous!

I hate giving such high scores cause it would mean this beer is almost impossible to improve upon. To tell you the truth it would be almost impossible to improve on. I cant picture a IIPA being any better than this. I havent tried them all but Ive had quite a few and this is at the top of the list. Wow!

bottle that friend brought back from Indiana:  Unfortunately my bottle seemed to be a bit oxidized :(.  I was really really wanting to get at this one to as a lover of hoppy ales.  Oh well, hopefully Ill get my hands on another one.  Aroma was first very resiny with some weird garlic type note.  The beer is a none-transparent amberish orange with a decent head that will remain as a bubbly film throughout the duration of consumption.  Flavor is a bit cardboardy and soapy, but has significant malt backbone.  palate was very sticky much like stone 10th anniversary.  Ill really need to find another one of these.

Dark yellow color with a solid head. Aroma is like a sweet wheat with some citrus notes. Strong hops in the flavor, but enough malt presence to balance it out. A little more citrus. Good, but not complex.

Man, for a while this was my Holy Grail of beers. I had heard so much about it that I wasnt sure if it could live up to the hype. I am happy to say that it lived up to its reputation, and then some. HUGE burst of citrus at the front that gives way to a pleasant alcohol warmth and finishes with a fairly dry hop crispness. LOVED this beer. Now, the question is, Dreadnaught or Hopslam? Right now, I have to go with the Hopslam. But, I have also had a lot more of it than the Dreadnaught. Thanks to The Keg Liquors in Clarksville for being so close and carrying so many good beers. I will be back!!!

bottle purchased from DLD pours the most beautiful  crisp golden amber color I think I may have ever seen with a decent head. real pretty in the glass I thought. The taste is of citrus and pine. Alcohol is hidden well hops are not overwhelming but definitely there. A great lasting finish taste that stays with you for an hour if you dont eat or drink after. A delicious beer, although may not be worth the money.

(Bottle) Pours a deep hazy amber color with a small white head and good looking lacing. Oily palate. Strong aroma of fruit and hops. Taste includes pine, citrus, and sweet caramel malty notes. The beer is pretty good, and well balanced for the style. The alcohol is there, yet rather well masked. A very good brew!
Bottle. Hoppy, pine - citrus flavor, couldnt really detect the Mango and Peach flavors, oh well. Very good beer, lived up to the hype.

UPDATED: NOV 3, 2007 Had to rerate this one, have not had it in a few months.  Had it on tap at FFF brewpub, and let me tell you it was much better than I ever remember it.  It was full of amazing mango, orange, and citrus aromas.  It had a wonderful carbonation, and really nice mouthfeel like it was extremely fresh.  It showed the floral bouquet of flavors...citrus, mango, caramel, pine, grapefruit, and plum notes.  It was extremely flavorful, balanced, and complex.  The 9.5% ABV was well hidden, and actually added to the complexity.  I loved this extreme beer more than ever.

Dreadnaught was a bit too astringent for me, but the wonderfully complex, hoppy, burning flavor and aroma far outweighs this small issue. Start this one ice cold and let it warm up to 50 for your last few sips, as the beer changes character and grows into itself at the age of 50f.

There really is a mango/peach aroma but I had to search for it behind the intense pine. Pours red/orange with no real head to speak of. Flavor is intense pine followed by the sweet afformentioned fruit. Super unique. I get pine, not citrus. This shit is good. Pretty balanced too. Very dry. Resin coats your mouth after every sip. Damn good beer.

Pours orange with small off white head.  Aroma very hoppy and piny, with hints of citrus.  Flavor of hops, pine, and orange juice.  Only slight bitterness and doesnt really pack the punch I expect from imperial IPAs. All and all a very good brew.

22oz bottle. Fresh citrus orange tree bloom aroma. Aroma from second glass was more malt and bread. Orange body with good off white head and godd lacing. From the some of the citrus vine aromas thought this flavor would be dry, but aroma was decieving. Flavor was a good malty thick orange juice and mild bitterness. Sweet malty orange syrupy aftertaste left on the palate. Good brew, thanks to the wife for sending this to me while on vacation.

UPDATED: JUN 2, 2007 On tap at the FFF brewpub.  Served in a bowtie glass.  Pours a deep hazy orange with a small beige diminishing head.  Leaves some nice thick lacing.  Aroma is heavy on the hops with some sweet peach and grapefruit undertones.  Medium to full body.  Taste is hops, pine and peach.  Very satisfying beer.  Nice bitter finish with lasting peach taste.  This beer lives up to its strong reputation.  One of my favorites.

Lacing in a glass of this beer is almost as thick as the liquid that produced it. The head is full, rocky, well retained and lasts until the final draw. Cloudy orange/copper body appears oily, luminescent with only the dimmest lighting available. Aroma is gorgeous, a true grand expression of an astounding hop combination. Mango, apricot, pine, earthy herbs, peach, orange pith; the hops are delicious long before the first sip. Alcohol is well concealed but tingles the tip of my nose with the forceful inhalation I subject myself to...I just want to revel in the wonderful scents. Bready malts are plentiful enough to demand recognition, soft enough to sidestep interfering with the fruit basket in liquid form I cant get enough of. Also noted are fresh florist shop scents and lavender hints. This isnt the best nose Ive encountered in a double IPA, but its awful close. Flavor is just as wonderful, much more balanced as well. Moderate malt charater is very sweet and slightly doughy, slightly peppery. Very light acidity. For such a boisterous hop shot in the nose, this is exceedingly drinkable and only mildly bitter. Finishes with good balance of malt and hops, moderately dry and lightly spicy. Oily and slick mouthfeel, incredibly smooth and full bodied. Its also ludicrously creamy. I suppost that if this were a draft sample Id have scored it even higher, those samples in the past seem a touch more memorable. As it stands, this rating is from a fresh bottle. This one is a keeper, always a treat. Ambrosia.

22 oz bomber. Ok the front of my bottle says "Imperial I.P.A." but the side reads "Dreadnaught is a massive American Pale Ale brewed....." so what the hell is this beer supposed to be if the brewers dont even know?? Well I think its an Impy IPA that is close to a year old so all those beautiful hops have mellowed to a fond memory that only the brewers know about. This is still a damn fine beer that poured an orangy/ amber color with only a small white head that came from a rather vigorous pour. Aroma is caramel malts with only slight hops remaining. Flavor follows suite with initial malt flavors and only a slight bitterness but it is a very enjoyable flavor none the less.

UPDATED: DEC 17, 2011 12/17/11:  22oz. Bottle:  Aroma of hops, pine, resin, citrus, and caramel malt.  Poured amber in color with a small, off-white head that lasted throughout.  Cloudy.  Sparkling.  Full of tiny particles throughout.  Flavor is light to medium sweet and heavily bitter.  Tastes of malt, hops, citrus, orange, tangerine, resin, and pine.  Medium body.  Oily, then dry texture.  Average carbonation.  Malt, hop, tangerine, citrus, resin finish is dry.  9.5%ABV is completely hidden throughout.  8/4/8/4/16 = 4

5/7/2007:  22oz. Bottle:  Very bitter and lightly sweet aroma.  Smells very hoppy with notes of pine, resin, and grapefruit.  Poured amber in color with a small tan head that diminished quickly.  Good lacing.  Hazy.  Sparkling.  Flavor is heavily bitter.  Tastes strongly of hops, with flavor of grapefruit and pine.  Medium body.  Smooth, creamy texture.  Average carbonation.  Long bitter finish.  Overall, a very good Imperial IPA.  8/4/8/4/17 = 4.1

Three Floyds Dreadnaught Imperial IPA
22 oz bomber
Medium pour in a tulip glass
Recent brewing, braved 05/07

Poured a clear amber orange with a small mostly diminishing white head.

Smelt of strong pineapple and citrus, and moderate caramel, apricot, light banana.

Taste was upfront strong sweet mango apricot and oranges  with a bitter grassy and spruce hops followed by a strong bitter moss and dry leaves yeast on a moderate finish.

Palate was creamy, lively carbonated, medium to full bodied lightly cloying and strongly astringent.

Overall, a rich malty sweet IPA loaded with fruit flavors and a generous hop bite.  Not a personal favorite though, it was fairly hard to drink a whole bomber.

Bomber. Pours hazy, very orange copper with thin ivory head. The nose is lots of pineapple, mandarin orange, mango, wheat bread, and a wisp of alcohol. The flavor is more piney than the nose, but has a good dose of fruit as well-- grapefruit, various tropical fruits. It is a little bit woody in the middle, with some brown sugar sweetness. Bitter finish with grapefruit and some tannicity and a round alcohol warmth. Quite good.

Picked up a six pack at The Coffee Grounds in Eau Claire, WI. Pours a dark hazy orange brew with a fizzy off white head. Good lacing. Aroma is very piney, grapefruit and some sweet caramel. Taste is smooth, sweet malted candy with a very bitter finish. One of the better IPA Ive tried.

UPDATED: AUG 7, 2007 Bottle from Jb175: Pours a slightly cloudy orange with a very thin white head. Aromas of mango and some hops. Flavor is moderately sweet with a medium body of carmel and toffee. Medium hop bitterness and flavor. Definitely a nice and strange mango flavor in this. Floral hoppy notes. Pretty damn good but i definitely did not find this one equal to its rating as 1 in imperial ipas.
Bottle. Light amber color with a small white head. Nice hoppy aroma. Full sweet malty body with a balance bitterness. Hoppy and dry bitter palate. Very nice.

22 oz bottle.  Poured a clear orange color. Head was off white and reduced to a thin film that left a little lace behind. Smelled of crushed pine needles, malty cereal grain, and a touch of citrus. Medium bodied and slightly sweet. Fruity flavor with hints of citrus, peach, and apricot. There is also some biscuity malt and alcohol. Moderate hop bitterness that peaks at the end and lingers. The alcohol warms as it settles into the stomach.

UPDATED: APR 29, 2007 Trade from Nolankowal, thanks John.  Pours a rich amber color with thin white head.  Aroma is resinous with citrus hops, some exoctic fruit (possibly some mango), pine and some candy flavors.  Taste is citrus hops, caramel malt, sharp spruce taste, light lime.  Its pretty complex.  Alcohol is well hidden and carbonation is moderate.  All and all a great IIPA, however Bells Hopslam still would be my preferred choice.

UPDATED: FEB 4, 2008 Bottled on multiple occasions. Pours a dark amber color with moderate haze to it with minimal head. Slightly syrupy pour, but still some decent white lacing going on. Earthy and toasty floral hop aroma as soon as the bottle is cracked it open, as well as rum barrel, and orange cheesecake notes, improving with temperature increase.  Very smooth mouthfeel towards the end. Heavy malt, pine sap and grapefruit in the flavor, excellent! This beer is surprisingly well-balanced for the high ABV. Palate finishes smooth and silky in the mouthfeel, with a good bitter kick. Definitely an ass-kicker of a DIPA. I would like a crisper finish, but definitely worthy!

UPDATED: OCT 25, 2007 Finally got to sample this stuff FRESH.  A whole different monster w/o all the age on it.  Very crisp - very flavorful, sharp, solid finish.  Much less resemblence of a barleywine than my first sampling about 6 months ago...Great job of balancing this one out and hiding that alcohol.  Flavor wise, I thought it was outstanding --- citruisy, piney, grapefruit, with a dominance of oranges - great mouthfeel/full bodied.  Overall, an outstanding beer - very few IIPAs out there could go toe to toe with Dreadnaught.   I could drink loads of this...just too expensive.

bottle from leopoldstoch:  pours a orange honey colour with a small white head that diminishes. no lacing. aroma is of sweet citrus hops with a nice malt background. flavour is sweet and smooth upfront with a wonderful balance of hop bitterness in the finish. the flavour is citrus oine and earth eith a a maltness to balance. excellent
ps aroma is like froliknig in an orange field with pot growing under you and hops over your head. bliss
(05) Pours oramnge with a white head. Has a aroma of  hops, caramel ,maple  and malt. The flavor is pretty complex with notes of hops fruit, citrus, lemom and malts. Extremely Good I2PA !!

The hops are everywhere in this beer, as is the case with many FFF beers, but really a light clean aroma and flavor here. The 9.5% is undetectable. Just a beautiful specimen of a beer. Mouthfeel, balance, HOPS....its all there on this one. No need to go in to extreme detail; the ratings and reputation speak for themselves here. Three cheers for Three Floyds!
Intense hops aroma, intense hops taste. Also some sweetness to the aroma that lingers well. Long finish with a bit of citrus taste.

bottle.  An orange amber color with minimal head.  Aroma of grapefrut and citrus.  Found the hops over powered the malt a little bit too much; Good malt flavor though.  Mouthfeel was good, could have been a little more oily for my taste.  Flavor lingers well.
Bottle.  Aroma of sweet malt and citrus hops.  Good smooth palate.  The flavor is strong, a little less malty than I anticipated.  The grapefruit / piney hops are nice and linger for a long time.
smells of hops and toffee, a golden amber color that is topped with a rich white head.  the mouthfeel is chalky, dry and biting, quite remarkable.

Yes, Im spoiled.  I can get Dreadnaught anytime I want.  Needless to say, I drink a lot of it and LOVE it.  Pine, tomato vines, grapefruit, great mouthfeel.  This is the standard bearer for all IIPA.

right up there as one of my favorite DIPAs ive had thus far. sweet sweet malts leading to a nice thick mouthfeel, bright balanced hop profile of citrus, grapefruit, with some piney and floral aspects...fantastic DIPA

lil sweet and fruity although better than some doubles ive had. was looking for more hop bite but i guess im seeing that for the most part the singles have more bitter straight forward hop burn than any double ive had i guess due to the amount of malts. id like to see a single ipa with double the hops and the same amount of malt!! there ya go lite that up! at any rate try one its a good beer!

UPDATED: APR 13, 2008 on tap at the maproom. pours a dense of orange with white head. nose is still something special, gushing grapefruit fruit, mango, and citrus. my favorite iipa nose. flavor isnt as bitter to me anymore and seems pretty heavy on the sweet side, however, the hop flavor is complex and more interesting than most iipa. extremely rich and fruity. wonderful flavor. alcohol slightly warms but is well hidden. probably still my favorite iipa and is really improved when its on cask. a must try.8/4/9/4/17=4.2. 

2/13/08, bottle from Im almost positive, the fresh early 2008 batch. pours clear golden with white head. nose has raw, gritty, grassy, grainy notes. not a beautiful hop bomb to say the least. flavor is rather bitter but lacks an interesting hop profile, intensely grapefruity at first but that drops off so fast leaving a grainy alcohol finish. watery body is probably what contributes to such a poor flavor-palate length. oh boy what happened to this beer? people have been noticing a decline in this brew over the past few years but this is obvious. pales in comparison to the pliny the younger I had 5 days ago. rating unchanged because further research is needed. 6/4/7/3/13=3.3.

Pretty high expectations for this brew given its ratings. Nice bottle label. Hops are pretty well masked by all the malt and ABV in this, pretty fruity for my tastes. I thought this would be tough to put down because it would be hop overload, but it went down quite smooth, nice brew, but in general I think I prefer single IPAs just for the fact that you typically can taste more hop bite.

UPDATED: AUG 29, 2007 Bomber. Pours a coppery orange with a cream colored head.  Smells really nice... hoppy and sweet.  Tastes very hoppy, but balanced nicely with that same sweet peachiness.  Mouthfeel is very smooth and creamy.  Wow-nice.

Re-rate: I had a second bottle of this which was not incredibly fresh and nowhere near as good.  Be aware there is a drastic difference between fresh Dreadnaught and old Dreadnaught.

Orange and somewhat cloudy, with a very hoppy aroma.  A very hoppy flavor as well, with a smooth, creamy palate.  It reminded me of a "triple" IPA.  Dreadnaught is a classic example of the American DIPA style.

Pours a dark copper. First glass has no foam, second glass has 1 finger. Very minimal lacing. Aroma is predominantly sweet malts with plenty of hops behind it. Pine hops slightly overpower the citrus and floral, but its a nice blend. Taste is hard to pin down. The sweet malts blend nicely with the hops. The interesting hop blend is not as aggressive as I would expect from 3Fs. Not too sweet, which is my primary complaint in the genre. Very easy to drink by DIPA standards. Mouthfeel is creamy and does not get syrupy. If this were $6 instead of $11 for a 22oz it would be a no-brainer.

UPDATED: JAN 17, 2008 Re-Rate 17-01-2008:
This really deserves a bit more in rating, as this was very full smooth and almost creamy like in feel. Hoppy yet sweet and very lovely to sip over a long period of time. 8 / 4 / 9 / 4 / 16

28-03-2007:8 / 3 / 9 / 4 / 14
Bottle.  [Blind tasting session @ Sk8viking]  #22 Small fizzy white head that was mostly diminishing. Good lacing. Light cloudy body with an amber hue. Aroma was very sweet fruit with a good mix of hoppy notes. Some malty notes can also be detected. Caramel, grain, toffee, tropical fruits, pine, grapefruit. Full bodied with a slightly dry texture. Moderated sweet with good balancing bitterness. Slightly sweet and dry finish. Excellent, would really like to taste this one again.
Abosultely my type of beer.  Overwhelming hops in this sample at the brewery.  Cant wait for Fridays beer.

Top notch imperial IPA.  We drive down to Munster IN from Chicago specifically to drink this on tap.  We can get it on tap in Chicago, but it just doesnt taste as fresh-- maybe its just our imagination.  One of the best beers Ive ever tried.
A delicious IIPA.  Hops, orange, grapfruit, citrus, more piney hops, and well balance with caramel, malt, and toffee.  Beautiful brew.

Big thanks goes to axilla for trading this. Blind rating at sk8viking´s. Pours a clear orange with off-white head and lacings. Smells of alcohol and grapefruit. Slightly malty backbone but otherwise big loads of fruity hops - pineneedles and tropical fruits. Also notes of a bourbon and cherries. Slightly sugary.

UPDATED: AUG 1, 2008 Bomber...Thanks to Ty5592 for this one. Quite good. Typical orange color, nice hop bitterness up front that cools into a smooth drinking big brew...A good  beer.
