Thanks Ty.tap at brewery, re-rate, 8/1/08- still not one of my favorite double ipas- too bitter for its own good. Solid, but not worth the hype.

UPDATED: MAY 29, 2007 Bomber.  Pours a cloudy orange with a small, off white head.  A lot of bubbles rising to the top.  Smell is sweet, floral hops.  Very sweet.  The hops arent overwhelming, in the aroma at least.  A lot of citrus in the aroma as well.  Taste is hoppy, bitter, oily, and tingly in the mouth.  The sweet and citrus notes in the aroma are prevalent in the taste as well.  A never ending bitter finish.  This is an interesting beer.  Complex with a nice balance between the citrus and bitter flavors.  

Re-rate.  After having 3 bottles of this I can say that the freshness factors in significantly.  My initial rating was for a pretty old bottle.  Since I have tried a relatively fresh one and the hop flavor and aroma are amazing.  Absolute perfect taste and a measuring stick for every other hoppy beer.  The sweetness is perfect and natural unlike some other cloying IIPAs (Im looking at you Hercules).  Really an amazing beer.

Bottle in trade with Puddintane (respect Dave). Theres no doubt this is a huge beer. From beginning to end it crashes through your senses, challenging you to keep up with it. Certainly one of the most fruity, flowery beers Ive ever smelt, with lots of apricot, peach and melon, as well as rose petals and wet stone. Upfront its massively sweet, almost syrupy - like someones drained the juice from a tin of tropical fruit into the bottle. Then the hops slide in, balancing out most - but by no means all - the sweetness, to leave a pleasant hop-tingle finish. The bottle conditioning delivers a wonderfully soft mouthfeel, with just a prickle of carbonation. What marks it down for me is the concentrated sweetness - too much tropical syrup for my taste buds - which in turn makes it a touch sickly to drink a lot of. I love hops, but delivered in a slightly cleaner, more refreshing way. That said, this is fab beer and a bottle I wont ever forget.

bottle. Sampled most recently apres-ski this past sunday. Orange amber with a moderate off-white head. Big, citric, hoppy aroma. Intense hop flavor, but the malt profile is big enough that the hops dont totally overwhelm. Nice double IPA thats not totally one dimensional.

UPDATED: JUL 6, 2007 A hop lovers dream?  You bet ya.  The problem is that while I like hopiness, this is just overpowering for my taste.  Hazy orange color  with a white head.  I love the smell of this beer....versy strong with an almost floral scent.  Like most FFFs, this beer has a creamy mouthfeel and explosive flavors.  I would have rated higher, but as stated earlier its just a little too hoppy for my personal taste.

UPDATE:  I just had this beer again and had to give it another point for aroma.  It seems now that I am beginning to be much more of a hop lover than I was and thats what makes this beer smell so great.  Its Incredible.
one of the better imperial IPAs i have had......commercial description is accurate on the flavors......pleasantly hoppy, non abrasive, fruity, delicious

Bottled. Hazy and deep golden orange coloured with a rather large off-white head. This is really well balanced. Notes of malty sweetness and bitter hops. Hints of pines, caramel, flowers and citrus. Yummy!

Bottle acquired from Viggo and shared with Piscator34 for  the MB DIPA throwdown.  Much thanks Viggo for this tasty hop bomb treat!  Pours out a solid dark amber. Decent head a lacing. Aroma was more about the malts than expected. For the rep of this beer, I feared that my nose hairs would burn off sniffing this sucker.  Taste is beautiful blast of citrus hops with a heavy creamy toasty malt backbone.  Very creamy indeed and had a great finish to it.  I can only imagine what it would be like fresh from the brewery. No astringency noted and the alcohol was well hidden.  Fantastic brew and was almost more balanced than I thought going into it.  It was a flavour explosion on an otherwise dull March Saturday. Best of show in the throwdown.

UPDATED: MAR 20, 2007 Bottled sample via Oakbluff on IIPA Saturday. Bold hop aromas with loads of citrus and soft stone fruit notes. Perhaps just the slightest touch of roasted malt aroma.  More citrus fruit in the mouth with elements of pine, crystal malt sweetness and a bit of breadiness. Quite heavy in the mouth. Not quite as dry as my favorite IIPAs, but a quality brew nonetheless. Huge thanks to Oakbluff for sharing this beauty.

This beer is really something...  Pours a golden orange color with a short white head.  It contains fantastic aromas of fruity hops, pine, and some pleasant sweet notes.  Flavors are of complex, fresh fruity hops, pine sap, and very well controlled bitterness.  It is so very smooth and balanced.  A really fine effort - something that even those who do not like IIPAs would enjoy.

(2006 version) poured from a 22oz bomber into a snifter glass

A: Looks like many top-quality DIPAs should look, a deep orange rust color, very clouded or murky. You wont be reading a book while peering through this beer. Very little head but nice oily lacing.

S: Oh so complex! Some mouth-watering malted bread scents meld beautifully with citrusy and perfumy-like floral hops. I even detect some notes of vanilla and peach. Sweet but not cloyingingly so.

T/M: Amazingly well-balanced double IPA, delicious mixture of fruity citrus & moderately toasted malts; VERY bitter grapefruit finish, massive hops, lingers a long time; slightly syrupy, but just enough carbonation to make it easy to take larger sips; damned near perfect.

D: If this wasnt bomber-only, and 9.3% ABV, Id request a Dreadnaught transfusion instead of blood. But alas, its not, so Ill just drink as much of it as I can. :-)

Highly recommended, a stalwart of the style.

Awesome. Great aroma. Very ice ambe color on the puor. Not alot of head due to the glass I used. The flavo is unreal!!! Nice citus, hop balance, and very smooth textue on the tounge. Followed by a lingering almost orange cady like taste on the tip of my tounge. Go get it....... What are you staring at? NOW!!!!!!

This was as good as advertised, and one of the more complex beers Ive had. Started out pouring from the bottle to a bright orange-red, with thick off-white head that stayed around for the entire glass, and excellent lacing. Initial aroma was strongly hoppy citrus, mainly grapefruit and oranges. However, as the beer warmed, the aroma became more influenced by a malty sweet aroma. Likewise, the flavor, which started out heavily on the bitter, hoppy citrus side, while retaining that throughout, became nicely blended with a malty sweet syrupy taste. Alcohol also made itself more known as the beer warmed, perfectly complementing the hops and malts.

Finally, the finish was lterally a bittersweet blend of hops and malts, with an overall warming sensation from the 9.5% abv.

UPDATED: APR 26, 2007 Poured into a snifter from a 22oz bomber, a beautiful dark, crisp, orange color. Not as hazy as some other IPAs. Aroma is well balanced, a good mix of piney hops, grilled citrus, spice, and some hints of peach and apricot. Medium to full bodied, lively carbonation, this is a great brew. Beat expectations.

The aroma was piney and resinous with a strong citrusy punch. The citrus was grapefruit and a bit of orange coupled with a nice malty backbone comprised of base malt and caramel. Crystal clear copper with a very low slight head which barely lasted to lace the glass. The flavor was peachy and contained a nice piney, grassy and fruity hop presence. The flavor which began as peach quickly changed over to a lemony grapefruit citrus with a bit of orange. The malt backbone was well done and the bittering came across as very, very smooth. The body was medium full and despite the fairly low carbonation level the beer was creamy. A really nice double IPA, some alcohol warming after consumption and a dry resinous and citrusy finish. YUM! 22 ounce bottle.
user_location: North of Raleigh, North Carolina, USA

text: Very appealing color - a bright amber- and a nice aroma like I would expect in a brew of this price and reputation.  I found the flavor to be slightly medicinal.  The alcohol content was well-masked but this one was a little too rich for my taste. Its a very good Imperial, but I would rather have a premium pale ale or regular IPA than this selection.

This beer came out of the Midwest?!  Tastes like NW hops.  Very valuable beer  for Indianians.  After several bomby beauties, I was pleased to try this hazy orange colored brew.  Bottle conditioned and worthy to stand beside any West Coast beer.  This beer has been rated 100 on this site for a while, and rightfully so!  Boo yah!  If you like this , you owe it to yourself to try Moylans Hopsickle, Mad River Double IPA, or the uber-awesome Fish Tail Ten Squared

Bottle, a nice amber orange color with a thin off-white head and good lacing.  Aroma is quite full and pleasing, with floral, orange, grapefruit, island fruits, pine and light caramel.  Taste starts with a nice bitter hops bite that echos the aroma nicely, a more malty middle, and ends with a milder hops finish.  A great flavor profile on the palate; an excellent IIPA, highly recommended.

This is a spectacular brew. I also speak for 3 people here so let it commence: The brews smell was that of grapefruit and hops. The flavour is bitter but not astringent. More of the grapefruit is present than other citrus hints....I am in tuned to grapefruit as it is one of my fav. citruses. There is a bit of tartness but not bitter and follows to a clean finish begging for aother sip. The head is white and semi-thick (translucent) and pours a gorgeous golden-orange. The inital taste is that of bitterness then finishes cleanly with a bit of palate coating citrus. In my eyes a good finish. My brothers analysis of this was a bitter aroma in which he could smell the hops with a flavor of grapefruit but not overwhelming. One he said he would not go out and order specifically but definately drink if the bar was open so to speak. My sister-in law said the aroma was that of peaches....where my brother and I wer like "okay where did that come from?" It did not fit a girls taste as much as ours. This is a near perfect beer yet again raising my hopes for DarkLord day. If you want a palate clenser or complexifier try drinking a bit of 100% ruby red grapefruit juice with it. It WILL change the flavor dramatically. I know because I am on number 2 and wanted to experiment. This is not the most extreme brew I have been able to drink ABV% wise but overall a fine brew. $10 per 22oz will however keep me from buying mass quantities.----Overall concensentuious is a drinkable brew in which my brother could actually finish...as could I. Thank you FFF for an amazing experience and a memorable one at that. Simply superb and fitting in the top 15 brews from around the world. My siss olfactory is the only X factor therefore not allowing this to be a perfect 5.....for which I am sorry. Otherwise it is perfect!!!!

orange/red color, a color i havent seen much in beer. aroma is citrus, BIG citrus, lots of grapefruit! love it!
flavour is all grapefruit, orange, lemon, with a butt load of hops!! finish is VERY bitter, easily the best IPA i have ever had.

Bitter. Amber orange color with small sized head. Very juicy and hoppy with pine and grapefruit, a lot of sweet fruitiness going on to complement the bitterness, supported by the firm pale malt backbone. I dont think my bottle was that fresh either and overall the flavors seemed somewhat muted. From this bottle, not the best double IPA in the world but still quite good. Hopefully rerate again soon.

Pours an orangy-copper with a decent head and considerable lacing. Aroma is dominated by pine with some flowers and honey. In the mouth it is totally consuming, with total bitterness and pine domination but with a consistent mid-taste of orange liquour that lifted this beer into the realm of the 4s. It has good mouthfeel, but the aftertaste is smooth..like an iced tea. I wanted a bit more of the bitterness to linger, but it doesnt and I cant tell if that is good or bad. Thanks to my dad for bringing this great beer down to Panama over Xmas. As I finish the 22oz. bottle, with a warm happiness, I have found that this beer only gets better with warmth. More metalic finish, a bit more citrus. Still not my favorite Imperial IPA, but I value the citrus a lot. This is a great beer, though.

Pours a lightly orangish amber with a nice big white head.  Nice aromatic nose of citrus, pine, lots of pine.  The flavor is very well balanced and reminds me of Hopslam, with less citrus and more pine.  The light malt backbone balances the finish very well.  A very tasty brew that survived being frozen, and leaking in transit to me.  I will re-rate if it is different upon tasting it again.
user_location: Farewell Minny; Hello Puyallup, Washington, USA

text: UPDATED: FEB 5, 2007 Bottle from Sprinkle. Lovely orange color with hints of amber. Aroma is very bitter and quite spicy. Some deep ancient redwood sap quality. Very bitter. Balanced though some sweet mandarin qualities. Very nice, very tasty.

UPDATED: FEB 19, 2007 Many many thanks to Nucular george for this one. He didnt have to send me one but did anyway.

Pours a darkcopper coller with a white head that wasnt too thick and didnt last too long. The smell is the smell of legends. Hoppy and floraly(WTF?). The taste hits you like a sack of hops. Just as hard as it hits, it finishes that smooth. The balance is freaking great in this one. For the strentgh of this one it is very drinkable. Not drink 10 in one sittig drinkable, but drinkable.

UPDATED: MAY 17, 2008 Orange-copper with good, white head / Nose of fresh pine, citrus and spun sugar /  Medium, creamy hop body with undertones of sweet, syrupy malts, and fine finish  / Rich flavors of fresh cut pine, orange peel, peach, mango, and spun sugar / Dreadnaught v. Dog 90 for supremacy?

Bottle:  Hazy orange  color with lots of foamy, white head.  Nice lacing throughout the glass.  Aroma is packed with floral hops, citrus, and sweet malt.  Even some grass.  Taste is thick, syruplike with lots of citrus, floral hops, slight fruitiness, and sweet malt to balance.  Tail is deliciously dry, bitter, and tart.  My first brew from FFF - Awesome IIPA.  Thanks Bert!

Pours a bright clear copper, with about an inch of foam. Seriously, I cant get over how bright the beer looks. Minimal lacing. Nice hoppy malty aroma.

Starts out way hoppy - pine, citrus, and a wee bit spicy. Then the malt comes in - smooth, sugar-sweet, and a hint of melon. Then the pine hops in the aftertaste. And then a sweetness coats the tongue in a thin layer. Spicy and alcoholic in the aftertaste. Full bodied.

Splendid. Potent. Delicious.

I lve this beer.  Mega-hops,  lots of citrus in that bad boy.

Available in 220z bottles in town for $12....even at that price its one hell of  a treat!

Bomber via Holdenn (Thanks!).  Aroma of  big hops, pine, grapefruit, peach and other fruity aromas.  Pours a golden/ reddish color with a medium sized tan head that lingers.  Flavor is laden with hop notes and fruity goodness that just lingers in your mouth.  Palate is quite exquisite with just the right amount of fruity bitterness.  Overall, One damn good Imperial IPA.  Its up there with Bells Hopslam and maybe just a little bit better.  Cheers!!!  Thank you Holdenn for sending this wonderful beer that I cant get here in Michigan.

22 oz bottle.  Pours a golden copper with a very slight head.  The aroma is dominated by peach, followed by mango then pine.  Very thick feel in the mouth.  Smooth and hoppy with a bitter grapefruit finish.  You wouldnt know it was a beer if you didnt pour it from the bottle.  A definite sipper.

Bottle.  Pours thick and oily, with a deep gold hue and a small slowly developing head.  The aroma is like being in a pine and peach forest, with sap on every peach.  Feels heavy in the mouth, but medium body in the finish.  Very clean finish.  This beer is amazing.
user_location: Peoples Republic of Athens, Ohio, USA

text: Complex, complex, complex. Finesse is near zero, but personality and complexity is over the top. Copper, slighly hazy, thin head,. The aroma: Pine, malts, sweetness, resin (?). The mouthfeel thick and satisfying. The taste is perfection, though again not overly refined, but there is alot going on with this beer. All the taste completely hides the alcohol.

#500 rating. 22 oz bomber courtesy of Degarth. Thanks Joe, this is one of the brews Ive been looking forward to trying for some time now. Cracked it open during the 8:30pm replay of The Colbert Report with guest Papa Bear Bill OReilly. The beer poured copper with quickly dissipating white head. The aroma has lots of pine, sweet malts creating biscuit and bread notes, some melony-ness, bubble gum, and maybe a hint of citrus. The taste has the nice full mouthfeel reminding you youre drinking something with assertiveness here. Pine hops hit up front with bitterness slowly giving way to a bit of pine hop flavor sweetness. About midway some maltiness surfaces for added sweetness and slight roastiness. Then the pine hop bitterness begins to build into the finish and aftertaste. No sense of the ABV. Delicious beer.

UPDATED: JAN 24, 2007 Poured from bomber into my Dogfish pint glass.
Pours a hazy ruby/light brown color with almost no head at all. Slight rings of lace around the top of the glass.
Smell is hops. Juicy, citrusy, piney and floral! This is really a very good smelling beer. The smell itself lets me know that Ive got something good here.
Taste is incredible. Everything one should look for in a DIPA and then some. It slams your tastebuds with a wide array of hops and a slight alcohol sense. With a pretty bitter taste coming through midway to the end. It all finishes clean and juicy, making you reach for the glass wanting another drink.
Mouthfeel is is perfect. Not too thick, not too thin. Just right. A good amount of carbonation and malt to balance this out. I was expecting a really bitter overly hopped beer. But this is really balanced and very, very good.
I dont think I would want to drink more than a bomber of this in a sitting. Im quickly becoming a bigger fan of Three Floyds with every beer I try. If you havent tried this one, you havent had the best DIPA yet.

22 oz Bottle at The Firkin in Glen Ellyn, IL. Pours a hazy oarange with nice white head. Strong smell of grapefruit, mango and pine. Surprisingly easy to drink. Great balance of sweet malt. Hard to believe this is a 100 IBU beer. This is potent stuff. Its easy to forget how high the alcohol content is. Youll still be tasting (and feeling) this beer the day after.

From a 22oz Bottle.  Deep, golden orange body with a thick layer of well sustaining fizzy off-white, golden head.  Loads of hops in the aroma, supplemented by a canteloupe-like malty sweetness.  Pink grapefruit juice and orange zest abound to create a citrus fruit hoppy bouquet, softened by a squeeze of mango.  Full bodied, creamy carbonated mouthfeel.  Slightly sweet, ridiculously juicy start on the palate, just dripping with freshly squeezed oranges and pink grapefruits.  Im quite impressed by how soft the mouthfeel is.  The hop characters are also quite rounded and soft, considering the obvious dominance - I wonder what vintage this bottle is?  It was consumed just days after purchase in the store.  Most of the hop bitterness comes out on the back end, again citrusy, will some soft notes of red pine.  An extremely well hidden alcohol slowly warms during the final smack.  Quite tasty overall; Im rather suprised how much Im enjoying this beer considering I usually shy away from big bodied IPAs.  Id like to taste it fresh on tap sometime to experience the maximum possible punch in the face from the hops.  Thanks, Dillon!

UPDATED: JAN 27, 2012 1/15/2007:  Strong aroma and flavor, but a little too much grapefruit and piney taste and not sweet enough. Id like to try again if I didnt have to pay $8 for a bottle because I really wanted to like this one and am hoping a I got a bad bottle.  (4) (3) (7) (3) (15) : 3.1

Re-rate 5 years later since 3F is distributing in Ohio again.
Funny I was complaining about an $8 bottle back then...its $12 now! 
Beautiful golden color with gigantic fluffy off-white head and tons of lacing. Huge floral and citrusy aroma. I taste a nice sweet & sour fruitiness in the beginning with an overwhelming, sharp bitter finish. Its really complex. And at $12 a bottle, I can only afford to drink one every 5 years now....

A great IIPA no doubt...but I think I expected too much from this. I must try another bottle. The taste and aroma was all floral hops with little malt. The bitterness is listed as 100 IBUs but it didnt taste like it. The Alpha King tasted more intense than this. This is a league of its own...but in the 3 Floyd League I must admit its not as potent. Will try again.
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text:
UPDATED: MAR 15, 2008 Re-rate of a fresh bottle from motortoddhead.  This is yummy and the citrus is amazing.


22oz bomber, curtesy of my pal and fellow brew rater, Bartzilla.  Beer 5 of the Bartzillas Death Metal Beer Tasting 1/12/2007, consumed with many great beer drinkers including Bartzilla, Naven, as well as Lee creator of Arrogant Bastard, and a really cool guy. 

This is a really seriously potent DIPA, and it really knocks you down with all that hoppy potency it smells great, lots of hops right there in the nose.  The taste though is pretty phenomenal.  Although I had it after many other beers, I may still say that I prefer DFH 90 minute to this brew, maybe its out of habbit, but thsi brew seems to lack some of the complexity of the 90 minute.  It is damn good no doubt.

UPDATED: MAR 12, 2007 This beer is light and refreshing with abundant and delicious citrus notes, but at the same time packs a big hop wallop. Dreadnought lives in its own place on the beer landscape, as it closely walks the yin-yang line between certain attributes. It is both extremely light and bitter/heavy, it is very sessionable yet satisfying, and is drinkable yet strong. This beer can be wonderful, my only complaint is that over a handful of times Ive had this beer, its character (or quality? or age?) has been extremely inconsistent. The bottle I had the other day was delightful and everything good I remember about this brand from the first time I had it (on-tap at Three Floyds). But Ive also had bottles of this that are extremely malty and stale. The bad bottles Ive had are made worse by the hefty price tag ($10 for a big bottle) this beer frequently carries.

Buy it when you believe its fresh, as it is an awesome beer then. Avoid it if you see any signs of age.  A truly unique beer.

Bomber from LennyH - thanks, man! This is the second Dreadnaught Ive had, and its tough to approach this beer after reading soooo much about it. Its a lovely brew, with a full and rich body, fine lacing, and a huge floral hop aroma. The first time around I thought the malt presence was too intense, but now Im feeling it a bit more and the bitters give the beer a bit more balance and integrity. I still dont necessarily think this is the top of the mountain, but its clearly top notch.
Wow very nice! nice copper color and a floral perfume nose that invites. Good body and lacing. The finish is bitter but balabces out with the full body malt.

Great beer, lived up to the hype for me.  It is a golden/orange glowing color.  Taste is really nice with a ton of peach/mango flavors and floral tastes on top of that.  Enough malt to back things up also.  If you never had this and are wondering if it is worth getting it...it is.

Smells great, very cloudy appearance. This is one relaly nice IPA. Taste is good, very nice balance. Only thing that keeps this from being perfect is that the alcohol is just a little too present. Still, very nice. I like the Alesmith still the best.
Spectacular Hop qualities with a passion fruit quality. Deep red color, floral aroma, great flavor. Wonderful beer. Very akin to Bells Hopslam.
22oz bottle, Great amount of hops and terrific amount of taste. everything i would hope for in a IIPA. Taste reveals something sweet amongst the massive amounts of hop. Another Fantastic from FFF.
Big hop aroma with grapefruit overtones.  Goodl balance between hops and malt in the taste.  Everthing is going right with this beer.

UPDATED: MAY 24, 2008 New 2007 bomber from a trade with BBB63. Aroma of grapefruit and mango. Medium to heavy bodied,. Taste screams of fresh tropical fruit and citrus. Very nicely bitter finish. After four bottles of this, I finally understand the high rating. This is one of the best IIPAs out there, IF you get it fresh. The bottles seem to age very fast.

I have never had a FFF that Ive not thoroughly enjoyed.  this IIPA is no exception.  Great citrussy grapefruit aroma with a great big full body.  A fantastic balance on the palate with a perfect finishing dry bitter end.  2 thumbs for 3 Floyds!

A clear amber ale with a strong hop nose.  The flavor is the oily taste of hops, balanced on a slight bit of malt.  Slight carbonation, very heavy mouthfeel.  I feel it is somewhat overrated as "the best IIPA" (Personally, Id stick to Ruination or Hopslam), but it is a tasty one.

UPDATED: DEC 25, 2006 Bomber from Archer Liquors.

Body is a dark tea colored hue with a firm and lasting thumb thick tan head. Aroma is a full frontal assault of citrus and pine hops that leave nothing else to smell save some vague sweet maltiness that leans to fruit, but who can really tell with their nose hair seared off. This doesnt smell, it attacks. You can tell the ingredients are quality, but it is like too many spices in the gravy.

Fore is thick and oily with a colossal hop presence that is bitter enough to cause one to recoil. The hop acids are so thick you can feel resin building in your throat. Curiously though it isnt bitter so much as it is oily. If you just love hop oil this is nirvana. If you like the hops to stay in the back and play second fiddle or to be crazy bitter this beer will drive you crazy, like it is driving me. I literally cant taste anything else but the tongue burning hottness of hop oils.

Wow. This beer could use some more hops. Ok, not really. Massive hop aroma ... definitely getting a touch of the mango, citrusy and floral hop, seems to me. Flavor is enjoyably hop-heavy with a touch of alcohol warmth and a lightly bittersweet fruitiness. Very good.

UPDATED: JAN 30, 2007 22oz Bottle @ Coles Buffalo, NY. The best DIPA to date. Where to Begin? Huge hop presence in both aroma & flavor. Alcohol well hidden in very well balanced brew. Why cant we get this in New York?

Very good IPA. Definitely well-hopped with good balance between aromaticity and bittering.  Great mouth feel- thick and substantial. Potently alcoholic. I sampled this on tap at the Three Floyds brewery. Not particularly well carbonated with a thin head that dissipated rapidly and it just tastes too much of  alcohol. This is a problem with all double IPAs that I have sampled. Overall, a good IPA but a cut below others.

One of my favorite IIPAs to date. The hop profile on this beer is a bit more complex than most. Aroma is a combination of both citrusy and grassy/piney hops, but comes across quite well. Flavor is primarily citrusy, with a nice last bitter finish. Alcohol is well masked, making this a very fine brew indeed.

22oz bottle.  Pours a cloudy dark orange; off-white head.  Huge, citrusy aroma: grapefruit and passion fruit, hints of pine.  Full, chewy mouthfeel: plenty of citrus hops (grapefruit and lemon), nice malt backbone (maple syrup, especially) to balance things out; alcohol is well-hidden.  Long, slightly bitter finish, showing citrus and floral hops.

Good double IPA, but not my favorite. Its strength is its complexity. Aroma and taste hard to pinpoint simply because there are so many elements coming together at once. Very fruity and hoppy with nice color. Hides the alcohol well but Im just not sold on the taste compared to some other imperials.

Tap from brewpub.   Pour is coppery color with a nice large rocky off white head.   Aroma is second to none, as advertised, peach, mango, grapefruit, pine, phenominal.   Taste is extrordinary, grapefruit, sliced peaches, chunks of mango, pine needles, orange wedges.   Palate is medium bodied, stcky, no burn from the 9.5%, its well hidden.   This is special.
Very nice citric flavour.  Strong grass flavour  with pleasant malty balance.  Great IPA, but not the best.

This is a great beer.  Full of character and flavor.  Great body on this one.  If this beer was a woman Id ..... well you know.
100 IBUs.... are they nutz?  nowhere near that bitter.  The technical limit for IBUs is around 80, others have tried to surpass this number but there is no real gauge after 80 IBUs when it comes to taste threshold.

id put this one at around 40

Pours a hazy orange color with white head.  A wonderful hop aroma, bitter grapefruit aroma.  Nice malts that balance this beautiful grapefruit, grassy, bitter hop finish.  Great mouthfeel for such a hoppy IIPA.  Without a doubt the best IIPA I have ever had.

UPDATED: AUG 19, 2008 Almost clear orange body with a very small white head.  Aroma is intensely citrusy with some pine-tree juice notes.  Smooth yet very full bodied.  Over-the-top hopping that somehow manages to never be aggressive.  Medium extra-flavourfull bitterness.  Mostly citrusy with some grapefruit and piney flavours.  Alcohol is well hidden.  Very very classy.  Im not sure why I gave it only a 4.5 on my first tasting.  Now Im going with the flow and rating it as my top IIPA.  Dreadnaught not dreadful.
cloudy, unfiltered body with huge hops in the nose, bot too bitter in the taste.  the flavor really comes out if you let it sit on the tip and sides of your tongue.  Great double IPA

Pours a slighly cloudy amber/copper with a thick hite head.  Crazy aroma of citrus, pine, peach.  Aroma overpowers the flavor, it was good, but I was expecting more based on the aroma.  Great resiny mouthfeel and a lasting bitterness in the finish.  Pretty good, I think my bottle was a little old, I would love to try a fresh one.
user_location: The Land of Milk and Honey, Ohio, USA

text: Well here it is a little something special for my 100th rating. I knew this was gonna be good when i opened the bottle and the smell of hops hit the air. Pours a nice orange with a thin off white head. Smells of grapfruit and pine, awesome smell. Taste is strong grapefruit followed by a touch of sweetness (which was nice) that is eventually powered out by the hops. The beer was great it has a thick and oily mouthfeel more thick than any other IPA or IIPA Ive ever had. Man I wish I could get this more easily. Thanks to Jason (boboski) for the trade.

I have one of these with a friend about once a month. Of coarse I split a bomber but we usually end up drinking 2 after the first one. Kick ass beer! This is a highly rated beer for good reason.First off is the very clean citrus aroma. Pours a cloudy copper with a small head. This beer taste like a fresh grapefruit with sweet honey overtones and hops. Carbonation is dead on perfect!

UPDATED: JUN 2, 2007 Cloudy amber color. Thick mouth feel. Bitterness is matched perfectly with malt sweetness. Alcohol well hidden. Expensive! Paid almost $11/ 22oz. bottle for special order in Terre Haute IN only 125 miles from brewery!

[Almost 2 years old bottle]
Dark amber colour. Rich aroma, smooth and malty. Hops are gone of course. Slight madeira here, and almond paste. Good fruity also in aroma. Smooth mouthfeel, with a thick, burning fieriness(?!?!?!) and a great deal of bitterness still, almost salty with exotic fruits. Bit sweet plus orange-like,with peppery bitterness. Overly thick. No backup from flavouring hops. Gotta try this fresh one day.
Bottle: Pours a nice amber color with a small white head. Smells very nice, with citrus and pine. Taste is very earthy. Its got a nice hoppiness, earthy and piney. This beer is good.

Grapefruit and oranges dominate the aroma.Pours a clear gold with foamy off white head.Very sweet and malty mixed well with hops.Palate is thick and oily.Very sweet at first then finishes with a lasting hop bitterness.

UPDATED: NOV 15, 2006 22 oz bottle via beerswap 2.0 (thanks!). This pours a hazy amber with a small white head. Nose is mostly citrus grapefruit hops, some vanilla, some toastiness, and some caramel malts. Taste starts with some sweet orange, then some grapefruit, some caramel, a litlle resiny pine and ends in some orange hops. Full bodied. A bit syrupy. A slight alcohol finish/aftertaste. Pretty tastey.

Thanks to Sliffy for this gem. A great one for my 200th rating. Pours a medium amber with a nice white head. Nice carbonation and lacing.  Aroma is of big hops and pine. Flavor is piney and hoppy with a dry finish. What a treat this was. Thanks again Sliffy!!!!!!

Bottled. Beer is clear, medium warm brown with a small, frothy, white, mostly diminishing head. Some seagulls of lacing holding to the glass.

Wall of hops hit the nose. The aroma is heavy with massive notes of grapefruit, pointed heavy notes of pine, moderate note of resin, light rosemaryish herb; Balanced out a little with large, soft, sweet malty notes of toasted grain, cookie and caramel; Yeasty with a light note of dough; Light miscellaneous note of alcohol. Very hop-centric, but pretty.

The flavor is moderately-to-heavily bitter, heavily sweet, moderately acidic with a long, heavy, sugary sweet, lightly bitter, lightly acidic and astringent finish. Grip hangs on. Alcohol is well tucked away.

The body is full, the texture is velvety and the carbonation is lively.

Bottle.  Utterly massive grapefruit nose noticeable from cap removal, sweet and fruity with hoppy hints of resin and pine.  Beautiful amber orange body, but all traces of head are gone after about three seconds.  Delicious hopbitter taste; very bitter, all the way through, but hoppy-sticky and certainly bearable.  Hops, hops, hops.  Pine, touch of flowers, citrus, and light alcohol.  Monstrously thick body, not so much oily as undiluted essence of hop.  Very dry, long finish.  Amazingly, I taste something like 40-50 IBUs instead of 100 [a Jever tastes bitterer], and the beer has a unique rounded character - its something greater than merely its ingredients - a truly original synthesis.  This is artistic, cultivated hop juice, a sort of legendary ambrosia, the object of doubting whispers and blissful, neverending dreams. Its not as complex as, say, an Andechser, but it is a masterful creation, and it may very well be the best of its style.

UPDATED: NOV 11, 2006 Bottle, sersdf bought my undying loyalty with this one.  Light brownish honey color with a fine white head.  Nose is very nice, and not overly hoppy, despite having huge hops.  That said, aroma is grassy, with a sticky, piney, resiny sweetness to it, great citrus and floral notes, just really well done.  Tart peachs, maybe even some raspberry in there, little bit of alcohol.  Great flavor too.  Massively appealing bitterness, grapefruit, alcohol.  Sweet up front, giving way to a smooth, slightly warming, hopped finish.  Nice palate, good carbonation, medium body.  This is definitely one of the best IIPAs Ive had.  Im not sure Id say it was better that the Summer Yulesmith, but definitely on par.  This is a monster, I love it.
GABF-on tap-pours a light tan head with hazy amber color.  Aroma is citrus.  Taste is nice, not too overpowering.

Nice aroma, appearance, and great taste. The hoppiness you expect from a double IPA, with a lot more malt than you find in others of the style. The balance hides the alcohol well. Full but smooth, this was excellent.

first off i have to say i had this at the brewery a week before i had it in the bottle to rate it.   aroma pine and passionfruit (draught mango and peach as they say no doubt) and some malt.  Flavor is much the with a biscuity malt sweetness.  it finished  quite dry and is drinkable.  in bottle it is good but not amazing.  with that said at three floyds  the aroma was amazing.   it drank creamy and smooth with beautifully delicate malting which paired almost perfectly with interesting hopping.  on draught this beer is easily the best ive had and is 5.  but to be fair to the other dipas ive had i have to count in the experience with the bottle which was lack luster (probably due to what i expected from what i had at brewery).

Beautiful Double IPA, all of the big hop flavors youd expect (lots of fruit, and some pine) with a big helping of malt to smooth it out and make it more drinkable. That big ABV is fairly well hidden too. Even though it was fantastic, I might have expected more from all of the hype. There wasnt really anything here that I havent seen before in a double IPA; it was just put together better than the others.

I can certianly appreciate the complexities of a good intense IIPA.  However, after so much of the hype that came with this "king of all IIPAs", there was bound to be a let down not matter how much I tried to temper my enthusiasm.  Nice deep dark amber hue.  Aroma of varying complexity detailing the use of several native and imported hop varieties.  However, a slight dampness to it.  The poor malt character is beat-up and abused with this one to the point of being taken out of balance to compliment the complexities of the hops.  The palate is sharp, grapefruity and citrus.  However, not near what the aroma would have led me to believe.  Well out of balance and very disappointed.  I will consider this a fluke until I have the opportunity to re-rate this highly acclaimed brew again.

UPDATED: JUN 26, 2009 Oct 30, 2006
A very complex DIPA.  There is a lot of citrus and passion fruit in with the piney hops finish of the beer.  Very well balanced and no noticeable initial heat.  This is nearly a perfect DIPA.  And while there is no initial alcohol taste, the overwhelmingly fantastic hop aroma belies a slight alcohol note which is not at all unpleasant in the finish.
----re-rate- Aug 1, 2008
Wow, still amazing.

22 oz. bottle.  Dark orange-brown color with a thin tan head.  Everything about this beer is big: big floral/fruity aroma and a big bittersweet citrus flavor up front.  A nice bit of malt to balance it out with the hops reasserting themselves in a big long finish.  Nice carbonation and a full bodied, creamy palate.  This one lives up to the hype.  One of the best beers Ive had.

I was really dying to try this, but was underwhelmed, unfortunately.  Interesting dark orange with an aroma of pine, citrus (especially orange) and alcohol.  The head is very small with almost no lacing.  The tase is bitter but I cant say anything else interesting about it.  There isnt a lot of carbonation and it almost tastes flat to me.  I actually (gulp) poured out some of the first bomber because I though it might be bad.  But alas, the second tasted the same.  Just doesnt do anything for me.

CONTAINER VOLUME: 22 ozCONTAINER TYPE: bottle (conditioned)FRESH: pretty surePURCHASED @: binnyCOST: $10HEAD: thin yellow sheen

LACE: ringsCOLOR: hazy amberAROMA: floral hopsMOUTHFEEL: medium/thick foamy

PALATE: resin moving to oily then slickTASTE: slight carb. sting; woody bitternessCOMMENTS: beautiful bitterness. the best IIPA Ive tried so far.  This is a wonderful nectar.  the only slam Ive seen against this beer is that its not deep; its just in your face.  Well, duh, its an Imperial...you have to respect anyone who can brew a beer this big and still have consuming it be a plesant experience...CONDITIONS:MOWING/WORKING ON CAR- 

yWITH FRIENDS- ySIPPING- yGET MY BUZZ ON-y

UPDATED: DEC 19, 2006 Pretty good.  Definitely indicative of the style, but I failed to find too much in it that made it as special as it came across.  A little maltier than I prefer in a double, but not a bad beer by any means.

beautiful deep orange color, small head that goes away pretty quickly.  Floral notes in the smelll, light citrus and grapefruit hops that also come through in taste.. pretty bitter, but a great blend of everything.  Full bodied with a smooth creamy texture.  Definitely a winner.

UPDATED: JAN 17, 2007 i had a very fresh bottle last weekend very nice hoppy taste 100 ibus! can not taste the alcohol and is very citrusy i love the three floyds brew and so far this is the best out of four that i have tried awsome double ipa bring on the russians!!  rerate had alot of the rest and this is the best! still have a couple of tops left but this is definetly one of the best beers in the world and would be a perfect score but needs a little bit more head and lacing other than that it is a perfect beer!
Shared bomber bottle Drafting Room in Exton. Great beer. Great balance of everything. Just a tad to florally for me.

UPDATED: AUG 29, 2014 First ratingThis particular bottle has been stored for at least one year, seems it didnt do it good though. Others that has tasted it fresh and also this bottle reflects it has lost lots of what makes it great. So this rating is in regard to an "old" bottle, probably too old. 650 ml bottle Shady orange color, white head. A bit hoppy, some citrus and chocolate. Fruity scent. Thick mouthfeel. Very sweet and strong taste, lots of Madeira. High bitterness, warming feeling of alcohol. Bitter aftertaste. The bitterness isnt sharp, but heavy.7/4/7/4/13=3.5RerateDraught at Mikkeller bar, Copenhagen, on May 8, 2010Hazy golden color, small white head. Hoppy apricot scent. Hoppy, bitter, mango taste, also sweet. Warming alcohol. Medium mouthfeel, high bitterness.8/3/8/3/16=3.8RerateBottle thanks to Knä (non-ratebeer), sampled in Ludvika on August 25, 2014.Light hazy golden coloer, white head. Sweet, caramel, white pepper scent. Bitter, hoppy, caramel, dandelion taste. Bitter, citrus zest aftertaste. Fizzy mouthfeel, high bitterness.7/3/7/2/13=3.2
22 oz bomber.  A bright orange color with a large head.  Intense citrus aroma assaults your nose.  Very hoppy but well balance with an intense malt character.  A great example of the style.

22 oz bottle - 500th rating.  Pours a mostly clear orange with a big fluffy head.  It has a very inviting grapefruit and hops aroma.  The first sip is very hoppy, then as one gets use to it, the hops is still strong, but citrus flavors and big malts to balance it become apparent.  Its lightly carbonated and has a nice full body.  The finish is long and crisp, those tastey hops hanging around for awhile.  This is a really great beer.

Bomber split with after4ever. Pours a brilliant orange with a fluffy pale orange head. Sweet citrus nose. This is a big beer with a full body, soft carbonation and a malt-sweetened taste laced with hoppy goodness. Surprisingly quick finish. If theres 100 IBUs in here, where are they hiding?

Bomber--thanks, BeachBum25! Pours an almost neon orange; easily the most remarkable color Ive seen in a beer. Towering off white head, decent lace. Enormous sweet sticky citric fruity nose. The attack and the mid-palate are almost roastily bitter with resinous hop. This seems to have every conceivable hop category mized into one: citric, piney, resinous, even bits and pieces of herb and spice. No earth, so I guess you cant say its the esperanto of hopping, but its pretty close. Malts there, kind of the silent partner. Great stuff, but that first wallop of flavors a doozy. Impossible to prepare yourself for.
GABF 06.  This one lived up to the hype.  Aroma is pineapple, citrus, and malt.  Taste is sweet citrus like flavors with a nice full bitterness that gets strong near the back of the palate.

UPDATED: JUL 14, 2009 There is no reason for me to tell you what this beer tasted like.  629 people have told you before me.  This beer is the great.  It is very hoppy and crisp.  The bottle i drank was a year old.  I would imagine a fresh bottle would blow your head off.  Outstanding IIPA.
UPDATED: DEC 27, 2006 Its like Alpha King on Steroids. I paid 10$ a 24oz bottle. Its really good, but its a little sweet. Its a bit overhyped.

UPDATED: DEC 11, 2006 Bomber. Holy schnikes!! Gadzooks, this is simply insane beer. I have had ALOT of IPA and DIPA in the last few years, this is in the top 3. I paid big bucks (15) for a bottle since its not easily available here in my area.  This is a great blend of the hoppy/bitter IPAs and the more fruit forward IPA versions, best of both worlds. It is easy to see why this is continually ranked as best. If this Imperial was easily available here, I would be in huge trouble. I....must.....find.....more....please!!

UPDATED: OCT 13, 2007 Now that Ive come back from the GABF floor and reviewed the comments on the beers that I tasted I feel vindicated mostly.  These blind tastings concluded with a confirmation from the accumulated RateBeer community on my thoughts, except for the Dreadnaught.  I knew Three Floyds was an important brewery to hit, and I knew theyre beers were going to be good, but I didnt know which ones were going to be the epic beers Ive heard stories about.  Thus, when I sampled the Dreadnaught I found it to be an acceptably good beer.  But now that Ive come back to the community and checked my word against everyone elses I feel like a fool.  I had no idea it was the God beer, the IPA that drinkers should prostrate before.  I sense that there are small shrines scattered around the country in homes and on roadsides dedicated to this hopped up beer.  If Im ever going to take a stand, though, and really rally against the crowd then I want to do it here.  The smell is vivid  pine resin, flowers and a general aroma that smacks of the Rocky Mountains in a way that only a traveler to the little rocky villas ensconced in the craggy pock marks of the mountains could understand.  This, paired with its bucolic semi-translucent marigold color topped with an orange blossom head projects a beautiful natural air.  But the Dreadnaughts taste is less enchanting.  It starts strong and savory, with a triad wheat, biscuit and oats and then mixes into a grapefruit sweetness which is unlike anything Ive had save for the Alpha King.  It makes for an intriguing mix of the bready IPAs and the bitter grapefruity IPAs and something I enjoy a lot.  But besides these qualities it seems to lack an edge of sophistry that would make it a legend in my heart.  It is, still, an altogether admirable beer and deserves the praise it receives  but not the worship.

22 oz Bottle:  The grapefruit and peach aromas hit you as soon as the bottle is opened.  Pours a thick, full bodied, orange color with a thin head.  Saying that the fruit flavors are intense is an understatement.  There is a sweet cascade hop start and a slightly bitter finish.  9.5% alcohol is unnoticeable; it feels like 5% at the most.  Citrus aftertaste stays with you forever.  Im not that into IPAs but I certainly appreciate the complexity of this masterpiece.

22 oz bottle.  I waited for a month to share this with a fellow beer taster - the anticipation was killing me.  This was very, very good but not my favorite IPA.  The color and appearance were as nice as Ive ever seen.  Aroma was citrus, alcohol and pine - taste followed accordingly.  Taste had a distinguishing malt characteristic as well.  Heavy IPA.  Very smooth and balanced. 3Floyds is an excellent brewery.  Must try this if you can find it.

bottle.  hazy copper pour with thin head. floral hops, citrus, toasted malt aroma.  nice carbonation.  citrus hops rounded out with caramel malts.  nice alcohol warming, but alcohol is hidden well.  huge pink grapefruit citrus taste.  please distribute out west.

If FFF were a band, they would play exclusively theatrical power ballads. This beer is no exception to the traditionally aggressive brewing FFF employs, and is a fine example of their craft wIth its loads of well proportioned hoppy-maltiness.

Bottle.  I usually hate 2IPAs but this was awsome.  Massive amounts of both hops and malt that are amazingly in balance.  I dont think I could have more than a pint of this at one sitting,  but it is an amazing beer.  Reminds me of a small batch bourbon.  Loads of flavor, but a ton of alcohol.

Bottle.  Pours a somewhat hazy light amber with not much of a head.  Nose is summer fruits and floral hops.  Thick and creamy, this is a very nice 2IPA.  Good balance of malts and hops and although the hops are totally present, they are pretty sucessfully staved off by the malts.  Ripe, carmelized apricot and peach flavors mingle with rest in this brew. I had this on tap a few years ago and loved it.  However, this was not as good as my recollection of that but still a very,  very solid 2IPA.  Thanks to jjpm74 for this bottle.

This beer pours a light orangish peach with some slight shades of brown. The head is a buttery light yellow egg shell film that left some very attractive strands of lace.

Smells like a walk through a pine forest after the rain. Theres also a little mandarin orange here as well. The fresh hops oozing out of this one really have my attention.

The flavor really caught me off guard. I was expecting a big hop punch in the mouth like Alpha King, but instead, I get a sublime doughy oats and honey malt that transitions into a crisp pine bough dryness that rides on top of the malt. There are also some sweet hints of oranges and peaches along the sides of my tongue. The bitterness of the hops in the finish is effortlessly blended into a toasted oat with a touch of fruity sweetness that lingers on a little too long. 

The mouth feel is silky smooth and a little heavy with a great micro carbonation that gives this beer an terrific body.

Im diggin this one. The smell is organic and fresh, the taste is subtle and supreme, and the mouth feel is right on. 9.5%? I wouldnt have believed it had I not seen in on the site. Im glad I caught that. Now I can try to pace out this bomber!

What a lovely beverage. An expensive $11 or $12 whenever you can find it in southern Indiana, but well worth the price of admission. Appearance is attractive, but not awe inspiring. Clear amber body is topped by a small, but sturdy, vanilla head. Sparse, patchy lacing is left on the glass. Aroma cranks up the experience a few notches. Incredible, citrusy, hops jump into your nasal passages. Freshly sliced, orange and green lime open into esters of pink grapefruit and tangerine. Sublime! Full and tantalizing in the mouth. Carbonation is lively, but unobtrusive. Taste is bittersweet, citrusy, hops, similar to the luscious aroma. Lime, orange zest, and a fleeting, caramel and honey sweetness play along together like three year old cousins in a sandbox. Hops finish things off as a polite assasin. Geeeez.., this is an impressive "beer". An American classic! From my many years of experience, only some of the aged, Plinys from Russian River Brewing in Sonoma, can aspire to such a lofty perch as the Dreadnaught.

I love double IPS. However, I may have gotten a bad bottle or something. This beer had a weird funk malt flavor and no hop aroma at all. How could a double IPA go bad? Arent all the hops supposed to keep this from happening?

22oz bottle from 1FastSTi. This hazy orange ale poured with a short off-white head, eliciting a floral, malty aroma. The initial taste is fruity and slightly sweet, but quickly achieves a robust bitterness. Now the sheer volume of hops should create an overwhelming bitterness, but somehow, the flavor remains balanced and tasty, and conceals the high alcohol content. This is a well-crafted beer which is a pleasure to drink.

22 oz bottle. Pours a nice light orange color with a small white head. Aroma of pine resin and hops. I was overwhelmed by the piney scent and taste. Not a bad beer but the hop flavor was just a bit over the top for me. This just isnt my type.

UPDATED: DEC 2, 2006 Bottle.  OMG what an awsome beer.  I didnt know what to expect at first, but this is just wonderful.  Pours a beautiful apricot orange with a small amber head.  Taste of cardemom, apricot and citrus.  This beer is freaking the best Ive tried in a long time.

I get this as a gift. But nots my style, or bad bottle?  Orange pour with a fluffy white head. You can smell this brew from the second you open it. Pungent centenial hops hit your nose with great force. Massive bitterness with enough malt. -

Pours a moderate head which reduced itself to lacing in about 5 minutes or so.  Color is a semi-cloudy burnt orange.  Aroma really knocks me out!  Grapefruit and a potpourri-like smell simply hit you in the face, repeatedly.  One of the few beers that I can still smell easily right after Ive taken a sip (for me, thats tough to do.  Anyway, the flavor has those characteristics, with a touch of salt hitting the front of the tongue, a light bread-like malt providing some upfront sweetness.  Some light roast flavors hit the sides of my mouth, but really, this is grapefruit piney hop goodness all the way.  Dry finish never leaves either.  All of the flavors work together in this beer, which makes it about as pleasing as IIPAs can be.  Well, shy of being Dogfish Heads 120 anyway :)  Excellently balanced extreme beer.

Bottle. Aroma is very hoppy, floral with traces of grapefruit.  Golden color, Very hoppy taste, with a hint of caramel.  Every taste im dreading the bottom of the glass.  What a well balanced, awesome dipa.  Hope to have more soon

Bottle. Pours a golden hue with a nice white head on top, looks very refreshing and excellent. Aroma is hops, grapefruit, pine, reisen, and malt. Smells amazing. Flavor is amazing, hoppy from start to finish with malts sneaking in to smooth it out. Tasting grapefruit, floral hops, pine, and caramel. This beer definitely lives up to its reputation. One of the best Double IPAs I have tasted. I want more!

Clear golden pour with an averaged sized eggshell white head.  Pine and floral hop aroma with underlying malt sweetness.  Bittering and sweet taste up front, very active hop presence, thick and resinous.  Citrus hops into the middle and a warming alcohol begins to creep in.  Probably the hoppiest, yet balanced beer Ive ever had.  Could be the poster child of a double. IPA.  Quite interesting.

Rating #100, 22oz bottle poured hazy pale/orange with a nice size off white head. The aroma jumps out at you with pine, citrus, grapefruit, sweet malt and alcohol. Now I know why this is #1 wow the taste is big and bitter with a wonderful malt balance and a slight warming from the alcohol. The aroma really sets this beer apart from others, I dont think any other bottled beer has such an intense aroma. It reminds me of a triple Alpha King. Spectacular.

UPDATED: DEC 6, 2006 Thanks to Beerdrenched for picking this beer up for me.  Pours hazy dark orange / brown with a nice white head.  Lots of floral and citric hops on the aroma that are balanced by a good amount of caramel malt.  Medium to full bodied with a good amount of soft carbonation.  Taste has an even blend of the hops and malt mentioned earlier.  The malt tasted a bit musty - could be due to age, I have no idea how long this has been sitting around.  The finish gets a bit spicer.  This was a very good beer, but I think this was a bit aged.  I will have to rerate if I get a fresh bottle.
RERATE NOTES 12/6/06 - Much fresher this time.  More of a clean hopfest on the aroma, but still has good balance considering the hops included.  Much more resiny on this sample.  Flavor starts with floral / perfume / grapefruit malt blend with good balance and none of the mustiness.  The finish has grapefruit and pine with the floral playing a supporting role.  Just a boatload of resin on the finish.  Much better fresh!!!

A great warmup for the lupulin flogging Im going to get in my upcoming trip to the west coast...Thanks to whoever brought this at Tiggmtls farewell tasting!

Lovely pale maple blonde, and perfectly translucent.  Pretty nice head on it as well.

Wa-Zooey!  Sticky sweet hops, its like shrinking down to nanometer size and having a coamping trip on a hop bud floating on a shotglass full of honey.  It had a few alcoholic vapors that gave some fusels but without stealing the thunder of the star of the show.

Just barely enough malt to give a half second of opposition to the massive onslaught of hops.  A quick glance at the dictionnary gives the definition of Dreadnaught as a kind of battleship with really big guns.  Well, my tongue and all taste receptors therein waved the white flag of surrender, as it shriveled up and dried out.  Very long and leafy, green aftertaste.  Unbalanced?  Maybe, but every once and a while, its good to throw a spanner in the works!

Pours a amber color with a medium bubbly head. Aroma is layer on layer of differing hop... pine, citris, flowers and alcohol. Flavor is solidly hoppy although you know that there is a stiff backbone of malt there. heavy bodied yet quite dry in the finish. This is definatly one I will have to try again. Tasted so good it was gone before I had managed to decipher all of the aromas and flavors. Outstanding beer.

22-oz. bottle from tjthresh, shared with chadzter.  Pours amber with a tiny fizzy off-white head, slight spotty lacing.  Aroma is sweet candied citrus hops, fragrant floral and fruity hops follow, caramel nutty malt (cookie, straw), yeast (grassy), pine hop and alcohol nose; a very inviting aroma.  Medium acidity and bitterness, malt and hop flavor, caramel, candied hops, spicy citrus and pine, alcohol at the end.  Full bodied and creamy yet spicy and dry palate.

UPDATED: JAN 21, 2007 I will preface this by saying it is possible that I may have drank an old bottle.  I was expecting a massive hop bomb, but what I tasted was another malty, syrupy brew that seems very overrated.   What a let down......Dont get me wrong, this is not a bad beer per se, but its hardly a beer that deserves a 100 rating.   Im just too spoiled.....this did not taste very hoppy to me......Give me a Pliny over this any day...



UPDATE 1/20/07:  After trying this one now several times, I have come to realize..........This beer is very very unpredictable.   This beer must must be fresh.  And, it seems, for whatever reason, it loses its freshness pretty quickly.  Anyway, I bumped my rating up.  The first time I had it, it was a 3.6.  Today, I would rate it a 4.0.

Poured from 22oz. bottle.  Nice dark golden hue, with a nice thin white head.  Sweet floral hop aroma.  Intense hop flavor which is very well balanced.  Fruity, with a bitterness on the finish.  Definately lives up to the reputation.

Even toned copper color with only the tiniest bit of white head off to one side, this liquid has a wonderful floral aroma. Nicely sweet tealike flavor leads, and finish contains an alcohol hop bite.  $13/22oz

UPDATED: DEC 16, 2007 22 oz bomber.  For my 100th rating I had to do something special, and 3 Floyds Dreadnaught seems appropriate - the top D/IIPA.  Bought a case of 12 of these for $89 and I think its well worth the money.  Nice hazy copper pour.  Absolutely wonderful hoppy aroma that makes you salivate.  Absolutely the best balanced IPA (or DIIPA) Around.  Smooth malts balance with finely hopped wonderfulness that explains why this is head and shoulders above the rest.  Very nice hop profile (Simcoe definately included, but not sure how much) that makes you want more.  Wow.  Finish and aftertaste very pleasant.  Its rare that Ill drink a bomber this fast, and thats only because its THAT good.  Lives up to the hype and then some!!!!!
UPDATED: NOV 17, 2006 Pours an orange/amber with a medium off white/yellow head.  Huge floral hop aroma with some orange citris in there.  Mouthfeel is thick with a sweet malt and big citris hops.

UPDATED: JUL 22, 2008 Pours a nice amber with medium head and some lacing. Nice strong aroma of orange and floral hops. Great palate and the flavor is great as well, nice sweetness and finishes with a nice bitterness. Beautiful.

Picked this baby up recently at Stateline in MD for $8.99. What an absolutely delicious, mouth-watering DIPA! Pours a bright amber-orange color. Produces a thin, 1/4" head which fades to a thin wispy coating. Beautiful, rich, sweet fruity aromas of oranges, pineapple, grapefruit, peach, pine needles and caramel fill the nose. The hop aroma profile in this beer is simply incredible. Mouthfeel is moderately full, but silky smooth and a perfect subdued carbonation level. The flavor would in my estimation be pretty tough to surpass. Perfect balance here between the hops and malt. Starts sweet with notes of caramel candy, toasted malts, and apricot. The hops then kick in with avengence showing off flavors of pink grapefruit, orange, pine resin, flowers and herbs. Finishes with a stout, assertive hop bitterness which is followed by a mild alcoholic warmth. Just a beautiful, classy brew.

UPDATED: JUL 8, 2007 Bomber. Picked this up at the Three Floyds Brewpub. Pours an orange/copper color. Looks very clear to me. Thin off-white head that quickly dissipates. Aroma is a beautiful mixture of sweet tangerine, floral hops, and grapefruit. This has to be experienced firsthand. Flavor is orange citrus and fruits, with massive hops in the finish, so strong it actually lingers as I type this, just as it did immediately after the taste. I actually got chills drinking this fine brew.

UPDATED: JUN 30, 2007 Rerate after having this on draft and having a bottle I know was fresh. Hazy orange with a moderate head, decent lacing and retention. Boring and just like most other IIPAs. Aroma is tropical fruits, grapefruit, pine, floral, etc etc so much is here. Caramel backing is there too. Medium to heavy body with a bitter finish with a small amount of alcohol. I found the alcohol helped the bitterness and made this nearly flawless. Its not the biggest in any way, but its possibly the best balanced. It also has some interesting hop flavors. Love this stuff...

UPDATED: APR 6, 2007 8/09/2006: Tasted with OhioGuzzler...  After everything I kept hearing and reading, I just had to go out and get a bottle of this.  This is an amazing IPA.  It is like drinking an excellent IPA with more alcohol and flavor perfectly blended in.  It is vibrant orande in color and has a wonderful orange and floral hop aroma.  Moderate carbonation.  The flavor is amazing with a perfect blend of sweet, orange, apricot, peach, and hops.  A nice hop finish with the perfect balance of bitterness.  You absolutely must try this beer.  If you can find a better IIPA, please let me know as I would love to try it - I dont think anything can beat this one!  22 oz bottle, $8.99+tax from Dilly Deli.
4/02/2007:  I had a couple pints of Dreadnaught on draught at Fries Cafe (Cincinnati, Ohio) during the Bells Oberon Release Party...  This stuff is killer:  Sweet, sticky, and lots of hop flavor and bitterness.  Rich, full-flavored, precisely balanced, and full and creamy on the palate.  Insanely good and great deal at only $5/pint (cheaper than buying a bottle)!

Not since your moms teet have you tasted mothers milk like this.  Smells sweet, slightly like flowers blowing in a citrus breeze.  The the taste is an incredibly well balanced array of malt hops and an orange like sweetness that lingers till the early morn.  Three floyds hit this nail on the head.  Id almost suggest you dont drink it, because it will alter your perception of Imperial IPAs forever.
While there might be a better beer out there, this beer is the best I have ever had.   Sure wish I could find it someplace near Connecticut!

Incredible... usually dobles are way to oily and resiny for me, light bitting into hop pellets and with no complexities. This one definatly deserves its top place of its style. Beautiful aroma of flowery hops, dried fruits and malts. Flavor is semisweet and verry hoppy but with a large amount of malts balancing it out, some lemon and oranges and a hint of dried apples. The pallat is smooth as silk and finishes crisp and refreshing with a nice bitterness and sweetnes lingering for ages. Thanks to Drewbeerme for the trade.
Fantastic IIPA -- this one is the hype.  Huge floral nose and deep long bitter and balanced taste.  This basically seems to be what an IIPA should be.

22 oz bomber-Pours an orange cloudy color w/a small off white head-kind of looks like a wheat. Nice crisp hoppy aroma. Somewhat fruity. Definite sweet, hoppy flavor-but not overwelmingly so. Long bitter finish. Much more balance than a lot of IPAs. Bought a couple of these w/an eye on trading as Im not an IPA fan but just couldnt pass up a chance to try one of the top ten beers in the world. Glad I didnt-I would have this again!

Pours an unimpressive warm orange to gold with a loose white head, thinning quickly and bubbles streaming to the top.  The nose is much more impressive.  Big juicy american hops.  Grapefruit seeds, pine, and a big sweet light malt backbone.  Theres a little bit of soap.  Alcohol present, but not overwhelming, and actually lends something to the flavor.  Reminds me very much of Troegs Nugget Nectar.  Really one of my favorite aromas.  Light on the palate, the mouthfeel is smooth and silky, with low carbonation, a bit of syrupy thickness, and some alcohol warming, but hardly any.  The flavors are outstanding, though perhaps not as succulent as the aroma.  Big sweet malt hits me first, with a heathy bit of citrus rind bitterness and a subdued bubblegum note.  Light papaya eminates from the combo of the hops and malt.  The lingering bitterness is grapefruit seeds all the way.  Theres not a lot of complexity here, this beer is clear and to the point, not to mention delicious.  Not as big a beer as I had hoped, but very impressive never the less.

A translucent pinkish color with a small white head and very bubbly.  I give it a four just because I think the color is really nice, but the rest of the appearance isnt exactly appealing.  This smells hoppy and citrusy (oranges, lemons and grapefruit), with some other fruits (like apples) coming through a bit, and a general sugary sweetness.  Similar in taste, with the citrus fruits, floral notes, candy, and just a whole lot of  hops, along with alcohol.  A strong bitter finish.

UPDATED: DEC 22, 2006 A Florida orange grove wafts into my nostrils, with a touch of flammable alcohol. The glass around the cap of this bottle broke as I opened it - never had that happen before!  Murky orange-amber beer with unusual big, clear bubbles that migrate to the rim and fade fast.  Orange-grapefruit hoppy with a unique tea note.  Extremely smooth and round, not highly bitter or hot-alcoholic, refined.   Sweet, with a few summer fruits entering the picture.  Given the ay the cap came off, the total lack of carbonation, and the apparently lesser intensity of the flavor, Im guessing this bottle was a bit abnormal and under par, but still can taste the quality of it.

Have since had this on tap in Indiana bars.  High wuality, extremely oranged, full of flavor and a very smooth palate, barely tastes like alcohol, very easygoing for a double IPA.  Quality beer.

Bottle from a store in Crystal Lake, IL.   I wonder what happened to the two teenagers having sex behind the counter...   Pours a deep, mysterious and seductive amber.  A slow forming head appears as the liquid enters the drinking receptacle.  Aroma is a pine forest with an orange grove intertwined among the plants.  Nice harmony of bitter and sour aromas.  Flavor is a thick, sugary yet bitter pine with just enough grapefruit and orange to keep things flowing toward the sour side.  There is a strawberry or two in here, maybe even a bit of peach.  Palate is about as coating as it gets, and it leaves the flavors to stir on the taste buds.   Ive been wanting this one for awhile, and it certainly was worth the wait.  Must... have... more!
user_location: Ugly, Hot, and Humid Spring, Texas, USA

text:
This is the end all be all of imperial ipas in my book!  This beer eluded me for quite some time.  I even drove 5 1/2 hours to the brewery to buy some of it, and when I got there they said they were bottling it the very next day (I was on a business trip of sorts so I couldnt stay to wait).  But after such disheartening news, the bartender told me they had it on tap.  So I got to try it for the first time ever on tap...and it was GREAT!  As soon as I arrived back home from my trip I placed an order to buy a case of the dreadnaught, and the day it showed up on my porch was like a kid in a candy store.  Sorry to fall off track but...
The aroma and taste are both jam packed with floral notes, grapefruits, apricots, and even mangos.  This stuff was phenomenal!

UPDATED: JAN 27, 2008 22 oz. bottle. Slightly hazy orange pour underneath a medium off white head that persisted for several minutes. Huge hop aroma that is dominated by pine and citrus, but with a little floral character as well. Underneath, if you take the time you can detect some malt based aromas of light caramel. Medium full mouthfeel with a bit of a resinous quality as I would expect after being hit over the head with the hop aromas. There is a flash of malty sweetness before the hops hit, and the hit is substantial with grapefruit, pine, lemon peel, etc. The finish is long and bitter, but not overly so, at least for me. Ive been waiting to get my hands on one of these, and I wasnt disappointed.

UPDATED: MAY 8, 2008 bottle. Cloudy bright orange/red pour with a foamy white head. Swirling the snifter reveals filmy and clingy lacing. The aroma is so intense. It doesnt take much effort more than breathing near the beer to pick up deep grapefruit, bright flowers, sweet caramel. Its very complex and pleasing, like standing in an orchard. Drinking it is much less serene. Its like a punch in the mouth. The biting citrus acidity courses long after one small sip, but I mean that in the best way possible. The mouthfeel is semi-oily. Man, the hops burn the whole palate down into the throat. Im fairly certain thats not alcohol burn, but rather the sheer spiciness eminating from this hop bomb. There is indeed plenty of malt presence to balance this beast, but I would not describe this as a sweet brew. The finish finally brings out subtle notes of peaches, grapes, biscuits, but it takes some time to get there past the onslaught of zesty acidity. I drank this as a night cap and when I awoke the next morning I still had hops on my breath. This stuff is beautiful.

[May 3, 07]

 I was excited to try this one again. I have to say, it wasnt as amazing this time around. Maybe I got a bottle that wasnt as fresh. Maybe I drank this one just a little too warm. It was still delicious, but just not as ridiculous. My score reflects my first, life-changing encounter with Dreadnaught.


[May 1, 2008]

Bomber, big thanks to BossHossBikes. Man, this is an amazing double IPA. Gigantic pine, grapefruit, orange blasts my nostrils. The malts are a pathetic attempt at balance with this hop heavy beast. I get more deep citrus which even expands into some acidic territory I associate with cinnamon. This is truly an impressive IIPA. The clarity and depth are commendable. 


[May 8, 2008]

Bomber. Pours a golden hue with a fair head. The aroma is fantastic. There was a snifter of DFH 90 minute, fresh mind you, nearby so I did a little aroma comparison. Dreadnaught pwn3d. Tons of pine, grapefruit, ganja, orange, pineapple. . .the nose is very sharp, stinging, yet remarkably clean. Flavor is more of the same. Straight up hop onslaught delights my tongue with a bombardment of herbal and citrus stings. I keep wanting to describe IIPAs like this as balanced, though thats not accurate since malts are certainly secondary. Dreadnaught is one of the most solid in the style Ive sampled.

FINALLY!!  Ive been on a quest for this beer not unlike that of King Arthur and Not So Brave Sir Robins quest for the Grail.  After almost 2 years of futility, I found one lone bottle at the Foodery in Philly.  On with the review:  Mildly hazy burnt orange pour supporting a tall and rocky off-white head with a great deal of lacing.  The citrus in the aroma practically muscled its way through the bottle before I could open it!  Plenty of tangerine and grapefruit in the aroma along with a more than healthy degree of fresh hops and cut grass.  Unlike some other Impy IPAs whos flavors disappoint after big fruity aromas, this one met the challange head on.  Wonderfully fruity with more grapefruit, lightly toasted malt, huge hops and a hint of alcohol - though well cloaked.  Mouthfeel is full and creamy and the finish is sweet, bitter, long but still dry.  My expectations for this beer were probably too high but it turned out that they may not have been high enough.  This beer is outstandingly well balanced, flavorful and expertly crafted.  Stone Ruination has met its match!

Bottler. Pours copper golden with a small head. Aromas of hops fruits and flowers.
Outstanding flavors of bananas,hops, and other fruit. It was kind of buttery, really smooth without any harsh hop bitterness. Definitely high in alcohol but you could not tell. Nice and full bodied and very satisfying due to its balance of hops and malts. Definitely one of the top beers.

This is a solid brew to be sure, but has nothing compared to other great IPAs like Hercules, and Ruination. The pour was the normal yellowish color with a decent white head. The aroma was a little off in my opinion. The smells were of pine and hops. The taste just doesnt overwhelm at all! This is supposed to be a hop monster, and it just doesnt deliver. I was really let down with this beer, and I am suprised to see that it ranks so highly."

UPDATED: SEP 19, 2006 via trade with slob & jasonmech77 - Pours a clear orangish-amber color with a nice intial head.  Head quickly faded to a ring of foamy bubbles around the glass.  Very light carbonation.  Has a very strong floral, citrus aroma.  Flavor is sweet, malty, fruity and lots of hops.  A very smooth, but thick tasting full bodied beer.  This is the Mac Daddy of IPAs.  Thanks Bert & Jason.

UPDATED: AUG 7, 2006 Big ups to brewblackhole for sending me this one.  My favorite double IPA to date.  An aromatic hop explosion.  Big hop taste lacking the usual sweet sugariness that overpowers some other double IPAs.

Thanks to a trade from the_Epeeist. Beautiul bright orange in the glass, whitish head, some lacing. I think this is the beer that has converted me. Not to IIPAs, I already love the style. As a resident of San Diego, I even think I have a palate for the hops, if you will, and expect them in truckloads when it comes to a beer of this style. Yeah, yeah, there needs to be a syrupy malt tone, but the hops define the IIPA, at least around here. Yet, Dreadnaught is not of the SD mold. Rich, roasty, profound malts. Tons of hops, but not sledgehammer hops, more like constant hop caresses, like subtle reminders that you are in IIPA land. So balanced, so wonderful. Lives up to the hype and then some.

22 oz. bomber. Great aroma of citrus/grapefruit, pine and hop aroma that really kicks the taste buds into high gear. Pours a deep honey color, a bit cloudy, with a nice firm head. Nicely balanced flavors, very hoppy with a backgound sweetness. This is a real fine brew, great selection for this style of beer. If you like this one, you must try Great Divide Hercules.

Since seeing Pigffots reviews, I dont write anymore. I just copy his:

"Ive been a fan of Three Floyds since my taste buds first became acquainted with the flavor of Alpha King. Now, I am happy to have concluded a 22oz. server of another of their fine, over-the-top, wham-bam-thank-YOU, mam brews, the delicious, the delirious, the damnedfine Dreadnaught IPA. On first cracking the crown, a heavy waft of fruit invades the atmosphere, though the bottle and glass are both held at arms length. Appearance: a bright, beautiful ruby red, with a good, fluffy, creamy head. Aroma: bows to no one. Sharp pine resin, grapefruit, spruce?, tar, citrus fruit, and thats it, but thats quite an it, and ITS in full effect, yall. An invasion of flavor, an armada embarking its onslaught upon every sensory receptor open and ready to receive. Tasty fruitiness recurrs with every sip, rewarding the drinker anew, long-lasting finish, almost sticking in the throat and taking up residence permanently on the palate. Malt is nearly an even match for hops, almost, barely, but at least they provide quite sufficient ballast and body that makes this quite a drinkable brew. Fruit factor turns a trifle sweet after a time, but hop bitterness is always at hand to combat it. This would count among the list of beers to spoil myself to death with, if I were so inclined, and were capable of...Ill have another, and another, and a..whoops! too much! But, to quote Louis Jordan, "Ill die happy!"
Taste is better than apperance.  So hoppy and bitter it leaves you thirsty.  Now my definition of IPA.  Very dry with a bit of grapefruit.
Hoppy, citrusy, flowery aroma;amber with a small off-whitehead; flavor is of sweet hops with only a small amount of bitterness in the finish. My second favorite Imp IPA (Moylands Hopsicle is #1)

UPDATED: MAR 27, 2009 My favorite iipa, I often forget how great it is, until I pop it.  It pours a beautiful light copper with a tall beige head.  One of the best aromas grapefruit, pine, carmel, and florals.  That near perfect combination can make a man cry.  Really full bodied smooth, slick, carmel, great hop blend thats really grapefruity and a little pine floral tasting with a nice but not overlydone bitter finish.  Its not the hop bomb its sometimes accused of being, but a well balanced and when fresh a near perfect IIPA. 10/4/9/5/18 = 4.6    On many many many re-drinks, this beer has become quite unpredictable in the last couple years.  Very recent batch out of the bottle was dominated with a toffee malt that hardly showcased the hops and tasted like a bigger alpha king.  It really just got worse as I sipped down.  Less than a week later at the maproom on tap it was fresh bitter citrus, grapefruit and malt, nearly as good as it used to be.  The past years have brought me to believe it is the bottling, but none the less, too inconsistent.  A great beer that has always been one of my favorites, I wish it would always be as good as it can be.  9/4/8/5/16 = 4.2
Intense aromas of resinous pine, cannabis, and citrus.  Creamy head with delicate lacing and deep orange color. Flavors...beyond words...a beer epiphany...

Big pine and citrus aroma. Lots of tangy grapefruit, pine and floral flavors.  Slightly sweet, candy and alcohol finish. Still manages to be refreshing for such a big beer, not overwhelming. I was expecting a lot and I got it!

Bubbly orange pour with a small white head....fair lacing.  Heavy resin aroma to it.  Malts are exceptional....tons of fruit and caramel on the front end. just the right amount of hop bitterness in the end.  This is very good.

Bomber poured a hazy copper with a diminishing amber head. Aromas of grapefruit, pine, carmel and orange. Palate was medium bodied and dry. Flavors of grapefruit rind, carmel, light pine and light orange with a lingering bittersweet finish.
Hints of Orange on the nose with some floral touches.  I found it slightly off on the tip of my tongue but became really hoppy and bold on the end.  The finish is long and warm the whole way down.
